TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia;
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported;

that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the Australian Capital Territory Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material;
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia;
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Middle East: Australian Military Personnel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

. The hasty deployment of Australian military personnel to the Middle-East at the request of the President of the United States has involved Australia in an undeclared war with potentially disastrous consequences for Australia and the people of the Middle-East.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
. Immediately withdraw all Australian military personnel from the Middle East and pursue a foreign policy designed to secure justice and human rights for all of the people of the Middle-East.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990DEFENCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 and 28 November, on motions by Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill cognately. I commence my remarks by speaking to the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. I intend to speak only briefly on this matter as the Opposition supports this legislation. The Bill proposes to amend the Defence Force retirement and death benefits legislation to entitle spouses of deceased members of the Defence Force to commute a portion of their pension. The Bill also proposes to index the fixed element of the children's and orphan's pensions to movements in the consumer price index (CPI).

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1948, a child's pension is a composite fixed amount, which is currently $5,000 for the orphan's pension and $312 for other children. This element will index those fixed elements in accordance with the CPI from 1 July 1990. The Opposition has constantly pressed the Government to index these benefits. The orphans benefit was only recently raised, in October this year, from $702 to $5,000, bringing it up to date. It had been $702 for 18 long years.

The current legislation does not allow a surviving spouse of a Defence Force member to commute a portion of the pension payable to that spouse. This amendment in this legislation today provides the surviving spouse with that option. The amendment applies to the spouse of any contributor who dies on or after the date the amendment comes into operation. This will apply to the surviving spouses of any service members who die as a result of their posting to the Gulf. I am glad to see that both these anomalies will now be rectified. It was unjust for them to be allowed to continue for as long as they have.

The other part of this Bill proposes to amend the Defence Act to exempt two Commonwealth owned companies, Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd (ADI) and Aerospace Technologies of Australia (ASTA), from paying capital gains tax to the Commonwealth for sale of assets that were acquired from the Commonwealth when the two companies were created. The Bill also proposes that the depreciation arrangements will be adjusted to allow ADI and ASTA to calculate depreciation on assets as though they had been depreciated for the period of time they were directly held by the Commonwealth Government.

The Opposition believes that the payment of capital gains tax is inappropriate, considering that the only significant change is the corporatisation of the management structure of Commonwealth-owned defence industries and that the creation of ADI and ASTA was intended to make these facilities better run and more profitable. We therefore support this Bill.

I turn now to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. This Bill implements a number of initiatives announced by the Government in the last Budget as well as modifying important interpretive aspects of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The coalition is not opposed to the fundamentals of this piece of legislation. Indeed, we welcome a number of the changes, particularly those that have been taken directly from coalition policy. However, there are also a number of concerns, and I shall address these further today.

For some time there has been an inconsistency in the application of defence service home loan portability in that only those loans granted post-December 1987 were fully portable. Under the terms of this Bill, portability is being extended to all defence service home borrowers who had defence service home loans outstanding on 9 December 1987. This has been printed coalition policy since 1988. I am sure that the 140,000 eligible borrowers will be glad that the Government has at last implemented what the coalition has been promising for some time. The introduction of the availability of defence service home loans for assistance in meeting the cost of entry to a retirement village is also welcomed by the Opposition.

There remain, however, a number of serious anomalies in the defence service home loan scheme. For example, unless very particular and limited circumstances prevail, an eligible person cannot be granted a defence service home loan to discharge his or her bank mortgage on an existing home. For a constituent of mine whose husband is dying of cancer, this means that she will have no option but to leave her current home to buy another in order to get access to a loan. In representations to the Minister on this very issue, it was indicated that the provision is necessary for purely financial, cost saving reasons. Yet that same constituent is eligible to turn around tomorrow and borrow the same amount if she wants to extend her home. But she cannot pay out her present mortgage so that she can afford to keep her current home when she is widowed. Now the sale signs are up outside that home while the husband lies dying. The wife knows that as soon as it is sold she, and perhaps her dying husband, will have to move into a new home in order to get access to a loan for which he is eligible and for which he could make immediate application if it were only to extend his home. It is a nonsense.

The Government claims that this anomaly could not be addressed in this legislation because over 350,000 people could be in the position of being able to seek a defence service home loan to discharge their mortgage. Inquiries I have had conducted in the last few days indicate that this figure and the consequential financial impact estimates are wildly overstated.

This lack of rigorous research is symptomatic of the general approach of this Government. It is not interested in careful, in-depth investigation and discussion. It is not surprising, therefore, to see the Government, with the support of the Australian Democrats, gagging debate on all legislation before the Senate this week. Anomalies such as that which I have just highlighted cannot be fully addressed and debated in this atmosphere of gagged debate. It is bad enough to be gagging it in the House of Representatives, but traditionally the Senate has exercised its right to scrutinise legislation carefully clause by clause, and that is being prevented because of the time constraints today. The Government, because of its inept management of the flow of legislation coming into this chamber, has ensured that full and proper debate is stifled and many issues of importance-in this instance, issues of importance to hundreds of veterans and their families-are left unresolved.

The automatic granting of the war widow's pension to the widows of veterans who are in receipt of the extreme disablement adjustment is in line with similar provisions already existing for widows of totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners. One may well ask why the widows of intermediate rate pensioners were not included in this change. This is another anomaly which time constraints prevent us from pursuing further.

The indexation of allowances for certain disabled veterans is a logical extension of existing arrangements. These include recreation, transport, clothing and attendant allowances. The deeming provisions in this Bill, mirroring those found in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, have been the subject of much controversy. It was originally the Government's intention that a $2,000 threshold be applied to single pensioners and to married pensioner couples before interest of 10 per cent was deemed to be earned on money held in bank accounts or in cash. The Opposition expressed the concern that the $2,000 threshold would be unfair to a married couple. However, a drafting error in the legislation has apparently effectively set the threshold on deeming for married couples at $4,000. As a result of this, the Opposition does not intend to challenge that clause.

Also included in this Bill is the extension to members of the Australian Defence Force allotted for operational service in the Gulf of full repatriation benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. That this should be necessary is sobering. Just when it might have been thought that the role of the Department of Veterans' Affairs would be entering a period of decline, we now find the need to extend veterans' entitlements to new operational areas. This should act as a warning to the Government, which is doing its utmost to shed its responsibilities to veterans.

It is also sobering to think that 20 years ago Australia was committing troops to Vietnam in the interests of all Australians and that those veterans are still today fighting for recognition and compensation for the effects of agent orange. We have to ensure that personnel returning from the Gulf are not fighting for their entitlements 20 years from now.

This Bill amends the Veterans' Entitlements Act so that the recent Federal Court interpretation of the phrase `allotted for duty' will no longer be applicable. This interpretation resulted in former defence personnel qualifying for benefits under this Act that they would otherwise not have been eligible for under the previous repatriation legislation. In association with this change has been a rounding down of dates for two operational areas relating to Malaysian service. These last two changes will together ensure that the precedent set by the two recent Federal Court cases will no longer be applicable. The Department has said that the changes were made to restore the original intention of the Act. Indeed, study of the repatriation legislation in force before the Veterans' Entitlements Act reveals that the rounding down of dates will bring them into line with what they were previously. However, it is not clear why the operational dates were extended, seemingly inappropriately, in the drafting of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The Government has not been able to provide an adequate explanation as to why this should have occurred.

This Bill provides that the Minister has the authority to approve guidelines setting out the conditions under which a person can be considered to be suffering severe financial hardship in order to gain a defence service home loan for the purposes of discharging a mortgage or carrying out essential repairs. These guidelines have not yet been drafted and will not be a disallowable item.

It is important that such guidelines not be used in any way to diminish the circumstances under which such assistance may be granted. They should be subjected to review and, if necessary, to disallowance. It is for this reason that, in the consideration of this Bill by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, the Opposition proposed an amendment that the guidelines be made a disallowable instrument.

The importance of guidelines being disallowable could not be any better illustrated than in the case of another set of guidelines associated with the Veterans' Entitlement Act currently before the Senate. The third edition to the Guide to the Assessment of the Rates of Veterans' Pensions has serious deficiencies which the Government is being forced to address only because the guide is disallowable.

In the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs the Government agreed to support the Opposition's amendment. I would now like to make sure that clauses 11, 12 and 14, which refer to the same guidelines, are modified in line with the amendment to clause 9. I intend to move amendments to effect that purpose during the Committee of the Whole.

Clause 82 of the Bill relates to the provision of tax file numbers. In the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990, yet to be debated in the Senate, the Secretary to the Department is empowered to ask for tax file numbers from any person eligible for payment under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Importantly, under that piece of legislation, any eligible person will also be required to provide the tax file number of his or her spouse. Clause 82 of this Bill addresses the widespread concern at the requirement for eligible persons to supply the tax file number of their spouses. Under this clause, the Secretary to the Department may waive the requirement for provision of the tax file number of an eligible person's spouse if he is satisfied that the person does not know that number and that it would be unreasonably difficult to obtain that number. This clause really forms part of the overall legislative framework for data matching, which is expected to be debated in the Senate later today. As I indicated earlier, the Opposition supports the essence of the legislation before us, the concerns highlighted above notwithstanding.

I would like to finish by referring to an important issue raised in representations to the Senate Standing Committee which considered this Bill-that is, the complexity of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Senator Tate indicated to that Committee that the Department will be producing a plain English rewrite of the legislation. It was suggested that this would be available some time in the next 12 months. The sooner that this occurs the better. As one witness familiar with repatriation legislation from around the world testified, the Australian repatriation system is one of the most complex in the world.

As the bulk of our veterans population ages, every effort should be made to ensure stability, certainty and simplicity in the administration of veterans affairs. Sadly, we are seeing too many worrying and complex changes and a diminution of the caring approach which was available to veterans in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. The latter of those Bills, the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), is constructive. It is essentially a machinery Bill which tidies up a number of anomalies and it has some very positive elements.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill perhaps cannot be seen in quite as positive a light. It is important that we are clear about the climate that is out there in the veterans community. There is, unfortunately, a longstanding feeling of suspicion common among Australian veterans about what is happening to their entitlements and the attitude of governments towards them. Unfortunately, the Australian Democrats believe that to a degree this Bill reinforces that suspicion.

The Government attests that the proposed amendments inherent in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 implement Government election promises, give effect to Budget decisions and implement a range of other matters regarding the provision of benefits to veterans. All of this is obvious. However, what is not quite as obvious is that some of these amendments impact negatively upon entitlements that veterans already receive.

As I suggested, a very substantial portion of the veterans community is quite suspicious about what is happening in relation to their entitlements. I would like to cite some of the aspects of this legislation which tend unfortunately to reinforce that suspicion. The Democrats will be moving six amendments, four of which are directly at the request of veterans themselves, in an attempt to redress some of the negative features of this amending legislation.

The Government has not openly admitted in any of its statements that this amending legislation will reduce benefits. I will cite some instances. Two other amendments will be moved simply to carry over into this legislation amendments in relation to deeming provisions that we attempted to introduce to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2).

Honourable senators will be aware of the fact that some recent Federal Court of Australia decisions impact upon veterans entitlements. Senator Newman referred to them. The Federal Court decision in the case of Doessel v. Davies, which overturned a longstanding interpretation of the words `allotted for duty', has now given benefits to Defence personnel who have never before been regarded by the Department of Defence-and, therefore, the Department of Veterans' Affairs-as having performed operational services and, therefore, attracting entitlement.

The term `allotted for duty' is a critical one. It is one which is very close to the hearts of many ex-servicemen because it determines whether they are entitled to wear medals and whether they can claim for a veterans entitlement. This critical decision of the Court has impacted generously and extended entitlement. This legislation contains amendments to immediately withdraw that entitlement. There are those in the community who will see that as being in line with what they regard as the approach that has been brought to bear in the general area of veterans entitlements over a period of some years.

Some of the suspicion lies in the fact that, unfortunately, veterans, who hope that the Department of Veterans' Affairs would be their advocate, their ally and their friend, find themselves in a constant struggle to prove their case for entitlement before their own Department. In other words, they see it as the adversary. There is this dichotomy between the potential role of the Department being their advocate and the real role, which seems to be what they are constantly confronted with, namely, the Department actually being the adversary. This is inherently at the base of the suspicions which are out there and which are unfortunately reinforced by some aspects of this legislation.

I have just referred to the significance of the court case which decided the meaning of the term `allotted for duty'. The court case, which went in favour of ex-servicemen, is now being reversed by this legislation. The number of individuals concerned is minimal. The veterans community has been fighting for this right for a long time. Now that it has been given the right by a judgment of the Federal Court, the Government is seeking to overturn that right and to reverse the implications and the outcome of that court decision.

Senator Newman rightly cites the fact that a substantial number of the largest portion of veterans are now elderly. We are looking at the possibility that the number of people in the community affected by this legislation is reducing. Of course, we still have the Vietnam veterans who are desperately concerned about this trend of erosion of entitlement. Many of them are looking at another 30 years of life. Many of them have had their lifestyles dramatically impacted upon by the fact that they served in Vietnam. So they are keeping a very watchful and concerned eye upon what is happening to veterans entitlements.

As Senator Newman has correctly said, in the last few days we have seen the return of another group of servicemen who should have, and will have, entitlements under the veterans entitlement legislation. They join the Vietnam veterans. One would imagine, history being what it is, that a continuing group of Australian citizens, who have served their nation in war or in the preservation of peace, will have entitlements as veterans. Therefore, monitoring and constant vigilance will be necessary.

Senator Newman also said that the legislation is extremely complex. It will unfortunately remain so because the pieces have been put in place. We have special obligations as law-makers to monitor very closely what comes before us.

As I have foreshadowed, the Democrats will be moving six amendments: four specifically at the request of the veterans community to reverse some of the negative impacts of this legislation upon their entitlements and two which simply reflect the logical flowing across from social security legislation into the areas of veterans entitlements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Government welcomes the support indicated by the Opposition in respect of the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) of 1990; it is important legislation which has the effect of providing for spouses a very particular benefit. Commutation for spouses of the pension entitlements will generally be available from the date of commencement of the legislation and officers advise me that they expect that that can be done rather speedily as soon as the matter is passed through the Parliament. However, there is special provision to ensure that, in the unfortunate event of any casualties in the Persian Gulf deployment prior to the commencement of the amendment, a surviving spouse will also be eligible for commutation. I believe that that is an important matter to note.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators will know, the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Review Committee recommended that spouses be provided with the option to commute a portion of their pension entitlement-that is, the equivalent of two years of their former spouse's salary for pension purposes at the time of death-to a lump sum. It also recommended that the fixed rate elements of children's and orphans' benefits-$312 and $5,000 respectively-be indexed to movements in the consumer price index. The Government has accepted those recommendations and they form the basis of this part of the Bill. It is not surprising therefore that this part of the Bill has gathered the support of all those in the chamber. I thank honourable senators for their support as it will ensure the speedy passage of that legislation.

The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill has been the subject of considerable discussion by the Standing Committee on Community Affairs at a very fruitful and constructive meeting of that Committee. I will mention, for the sake of those who are listening, some of the main features of the legislation which make it so important. For example, and once again keeping in mind the very dangerous situation in the Middle East and the jeopardy which Defence Force personnel who have been deployed for operational service are in, it is important to note that under this Bill, and in providing certain repatriation benefits, the Government recognises that Australian Defence Force personnel deployed for operational service in the Middle East face a very real danger as a result of that service. The Government has decided therefore that all Australian Defence Force personnel allotted for operational service in the Middle East, including those deployed with United States or United Kingdom units, will be regarded as being on operational service once they reach the operational area. Until such time as they reach the operational area they will be regarded as being on hazardous service. This will ensure that they receive the benefit of the more generous standard of proof in determining eligibility for compensation under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

With the introduction of these amendments, eligible personnel will have access to disability pensions on the same generous standard of proof basis as war veterans. They will qualify for service pension and thus have entitlement to the equivalent of the age pension benefits five years earlier than others, as do war veterans. They will be eligible for repatriation medical treatment and associated benefits on the same basis as war veterans. Those service personnel who enlisted in the Australian Defence Force on or before 14 May 1985 will have access to subsidised low interest housing loans, insurance and other housing benefits under the Defence Service Homes Act. Those who enlisted after that date will be entitled to housing ownership assistance under the Australian Defence Force home loans assistance scheme to be implemented early in 1991. Finally, in the event of a member's service resulting in severe or fatal injury or disease, cover under the Act will also be available to that member's dependants.

I mention those matters just to emphasise the very real measures which the Government is taking in a way which anticipates the worst case, while, of course, it remains hopeful that terrible conflict, with resultant injury and death, can be avoided in the Middle East.

There are also changes to ensure a more equitable distribution of benefits to veterans and dependants. These include, for example, an increase in the rent assistance threshold by $10 a fortnight to $50 a fortnight from March 1991 for both single pensioners and pensioner couples to ensure that the level of rent assistance more realistically reflects the current level of housing costs. There is also an increase in the rates and automatic indexation of a range of benefits and allowances for severely disabled veterans, including allowance for specific injuries and disabilities, recreation and transport allowance, and clothing allowance. The rates of these allowances will be increased and, I believe, then indexed to reflect movements in the consumer price index.

In the course of what were, as I say, very fruitful and constructive discussions held during the Committee hearings, I indicated that the Government was prepared to accede to the request by the Opposition that certain guidelines be made disallowable instruments. Quite clearly, it is very useful and in accordance with the general role of this chamber that guidelines of importance which can affect the entitlements of Australian citizens-in this case, veterans-ought to be disallowable. In other words, they are laid before each House of the Parliament, and within 15 sitting days of that being done the proposed guidelines could be subject to disallowance.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills commented on the fact that the guidelines were not subject to disallowance. The Government, as always, has taken into account the report of the Committee because it believes that the sorts of principles and criteria used by that committee are such that they tend to remind governments occasionally of the need to provide for parliamentary scrutiny of guidelines which can have such an impact on those who benefit from legislative provisions. I believe that in this particular case, where guidelines set out the matters to be taken into account in deciding whether a person is suffering either financial or severe financial hardship, matters such as those are eminently suitable for the disallowance type procedure.

In the course of the Committee hearings there was also comment about income from certain moneys being deemed to attract a particular interest rate. I think in the legislation the rate was set at 10 per cent per annum for the purposes of the income test. A couple of issues were raised in the Committee hearing in relation to this. One concerned the way in which the legislation was drafted so that, as drafted, a $2,000 threshold would apply to a single person and married couples would be allowed $2,000 for each person before any interest was deemed to have been received. In the Committee hearing I reserved the position of the Government in relation to that matter. On maturer reflection, the Government has decided to allow the draft provisions to stand and I will not be moving any amendment, as I foreshadowed, in relation to those threshold amounts. That is, a married couple can have a total of $4,000 before any interest is deemed to have been received for the purposes of the deeming provision.

There was also considerable discussion at the Committee hearing about the 10 per cent interest rate. Given the constant fluctuation of interest rates, it was nevertheless noted that the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, gave an undertaking that that rate would be reviewed before the provision commences operation in March of next year. I think in the Committee discussion it was thought that, given the considerable volatility and fluctuations that are occurring week by week, it is sensible that the Committee itself not try to establish a different rate; rather, the undertaking by Senator Richardson should be relied upon in order to set a realistic rate before the provision commences operation in March of next year.

I believe the work of the Committee was very useful and I believe the second reading debate indicates that, on the whole, this legislation deserves the support the chamber. I commend the second readings of the Bills.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
