PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 and 15 November, on motions by Senators Collins and McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us six Bills relating to education, affecting a wide range of educational issues. The Opposition condemns the Government for the way it is managing education in this country at the higher education level, the technical and further education (TAFE) level and the schools level. In particular, it has bungled the program of overseas student participation in our education system in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, today we are faced with two Bills which are to repair the bungles that this Government has brought upon the overseas students of Australia. One Bill is totally intolerable and a disgrace because it will, by Government decision-if this Parliament agrees to it-force compulsory student unionism on the higher education institutions of this country. The Opposition is totally opposed to it. The three remaining Bills provide thousands of millions of dollars in the normal way-that is, from the Commonwealth-for the provision of all the costs of our higher education, TAFE and schools.

A wide range of education issues is included in each of the six Bills. My first observation is that in past years we have had two sets of education funding Bills in each year. In the Budget sitting we would deal with the major provision of funds for the following year, and in the autumn session we would consider supplementary funding Bills which would top up grants in accordance with whatever supplementation policy applied. This year the two are combined so that we get supplementation for this year and new provision for next year-in fact, at the end of the triennium in some cases-occurring at the same time. This means, of course, that we have one opportunity for debate in this Senate and, indeed, in the House of Representatives on the Government's education legislation instead of the usual two.

In the House of Representatives there was a guillotine and there was not even time for the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) to reply to the speeches that the members of the House of Representatives gave. Here in this Senate-let the Australian public know-there is a guillotine whereby there are only two hours to discuss these six important Bills that affect education throughout the country. We will have to be self-disciplined in order to allow the Minister to respond and give answers to those matters about which we are still seeking replies.

I am critical that we are limited not only by guillotines in the debate on these Bills, but also by the actual occasions for there to be an education debate in the Parliament being reduced. Nonetheless, it is deplorable that we are so restricted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get on with the issue, then. You are wasting time.

—I will get on with it. I turn, firstly, to the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1990. The Opposition does not oppose this Bill for it serves to set fees and needs for those students who are still covered by the former policy of the subsidised overseas students scheme. However, it is important to note that in this area the Government has been guilty of a significant breach of faith towards education institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government announced in December 1988 that the subsidised program was being replaced with a new full fee and scholarships program, the Ministers making the announcement-Mr Dawkins and Senator Evans-said that institutions would not be hurt financially by the change. Overseas students would no longer be counted as part of an institution's student load, but the Government then claimed that the funding lost by this change would be made up by the scholarships awarded to overseas students attending these institutions.

Less than two years later, the Government has broken its word. The scholarships scheme is short-changing the institutions. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee has estimated the shortfall to be $1.7m in 1990, $8.2m in 1991 and $8.3m in 1992. It is little wonder that the Vice-Chancellors Committee described itself as incensed by this breach of faith. What will the Government be doing about honouring its promise?

I turn, secondly, to the Overseas Students (Refunds) Bill 1990. This is the Government's attempt to pick up the broken pieces from its own policy disaster. There has been a massive growth in the education export industry in recent years. If this were well handled and soundly administered it would have the potential to be of great benefit to Australia and, of course, to the other countries-especially in our near region-from which the overseas students come. However, as things have turned out, the Government's maladministration has not brought this full benefit and, at the same time, this has become a disaster area for Australia's reputation overseas. The Minister has failed to foresee the problems that would arise and failed to act promptly when problems did start to emerge.

Opposition spokesmen have been consistently critical of the mismanagement of the Government. The Government failed to provide a proper framework within which the industry could grow. The Minister has failed to establish a process for the provision of visas and the policing of compliance with visa conditions. The failure to establish a framework for the proper vetting of visa applications until after June last year resulted in some students entering the country under false pretences. The failure to ensure visa compliance resulted in some students remaining in Australia illegally.

The belated attempts to remedy the problems resulted in significant visa rejection rates for students who had already prepaid their fees. Hence the need now for the Government to make this provision for repayments, for the tightening up-when it eventually came-came at a time when not all institutions were in a position to refund the moneys to those applicants who were refused visas. The process is that overseas students had to pay the money with their applications ahead of time, and institutions in financial difficulties are not able to refund the moneys, so the Government now, through all this mismanagement, has to have this legislation to pick up the pieces. This legislation, which will require the Australian taxpayers to reimburse students for their lost fees, is an admission by the Government that its own policy changes led to the losses.

I now refer to one clause in particular, clause 5, which raises a concern with regard to information collection. I refer to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which states:
Clause 5 of the Bill empowers the Secretary (or an officer authorised in writing) to issue notices to an educational institution (or its agent) requiring them to supply ``particulars''--
What does `particulars' mean? That is what the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is concerned about. The report continues:

of overseas students enrolled at the institution. This may be considered to involve a breach of students' privacy, as there is no indication of the kinds of information covered by ``particulars'' or the uses to which such information could be put. Though there is no formal requirement to do so, the Committee also notes that neither the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill nor the Minister's Second Reading speech refer to the Privacy Commissioner having been consulted on this matter. The Committee draws Senators' attention to the clause as it may trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties, in breach of principle 1 (a) (i) of the Committee's terms of reference.

I trust that the Minister, Senator Bolkus, in responding to the debate, will explain more clearly the Government's position on this clause. I hope there will be a Minister's reply to the debate. As I said earlier, there was not any Minister's reply to the debate on these Bills in the House of Representatives.

I make one other reference to clause 5; that is, to observe that clause 5 (1) requires institutions to respond to requests for information within 14 days. This is potentially unsatisfactory as there is no correlation between the amount of information requested and the amount of time provided to satisfy the request. The Department of Employment, Education and Training has a reputation for demanding detailed and complex information from institutions. It may well be that 14 days is too short a time. There is a discretion for the period to be longer than 14 days, and I hope that that discretion will be used wherever appropriate.

Another aspect of this problem is the situation of students already in Australia who have been denied access to moneys paid by them-their own money-before they arrived in Australia for living allowance purposes. The Government has said that it will give a refund to cover the outstanding living allowance payments to such students where the institutions in which they are enrolled have closed down. I support such payments because it is Australia keeping good faith with these students. What is not clear to me is exactly what the Government is doing where institutions are in difficulty but have not reached the point of closing their doors, yet they have not the cash flow to actually give the living allowances received from overseas students as prepayments back to those students while they are undertaking courses in Australia.

The explanatory memorandum states that institutions that seem able to trade their way out of their difficulties may receive some short term assistance. I ask Senator Bolkus for a more detailed picture of what that assistance will be. What is the maximum amount envisaged? Will any interest be paid on any loans at a market rate or some lesser concessional rate? Will the assistance be made available speedily in cases where it is needed to pay outstanding amounts of living allowance to students?

My concern is chiefly for the students. After all, it is preposterous that the Government requires prior payment of living allowances, but has not made any provision for that money to be paid into a trust account so that it is safeguarded for return to those students for living allowance purposes when they are in Australia. A number of cases have been directly brought to my attention where students are suffering as a result of that problem. Imagine students at the University of New South Wales who have prepaid their living allowance-it is their money. Then they find that the institution-it would not be the case with the University of New South Wales, but it may be with some private institutions-is in financial difficulty and says, `Sorry, we can't give you your own money'. I believe that the scheme needs to be extended for institutions that have closed down, so that there is no failure of good faith on Australia's part.

Of course, the basic answer to this problem is that there needs to be these trust funds. The Government has given notice of legislation which will require such trust funds for these payments in the future. But this is required under separate legislation for regulating the education export industry. However, the Government has botched the job of drafting even that legislation. It was done in a hurry without adequate consultation with the States, institutions or student representative organisations, and as a result there have been numerous objections to it in its draft form. The Minister has now agreed to start consulting-hooray! So the legislation, which should have been in better shape through consultation in the first place, is not now before us. This means that the Bill will not be debated by the Senate before Christmas but will be held over until the new year. This is a Bill which, when it was introduced this year, the Minister claimed was very urgent. Of course it is urgent and this Government is not administering itself properly. On behalf of the Opposition, I move:
At end of motion add: ``, but the Senate:
deplores the Government's mismanagement of the education export industry''.

I now turn to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1990. This is a most shameful piece of legislation. It denies choice, it is against freedom of association and it is grossly hypocritical on the Government's part to boot. It should be thrown out root and branch. Even now I appeal to the Australian Democrats to join with the Opposition in throwing out this shameful piece of government legislation.

This Labor Government wants this Parliament to legislate to restrict freedom of choice for students when we should be legislating to enhance and entrench freedom of choice. The Bill supports compulsory student unionism in our higher education institutions. Indeed, it goes to the lengths of using the Commonwealth's pre-eminent position in the funding of higher education to thwart any State government that wishes to act to ensure freedom of choice for students. That this Government or any government should act to enforce compulsion in this matter is deeply offensive to the Opposition, and also the public, in philosophical terms and in practice. Students should have a free and unfettered choice as to whether they join the student union at their institution. It is as simple as that. Individual students should decide whether they wish to join a union and get the benefits that may derive from membership of it-the use of its facilities, the concessions it arranges and so on. Students should be free to decide whether it will be worth while for them to join. The obligation should be on student unions to market themselves effectively to students to persuade them that it is worth while joining.

There is also a directly political aspect to this matter. The left wing Ministers, Mr Dawkins, Mr Baldwin and Senator Bolkus, understand the politics of this matter. They know that student unions have tended, except in some glorious years, to be controlled by the Left. The funds of student unions have been applied not merely to provide facilities on campus but to achieve political objectives that benefit the Left of politics in this country. This is why this Labor Government is bringing this Bill forward. It sees advantages for its own political cause in having its political allies on campuses being able to use student union funds by a sort of monopoly power without having to do any work for them-to use them as a slush fund for political purposes to help this Government. Maybe it will backfire on the Government and in fact will help opponents of the Government who are even further to the Left than the Australian Labor Party.

But it is not just this political application that concerns us. We are deeply offended by this legislation. It is against the philosophy of the Liberal and National parties and so we reject it in principle. Students' academic careers should not be dependent upon their membership of a student union; yet that is the current position. There have been suggestions from time to time that State governments, under whose legislation most higher education institutions are in fact established, may move to insist on voluntary student unionism under that legislation. That is not happening anywhere as yet, but the mere thought of it has alarmed the Government and the student Left, and so the Federal Government has bought into the issue with this Bill. More than that, I make it clear that if the Bill is passed at this time it will be repealed by us when we return to office. Our policy is that Federal legislation should be on the side of liberty and should insist that there be voluntary student unionism.

The Government has argued for this Bill in terms of the autonomy of educational institutions. What hypocrisy! This is a sad joke when we consider the huge extent of heavy-handed and centralist intervention in the running of institutions in which Mr Dawkins indulges. In any case, when it comes to individual rights and freedoms it is not satisfactory to say that autonomy means that institutions have the right to impose this form of compulsion on their students. I do not doubt that educational administrators who like a quiet life can be found to support compulsory student unionism, but I would argue that their convenience is hardly a satisfactory basis for policy. The issue of freedom of choice is so fundamental that it should not be left to institutions to decide upon. It is entirely reasonable for State governments to legislate to insist upon it and it is quite wrong for this Federal Government to try to stop them doing so.

In the Senate we have already had some debate on these issues when the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1990 was before us last week. Clause 12 of that Bill was related to this higher education Bill. I and other members of the Opposition spelt out then our objections to compulsory student unionism, and we repeat all of those objections today. I press on to the fourth Bill, the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Teague, do you have an amendment to the second reading of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill?

—No, we totally reject it. I now turn to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2). This Bill is in large measure a routine Bill, for it provides the funding for higher education institutions for 1993 and also provides supplementation funding for 1990, 1991 and 1992. This is as we would expect. The Bill simply continues the policy framework for higher education funding which has already been established, but it provides for a set of policies of which I and the Opposition generally have long been very critical. We reject the way that this Government is handling higher education. We will do it differently and better, and we long for the day of our election when we can start to put our policies into effect.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Dawkins has given us a higher education system that is centralised and, with all due respect to the officers present, bureaucratised. This is a criticism which can be levelled at the style of operation of a Labor government. It impinges far too greatly on those decisions about the setting of institutions' own priorities which are best left to individual institutions to make. For example, Mr Dawkins's elaborate requirements for institutional profiles to be negotiated with his Department have been a mechanism for putting into the Government's hands a whole range of highly significant decisions about the structure and operations of all of our higher education institutions. These mechanisms require that institutions provide massive amounts of information to the Department-requirements which have proved to be a major administrative burden. Many institutions have complained that the conditions formulated as part of the profiles process are almost impossible to comply with and have resulted in even greater losses of their own per capita funding.

The policies flowing from the infamous White Paper of the Hawke-Keating-Dawkins Labor Government have forced institutions into amalgamations in which they would not have chosen to participate if they had been left to their own educational judgments and initiatives. Amalgamations have occurred under financial pressure from the Government rather than for justifiable educational reasons. We are reminded of this when we look at clause 4 of this Bill which, because of amalgamations, revises the list of institutions funded by the legislation.

Most recently, we have the direct example of this Government's coercive attitude in the funding of higher education institutions in Victoria. Because the Victorian institutions have not proceeded to amalgamate with each other in the way or at the speed that Canberra wants, the Dawkins-Baldwin Labor Government and bureaucracy here in Canberra have announced future funding details for higher education, not in terms of individual allocations for Victorian institutions for 1992 and 1993 but set out in global amounts, pending the Government-forced amalgamations. We have already seen this happen to South Australia. The Government wants to coerce institutions into behaving as the Government wishes and it is using direct threats of funding as a means to achieve this. This interference policy, this policy of coercion, is a disgrace.

Another major problem is the education advisory mechanism to the Minister. The National Board of Employment, Education and Training structure, including the four councils under NBEET, places these advising bodies in the departmental structure rather than, as in the past, allowing them a sufficient independence and a demonstrated separate integrity. NBEET and its councils depend on departmental officials for their administrative support, a symbol of how they are too close to the Department to best serve Australian education.

The public perception of NBEET and the education councils is that they appear to be nobbled by the Minister, but their true role is to consult with all education interests and expertise and to present-as much to the Minister as to the Parliament-independent advice which is open and sound and which demonstrates an independent integrity. The only way to achieve this now is with a change of government. In the meantime, this side of the House encourages NBEET and the councils to do their best to become independent and sound in their advice to this Government.

Australia continues to have a problem of unmet demand, estimated for 1990 as being somewhere between 13,500 and 20,100 potential students. That is 20,000 students who want to go to higher education institutions, our universities, and who are denied that opportunity. Of particular concern is that that unmet demand is the same this year as it was last year and not very different from the year before. Officials indicated in Estimates committee hearings that the number of new places to be offered in 1993 would be approximately 3,000. There is a pattern of steady decline in the number of new places being funded each year since 1989. There were 6,500 new places in 1989; 5,800 in 1990; and there will be 4,800 in 1991; 4,000 in 1992; and 3,000 in 1993.

This Bill also increases the rate of repayment for students who are paying their higher education contribution on a deferred basis. The repayment levels, which were previously one, 2 and 3 per cent of income, depending on income level, are all to be increased by one per cent to 2, 3 and 4 per cent. The nature of Labor's higher education contribution scheme requires students to make long term financial decisions, but they can hardly plan such decisions if the Government suddenly changes the arrangements and increases the repayment rate. On behalf of the Opposition, I therefore move as an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990:
At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate:

(a) deplores the Government's mismanagement of higher education and its failure to establish a satisfactory framework for the development of an internationally competitive higher education sector; and
(b) deplores in particular, the Government's:
(i) failure to address adequately the issue of quality in higher education;
(ii) failure to provide a proper framework for accountability with respect to the exercise of ministerial discretion;
(iii) imposition of intrusive institutional profiles on tertiary institutions as a precondition for funding;
(iv) failure to make inroads into the level of unmet demand;
(v) failure to provide institutions with the freedom and flexibility needed to address the impending shortage of academic staff;
(vi) policy of forced amalgamations and damaging pressures it has created towards institutional uniformity;
(vii) disarray in relation to the export of education; and
(viii) failure to undertake any meaningful assessment of the impact of its policies on the higher education section''.

I have two Bills yet to refer to and I notice that I have only three minutes remaining. The States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill gives us an opportunity to reflect on the present state of the TAFE sector. This is timely, since the Deveson report has been released quite recently. Our thinking is hardly helped by a particularly thin second reading speech from the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus). It contains only two substantive paragraphs, each of them consisting of only one sentence. We deplore this Government's lack of accountability to this Parliament about TAFE or about any of these education issues. The second reading speech completely fails to provide us with any assessment of the framework surrounding the funding that this Bill provides. Because of the shortage of time, I ask that the remainder of my remarks on the TAFE Bill be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows-

In its policy for TAFE, as elsewhere in education, the Commonwealth has been overly bureaucratic and centralist. A recent report of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training observed that there has been a trend for resource agreement commitments to become increasingly numerous and complex over time. It also noted the concern on the part of the States and Territories that such agreements often fail to account for regional factors. With respect to the complexity of the resource agreements, a second report of NBEET noted that this trend had worsened with respect to objectives suggested for 1991. As in the school and tertiary education sectors, the Commonwealth's demands for information have been criticised. The NBEET report described the Commonwealths demands in this area as excessive and inappropriate. As well, this report noted that the Commonwealth's demands tend to focus on quantitative as opposed to qualitative indicators. This criticism of the objectives and indicators as `excessive' was repeated in the second NBEET report. The NBEET report noted that there is little evidence of follow-up by the Commonwealth where commitments are not met by the States and Territories and several Commonwealth priority areas are poorly reported on. The second NBEET report also criticised the lack of information given to the States and territories about the final allocation of grants. This has created a perception that the Commonwealth is playing TAFE systems off against each other.

Into this far from satisfactory situation of present arrangements has come the Deveson report. While the Opposition naturally does not commit itself to endorsing every single recommendation in that report, we do very much welcome its general thrust, and we see it as a most important document in enabling governments to chart a clearer course ahead for the development of training in our economy. The Opposition has long been calling for a more responsive and flexible TAFE sector. We therefore are pleased to see that report's urging of a market-responsive TAFE system. A significant barrier to this has been ill-conceived Commonwealth regulation, which has led to a confusing array of fees and charges.

I draw attention to a significant development, which Deveson refers to, and that is the increasing significance of private sector training in the total training effort of this country. Governments must take full account of this, and ensure that the regulatory framework in no way impedes that development but, rather, aids and enhances it. This presents the TAFE sector with a challenge, and it may need to reorient its approach in the future. In this regard I note that Deveson recommends that TAFE should move more towards support and development of in-house training activities and provide less direct training itself.
On behalf of the Opposition I move as an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill:
At the end of motion add: ``,but the Senate:
(a) deplores the Government's:
(i) imposition of increasingly numerous and complex goals on the TAFE sector; and
(ii) imposition of performance indicators which are in some instances excessive and inappropriate or counter-productive; and
(b) calls on the Government:
(i) to review the whole range of excessive regulatory demands it has placed on the TAFE sector and instead pursue the establishment of open and flexible training markets;

(ii) in particular, not only to widen the financial flexibility of the TAFE sector but also to provide significant autonomy in staffing matters so as to encourage the development of a TAFE sector which is flexible, competitive and responsive to consumer demand''.

The final one of these six Bills is the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill. Its major purpose is to provide supplementary funding for 1990 and new funding for 1991 to the schools sector from the Commonwealth. As well, it makes some relatively minor changes to the structure of the funded programs. The Minister's speech refers to these items, and I will not repeat the detail of them. I refer to clause 21 of the Bill. Again, I can either seek leave to have five more minutes to complete my speech or I can, inadequately, incorporate some material. I ask for an extension of five minutes. (Extension of time granted)

I thank the Senate. I wish to refer in particular to clause 21 of the Bill, which seeks to insert a new part VIIb into the Act to allow the Commonwealth to make grants to cover extra expenditure made necessary through award restructuring. Schedule 19 tells us that $50m is provided for this purpose in 1990-1991. I ask the Government how it determined that figure, which seems a pretty arbitrary one. Can the Minister tell us how this will be administered? What will be the allocation between government and non-government schools? What proportion of salary cost increases are expected to be met by the Commonwealth under this program? How will the Government use the mechanism provided by the requirement for schools and school systems to enter into agreements with the Commonwealth if they are to benefit from this scheme? Will this simply be another opportunity for the Commonwealth to interfere in the detail of the running of our schools, when there is no real need for it to do so?

In particular, the Opposition has difficulty arising from the expression `complying with an approved award', which occurs in the proposed new subsection 40f (2). This difficulty arises because schools which have been exempted from the award but which follow the award in setting salary rates for staff may not fall within such a provision. Compliance implies a legal obligation and, being exempt from the award, such a legal obligation cannot be said to exist for some schools. There exist many non-systemic, non-government schools which are in fact exempt from the award.

I have been further informed that it is not unusual for such schools nonetheless to set their salary rates in a manner consistent with the award. So the Opposition believes it would not be fair for such schools to miss out on government assistance for award restructuring merely because they cannot be said to be complying. The Minister for Administrative Services, who is at the table, is aware that we have had discussions. As a result of these discussions, a proposed amendment on the Opposition's part that we believe would have solved the difficulty has been withdrawn because we will accept a committee stage Government amendment to achieve the purposes to which I have just referred.

The Bill does not change the central elements of the Government's schools policies. These policies have received a good deal of criticism from the Opposition, and the Government shows no sign of significantly adjusting its approach to meet those criticisms. I seek leave to have the remainder of my remarks on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows-

For example, there is a very great deal of concern in the Australian community about the standards of the education our school students are receiving. There is no constructive recognition of this community concern on the part of this Government. The Opposition has in its policy spoken of the need to have a national standards monitoring program. We believe that the community has good reason to be concerned about education standards, and community debate will be greatly assisted if there is available much more information about the standards being achieved by students.

Hence the need for programs that will monitor this in some detail. Unfortunately the Minister for Employment, Education and Training shows no serious interest in acting on this point. He should reject the advice that he is getting from those administrators and educationalists who are complacent about standards or who blandly try to assure us that all is well in our schools. Standards do matter, the wider community is concerned about them, and I say to the Government that it should face up to this, as the Opposition has long been urging.

Again, the Commonwealth shows no signs of backing away from the unwarranted intrusiveness of its complex programs for funding non-government schools. Its so-called ``new schools'' policy, which in fact seeks to minimise the number of new non-government schools opening, is a good example of this. This policy and the unduly intrusive accountability provisions for non-government schools will go, under the next coalition government. And the funding categories for non-government schools will be significantly simplified. The announcement by the Minister during the election campaign and reiterated by him in November of his plans for post-1992 funding arrangements does not meet the Opposition's criticisms on these points at all. The Government needs to reverse its present inclinations and instead adopt education policies that nurture diversity and excellence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, I move on behalf of the Opposition a second reading amendment in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion add: ``, but the Senate:
(a) deplores the Government's excessive centralised regulation of the schools sector and in particular its:
(i) attempt to control the growth in the Non-Government school sector through the New Schools Policy;
(ii) pricing of Non-Government schools out of the reach of many parents through its Post 1992 funding policy; and
(iii) excessive and intrusive accountability requirements through the mechanism of resource agreements;
(b) deplores the Government's mishandling of education at the recent Premiers' Conference and the Government's failure to address properly the vital national issue of school standards; and

(c) calls on the Government to adopt a policy which gives much greater weight to the right of parents in both the Government and Non-Government school sectors to make informed choices between high quality education offerings.''.

I thank the Senate for extending my half hour to 35 minutes. In conclusion, I present the views of the Opposition on these six Bills. I have been able to refer to only some of the matters that I would have wished to bring to the attention of the Parliament. I greatly regret that we have only two hours set aside for this debate, with many people wanting to speak. Many will not get a chance to speak at all. I deplore the way this Government is handling education. This is a failed Labor Government, and the sooner we have an election and get education onto a proper policy basis the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is addressing a package of six education Bills: the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill, the Overseas Students (Refunds) Bill, the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill, the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2), the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill. Yet again the Government has left the education debate until the end of the session. We had a few histrionics at the beginning of the debate when Senator Teague treated us to a couple of minutes of unnecessary, repetitive verbiage about the time that has been devoted to this debate. I find that strange when we needed to grant an extension of time at the end, and strange also with regard to the fact that the debate has already had its parameters drawn. We are all well aware of what this debate is about, as the issues have been flagged for some decades. In addition, other speakers for the coalition have simply not fronted. Probably they have worked out that they have nothing left to say.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by addressing the controversial Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill. While this Bill is an undisguised threat to any State which would obstruct the collection of fees for a student association, the Australian Democrats do not accept the Government's justification for it in terms of institutional autonomy. Institutional autonomy is a fine sounding phrase, but the most important aspect of that phrase is that it is academic institutional autonomy.

I do not share the coalition's abhorrence of centralism. There are some good aspects of national policies, particularly, for example, in respect of national consistency regarding students' rights and obligations, Austudy provisions, and the quality of instruction which people would expect to have available to them at tertiary institutions. So centralism or a national consistency is not per se a real concern.

Institutional autonomy in the area of the particular curriculum provided and perhaps even the fee structure which is justified by that curriculum is certainly something which should be preserved. In the use of that phrase we should not confuse the opportunity for students to be guaranteed national consistency of their rights and obligations with institutional autonomy. The Democrats believe that all students should be required to pay a services and amenities fee. The level of that can be determined by the institution concerned. That is autonomy. The cafeteria at Monash University versus the cafeteria at the University of New England can vary as the campuses decide. There is no need for a heavy handed bureaucracy to oversee those areas. There can be some degree of autonomy in the areas that I have already mentioned.

There need not be an objection to a national consistency regarding students' rights and obligations. No student should be compelled to be a member of any association as a result of enrolling at a tertiary institution. These principles are distinct from the misplaced interpretation this Government has of `institutional autonomy'.

In the context of academic freedom, it is disappointing that funding for higher education is at the moment inadequate and research projects remain heavily prescribed. Education and access to it continue to be compromised by this Government while it concerns itself with this contrived and transparent Bill, which needs to be associated with what I believe is an unassociated Bill concerning States' grants to bring about the philosophical attachment which this Government has towards compulsory student unionism. I foreshadow an amendment to this Bill in the committee stage which would ensure that each student has the opportunity to choose whether or not to become a member of any student association.

Students who declined membership would still have to pay the full student services fee. This money would support all the other services and amenities but would not be used for the benefit of any association. This ensures that students who do not wish to join the student association, for example, do not join or subsidise activities that they object to.

Our position here recognises that many institutions have, in fact, failed to provide a fair and proper clause for giving students the right to decide on membership. It is commonly referred to as the conscientious objection clause, which is not consistent across the nation. Currently about 60 per cent of institutions have some opting out provisions, and the grounds for so-called conscientious objection under those sorts of procedures are usually limited to religious or cultural grounds. The students are in many cases not informed of this right and it may be granted at the institution's discretion rather than as an automatic right. Some institutions even support an additional charge upon their students for exercising that right. In these circumstances at the moment, the students' money still goes through to the student association, except in some cases-very few cases, I might add-where it is directed towards a nominated charity.

The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) drew an analogy between living in a city and being represented by a local government body. Quite frankly, that analogy fails because living in a city does not oblige residents to join any association or union. One can easily dissociate oneself from the political activities of a city council. Residents are not required to join a residents union before settling in a particular city.

The Minister's use of this analogy merely illustrates to me that he does not really understand the dynamics of campus life. He may see it as equitable that a young person be required to join a student union before that person pursues academic studies; I do not. I see no relationship between the union and the academic studies. The provision of amenities may or may not be associated with student unions; it might be associated with some other sort of association. Student unions may have provided considerable amenities at a particular campus. But in other cases, amenities may have resulted from bequests or actions of organisations. Amenities may have been provided by the administration of the university. It is fair and proper that all users should pay for the use of whatever amenities are on site. It is not proper that any student should be coerced into becoming a member of any association, whether that be medieval German poetry readers or the political union of students.

I do not share Senator Teague's paranoia about student unions mainly being to the political left. That is irrelevant. Whatever the student unions are-whether they are off to the right, off to the left or up in the sky-is irrelevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with you. Whether it is to the right or left, it is the principle that matters.

—I thank the honourable senator. I do not share the assertion that Senator Bolkus expressed to me privately-nevertheless I do not think he will mind me mentioning it-that the Vietnam war moratorium protests would have failed if it was not for compulsory unionism. I believe sincerely that that issue would have reigned supreme and would have emerged whether there were compulsory student unions at the time or not. I have faith in those who took part in that protest against government policy at the time. As a participant in the moratorium, I was totally unaware that we had a union on site anyway; I participated quite happily not knowing what it was.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is this confused entanglement of union, politics and business with the daily operations of tertiary campuses that is the real problem. While this Government, either studiously or in ignorance, maintains that entanglement, the freedom of Australia's tertiary students will be compromised.

The Government would be advised to drop this legislation on the basis of the amendment which I hereby foreshadow. Our proposal will preserve the ability of institutions to determine fees-whatever they may be-for student services. However, the institutions must respect the right of every student to choose whether to become a member of any association which may or may not be on campus.

I turn briefly to this Government's appalling treatment of overseas students. While our course fees are comparatively reasonable, students coming to Australia are subjected to a multitude of charges, including increased visa processing and medical charges. Struggling students who may arrive here not necessarily knowing much of the infrastructure of our society, what is expected and what the level of fee payments for all sorts of services is, often are even ineligible for transport and other concessions.

The situation is incredible if we compare Australia's treatment of tourists who come here for two or three weeks with the treatment of and our attitude towards overseas students who come here, pay us for the education services which we sell them and also contribute quite extensively to our economy. In fact, I think these students put more into our economy than they take out-and here I am talking about the cost of food, accommodation, transport and so on. Yet, we still do not seem to recognise those aspects. We are making it difficult for these students even to enter Australian society let alone participate in it and gain whatever they can from it. I speak of these matters from some experience, having been involved with some students from a couple of overseas countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were going to say you were once a student for a short time.

— I was at one stage. I did learn a little bit in the past but recently I have had direct personal contact with students from overseas countries. My personal contact was mainly initiated because I was frustrated at seeing how little infrastructure support our Government provides for these students.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's confused and contradictory policies in the area of education export, as well as in the area of immigration, have damaged Australia's international reputation. I do not think we need to rely on my anecdotal evidence for the demonstration of that fact. As Senator Teague mentioned, that is particularly the case in respect of the debacle over refunded fees to students who had prepaid their courses and who later were refused visas. I agree with Senator Teague that this can only be described as incompetence. Australian taxpayers will have to pay millions of dollars for this incompetence, which was entirely unnecessary.

Through the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Government is seeking to increase the rate of payment of the deferred higher education contribution charge. This will refill the Government's coffers more quickly but it does not yield any gross extra income. The accelerated payments are also regressive. This is a major area of concern to us because they fall disproportionately on lower income earners. Those who fall within the lowest income bracket will pay 100 per cent more and those in the highest bracket will pay only 25 per cent more. This flies in the face of equity and further penalises students who cannot afford to take advantage of the 15 per cent discount saving available if they pay up front.

The Democrats have always opposed a tertiary tax and we particularly object to this clause which seeks to impose further burdens on students at the very time when they are faced with personal economic stringency because they are studying rather than working. In most cases they have not had the time to build up the capacity to meet their financial obligations.

The Democrats regard the increased rate of payments under the higher education contribution scheme as a breach of the original contract which was reached between the Government and the students enrolled. To rearrange that, to change the rules in the middle of the game, is just un-Australian. There in no other way to describe it. Part of the way we look at things in this country is not to change the rules in the middle of the game. But that is precisely what is proposed here. Many students have already made financial plans and they are entitled to rely on those plans. Accordingly, I would like to see the Government reconsider its position and ensure that the payments do not operate retrospectively.

I will speak briefly on the commitment to technical and further education (TAFE), which is indicated in the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1990. The commitment illustrated in this Bill is frankly pathetic. The Government has spoken often of retraining, multi-skilling and award restructuring. It is trying to administer the training guarantee scheme although it has had a great deal of difficulty in respect of registered industry training agents. Also, it is masterminding many changes to the industrial profile of Australia. However, it has not, in this Bill or in any other Bill I have seen, sought to give TAFE the opportunity to become a partner in this process.

I believe that we now have a set of organisations across the country which are unsure of their resources. If the organisations are unsure of their resources, they are unsure of the availability of expanded resources to meet these changes being implemented by the Government. They are certainly unsure of their orientation or of what the Government expects of TAFE institutions in this change process, because they have not really been given the message that they are part of the team to achieve these monumental changes. I see no opportunity in this Bill to bolster TAFE or to include it in these great changes that are sweeping across the country.

The problem is that the Government somehow thinks it is all going to be done by mirrors, that these sorts of things just happen on autopilot. There is no specific direction. In this Bill we could have had greatly increased funding or at least an indication that a team was being built. These changes, about which the Government often mouths in a superficial manner, could have been brought on at this stage, but they have not been. I am disappointed. Quite frankly, I think what is proposed here is pathetic.

During the discussion I was just having with myself-nobody else seems to be listening-about the higher education contribution scheme, I mentioned the fact that some students would feel compromised because they have been betrayed by the Government's changing the rules. I should perhaps have mentioned that this sort of evidence can also be seen in present Austudy arrangements. Words fail me when I start to think about that. Many aspiring students will be further disadvantaged by the changes that are proposed to Austudy, because again the Government has backtracked on its lowering of the threshold under the parent's assets test. This was reduced to $200,000, and now the Government has restored it and indexed it to over $340,000.

The Democrats still believe that the family farm should be exempt from provisions applying to Austudy. I cannot see the relevance of that to a student's education plans. The Government should rethink its changes to the spouse income test under Austudy. The threshold has been massively reduced, by $6,000 down to $12,150 a year. It was bad enough as it was before, at $18,000-odd for a spouse. Again, I cannot see the relevance of that to a student wishing to undertake tertiary studies. Here we have a change which is not really justified in the Budget; the Government simply explained that the threshold had been reduced and would now be $12,150 before it started to affect the partner's receipt of Austudy.

This is an incredibly harsh measure when the average gross income in Australia today is over $26,000. It makes a nonsense of this Government's commitment to education. It excludes women, it has a huge effect on part timers and it forces young married people who want to be involved in studies into a poverty situation. The Government estimates that 1,000 students will lose Austudy as a result of this; 1,300 will discontinue their courses; and another 6,800 will stay on, but their Austudy will be reduced.

During last year's debate on this, the Democrats unsuccessfully moved two important amendments. The first would have removed the age requirement of 16 years for receipt of Austudy. We should look at that. Surely the level of education that is being undertaken has more relevance to the distribution of Austudy than age. The age requirement of 16 years for receipt of Austudy should have been removed. Our other amendment would have given part time students the right to defer payment of their tertiary charge. Given the limited time and the lack of support for those amendments, we will not waste the time of the Senate by formally moving them again, but I think that the issue needs to be raised.

Recent studies have warned that Australia's universities face academic staff shortages of up to 20,000 by the year 2000. The Higher Education Council has estimated that 5,500 extra staff are required in 1991 just to maintain the current student to teacher ratios. In order to avert a major crisis, the Government should be acting quickly to recruit and train academic staff, but we do not see any evidence of that in any of these measures. We should be encouraging and supporting our postgraduates. Academic careers are not being made more attractive by what the Government proposes here. When I look at this package of six education Bills, the only feeling I have in the end is one of great disappointment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to refer to the part of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill which provides that, in the event that any State passes legislation which provides for the voluntary unionism of students, the amount of funding to that State is reduced. The legislation makes payments under the Act conditional upon the States taking no action to prevent or hinder the imposition or collection of fees by higher education institutions or organisations representing the interests of students generally. If the condition is not met, the Minister is empowered to determine an amount deductible by the Commonwealth from a State and the amount payable by the Commonwealth to institutions in respect of such organisations. The latter amounts in total will not exceed a total of the former amounts.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the Bill, and no doubt its philosophic underlying purpose, is to make contributions to student unions mandatory. Although, of course, there is no direct provision for making membership of such unionism compulsory, that is the effect. I have always found it a quaint contradiction of the Australian Labor Party that it claims to have amongst its ranks those who believe they carry the torch in a singular way for the civil liberties of individuals-in fact, some of them are so arrogant as to assume that they are the only ones who care about the intrinsic rights of individuals-yet we find that when it comes to a compulsion to join an organisation or association the Labor Party makes no apology and has no shame about the fact that it compels members of society to join associations and bodies, and it is at great peril to themselves if they dare not.

In a related way, I thought the recent SPC case at Shepparton was a good example of the muscle that these organisations, these associations and these unions are able to impose upon individuals because those individuals are compelled to be members. The Government understands, for instance, in respect to unionism that if there was not compulsion, if there was not blackmail, if there was not duress, and if there was not inordinate and unnatural pressure on individuals to be forced to join these associations, the associations and the unions themselves would be fundamentally without power, because they are required to have a commitment and a responsibility to reflect the attitudes, the aspirations and not the least the wishes and desires of the individual members of the unions. In other words, the unions would be required to be more responsible and more responsive to those people who choose and seek to join them because they believe that there is some intrinsic merit in that association.

We saw the case in Shepparton recently where a group of workers made a judgment that it was in their best interests, in the interests of their family and children and in the interests of their community for them to forgo some previous benefits if they could maintain their jobs and have some chance of economic survival. The company made a judgment that it could continue to provide them with jobs if there was a mutual agreement where the company made sacrifices, the executive and the directors of the company made sacrifices and the workers made sacrifices. Ultimately, that sacrifice would manifest itself by the continuance of the company and of the workers' positions and, ultimately, a reward by way of profit sharing in the event that the company returned to profitability.

We found that the individuals were naive enough to imagine that they had some basic human right to enter into such an agreement and arrangement with their employer. They thought that their labour was their own and free to be negotiated with their employer for whatever reward they judged their labour to be worth. Of course, their naivety was demonstrated in their belief that they had some rights, some responsibilities and some capacity to make judgments for themselves. Their naivety was also demonstrated when Mr Halfpenny from the Victorian Trades and Labor Council stood up and said, `You do not have a right. You do not have the capacity to make judgments that affect you. Don't you understand that in society there is a higher order, that there is a greater responsibility imposed upon you by other people who are more competent and more capable of making judgments about your welfare, your well-being and that of your family than you are?' As a result, those employees were told that, if they persisted in the folly of seeking to maintain their jobs, the company would be black-banned and would be driven into bankruptcy and ultimately their jobs would be totally lost. The only reason that Halfpenny, the thug, could do that--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I would claim that the word `thug' is unparliamentary language. I would ask for it to be withdrawn, no matter who the person he is talking about.

—On the same point of order. It would be extraordinarily sensitive to require any senator to withdraw the word `thug'. There have been many precedents set in which this word has been used in the Parliament before. There should not be a ruling that it is unparliamentary.

—Certainly in the case of any other member of any parliament that word would be totally unparliamentary and would not be used in this chamber. Would the Minister like to explain his point of order a little more?

—The basis is that the word `thug' in the context of any individual is one that is offensive. Mr Acting Deputy President, you make the clear point that, were it used about any member of this House or another, then it would be unparliamentary. I would contend that we are then drawing up one set of guidelines to apply for people in parliament and are not prepared to apply them to individual members of the community who, quite honestly, do not have any right to recourse in half the Parliament.
—Yes, they do have it in this place.
—They do in this place. I think it would be unfair. In essence, I think it is an unparliamentary term which should not be applied in this particular case.

—I rule that the point of order cannot be upheld. It would be out of place and unparliamentary if it were applied, as I indicated, to any member of any parliament. It might be inappropriate but, at this stage, Senator Crichton-Browne has the right to use that term. However, if any individual feels that, under parliamentary privilege, he has had his reputation spurned in some way or another then there is a course of action that can be taken by that individual. But it is entirely up to that individual to take that approach. The point of order is not upheld.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. If John Halfpenny has the audacity to complain to this Parliament at being described as he is, I would be very surprised. Frankly, I do not speak here under privilege. Mr Acting Deputy President, I am not canvassing your ruling and I am now back to the debate. I stand here speaking out for those 300 workers at Shepparton who were denied an opportunity to respond. They were unable to reflect a view about Mr Halfpenny for fear of the consequences. I give this example to demonstrate the implications of compulsion of any nature to join any organisation or any association. The fact that people are compelled to join a union is the political muscle which is granted and provided by the legislative process to Mr John Halfpenny, and which allows him to do what he is doing to the workers at Shepparton.

—Senator Crichton-Browne, the Bill before us is the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill. It does not have a great deal to do with Mr Halfpenny or SPC. I wonder whether you could come back to speaking relevantly about the Bill before the Senate.

—I mentioned that matter, Mr Acting Deputy President, to raise the question of the implications of making it compulsory-which is the effect of this package-for students to join a student union. Sadly, this Government has got the support of the representatives of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and I suspect that is because of having peace at any price. There is nothing more obnoxious than young students, who go to university for the purpose of improving their education and their prospects and for developing and educating their minds, being compelled to join an association with which they may have no philosophic commitment or belief. These students may obtain no material benefit from joining an association and they may wish to have no access to the facilities that are provided to those who may wish to join the association or union voluntarily.

SPEECH.PARA: I was saddened to learn recently from my own little daughter in her first year at university that the National Union of Students went to Western Australia to contribute to the plebiscite as to whether or not that campus would be affiliated. When she tried to get into the booth to cast her vote, she was harassed and intimidated by a smelly, long-haired thug from that association. I took great exception to that. It is bad enough for workers on building sites to be intimidated by union officials, but for little kids on a campus to be intimidated in that way is not something which I imagine the Australian Democrats, or anybody on this side of politics, would approve of. But I can make no judgment past that point. The consequence of such conduct is to intimidate and isolate young people.

I find it grossly obnoxious that the price of education in Australia cannot be paid for by the sweat of the brow of parents or the individual endeavours of the child. The price of education comes with capitulation and compulsion to be associated with a group or body with which the students may well have no association, no interest and no common objectives. We have legislation before us now which purports to blackmail students to the extent that if they do not join the union they do not get an education.

I am used to walking down St George's Terrace in the halcyon days of the Labor Government and seeing signs stating, `No ticket, no start.' That is offensive enough, and 75 per cent of workers oppose such a proposition, but going on a campus and finding young adolescents having to read a placard stating, `No union, no education. No education, no future. No future, no hope', would be incompatible, I would have thought, with the mainstream view of the overwhelming majority of Australian society. Yet without shame or embarrassment, without a touch of a blush, this Government tells the young people of Australia-while the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, says that we have to be a smarter country-that they will get their education on the condition that they join a union of students.

I am told that time prevents me from going through the ways in which some of the money is wasted. Wasting their money on taverns and those sorts of things is bad enough, but spending the money on political purposes-I object to that irrespective of whether it is the Left or the Right-and on political advertising during Federal and State election campaigns is objectionable. Having the money supporting a lifestyle which some in this society might find repulsive and contrary to their religion is objectionable. Having the funds used to take a political view about a matter which might be quite outside the Australian borders is obnoxious.

The truth of the matter is that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) knows that if a poll were taken any day of the week in Australia and the question was simply, `Do you believe in the compulsion to join a union to be allowed to work?', 80 per cent of the population would say no. If the question were asked of all parents of students in this country, `Do you believe that your child should have to join a union to get an education?', I suspect that the figure would be higher. At least there can be some argument, however distorted or subjective, that by joining a union as a worker a person is bearing the fruits of the labours of those who collectively negotiate with the employers. What benefit is there for a 17-year-old girl going on a campus to simply have her money, her parents' money or other taxpayers' money spent on lesbian counselling, political advertising, a tavern or some other facility? There is no intrinsic merit in this legislation whatsoever except to say that it is a simple reflection of the Australian Labor Party's long held philosophical view of life and society that there is always somebody more intelligent and superior and with greater knowledge of what is good for the individual than the individual himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not hold the Senate up at length on the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1990, the Overseas Students (Refunds) Bill 1990, the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1990, Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990, the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1990 and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1990. Speakers have tried to expedite the matter this morning and I will attempt to do so as we now move on into the afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of points have been made and I need to respond to them specifically. Senator Teague made a particular point in respect of the privacy implications and what the Government was trying to do with clause 5 of the Overseas Students (Refunds) Bill 1990. That clause enables the Government to seek particulars of overseas students enrolled at an institution. That clause was discussed by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Without reading all the deliberations of the Committee, I would like to incorporate in Hansard three pages of that Committee's report, as they might be useful.

I make particular reference to the fact that the Privacy Commissioner's office was consulted with respect to this provision. The Committee thanked the Minister for his response and his assistance with the Bill. More importantly, the information that is allowed to be sought under clause 5 is information which is normally sought. The information is needed to ensure that refunds are paid where the financial circumstances are necessary and that the Government is not irresponsible in the administration of public moneys in this area. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard three pages of the Committee's report.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows --
This Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 17 October 1990 by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training.

The Bill proposes to facilitate the refunding of payments by the Commonwealth to overseas students unable to undertake or complete courses of study in Australia for which money has been paid in advance.

The Committee dealt with the Bill in Alert Digest No. 9 of 1990, in which it commented on a clause of the Bill. The Minister for Employment Education and Training responded to those comments by letter dated 5 December 1990. A copy of that letter is attached to this report. Relevant parts of the response are also discussed below.
Power to obtain information and documents
Clause 5

In Alert Digest No. 9, the Committee noted that clause 5 of the Bill would empower the Secretary (or an officer authorised in writing) to issue notices to an educational institution (or its agent) requiring them to supply `particulars' of overseas students enrolled at the institution. The Committee suggested that this may be considered to involve a breach of students' privacy, as there is no indication of the kinds of information covered by `particulars' or the uses to which such information could be put. The Committee also noted that, though there is no formal requirement to do so, neither the explanatory memorandum to the Bill nor the Minister's second reading speech referred to the Privacy Commissioner having been consulted on this matter.
The Committee drew senators' attention to the clause as possibly trespassing unduly on personal rights and liberties, in breach of principle 1(a) (i) of the Committee's terms of reference.
The Minister has responded as follows:

I appreciate the Committee's concern on privacy issues and I can assure you that, while no mention was made in the Explanatory Memorandum or Second Reading Speech, consultations were undertaken with the Privacy Commissioner's Office. This was at officer level and resulted in an undertaking being given to include in the Explanatory Memorandum an indication of the information about students that would be sought from institutions.

In relation to the Committee's concern about the meaning and use of `particulars', the Minister has drawn the Committee's attention to the notes on clause 5 of the explanatory memorandum which does indicate the type of information to be sought, and that its use is to establish the amount of refund to which a student may be entitled.
The Committee thanks the Minister for pointing this out.
The Minister concludes by saying:

I should add that students, when completing the Acceptance Advice Form prior visa issue, specifically authorised Australian education institutions and other Commonwealth agencies to provide to my Department, on request, information contained in the application, enrolment details, attendance records, results, current address and information regarding their entry to and stay in Australia. This provision has been included for some time and is in keeping with the Information Privacy Principles of the Privacy Act 1988.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his response and for his assistance with this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will quote from Minister Dawkins's letter to Senator Cooney, the Chairman of the Committee. The particulars that are being sought are not exceptional. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I should add that students, when completing the Acceptance Advice Form prior visa issue, specifically authorise Australian education institutions and other Commonwealth agencies to provide to my Department, on request, information containing the application, enrolment details, attendance records, results, current address and information regarding their entry and stay in Australia. This provision has been included for some time and is in keeping with the Information Privacy Principles of the Privacy Act 1988.
The histrionics that surround that point in the debate were not really necessary, but I am sure that the incorporation of these notes will assist.

The role of student unions at universities has been made quite recently in the debate. The Government has a very clear policy position which I personally share very strongly; that is, that student unions at universities provide a whole range of services. They are basic to the social conduct of campuses and to the provision of funds and facilities, not only for the student union itself but also for other organisations associated with the unions at universities. I know from my experience-I am sure that Senator Bell would agree with me; I will not repeat private conversations that we may have had on the role of student unions-that student unions provide a great focus for students at tertiary institutions. They provide a range of counselling, sporting, health and career services and necessary social outlets.

I am struck by a touch of hypocrisy from the previous Opposition speaker, Senator Crichton-Browne. He complains about student unions providing social facilities, whether they be taverns or whatever, when we, as members of probably one of the most elite clubs of Australia, avail ourselves of similar sorts of tavern facilities, such as swimming facilities-those which he stridently makes it difficult for staff to have greater access to in this place.

The point is that student unions provide a whole range of facilities for students. I am one who believes that those students should not be undermined. The Government believes that they should not be undermined and that they should be allowed to continue in a strong and viable way to provide services and advice to their members. Those services and advice are in the interests of members. They do not have to represent the majority view of the membership; in fact, they do not, never have and nor should they. The student unions are there to act as a focal point for all members. They may provide lesbian advice, but lesbians are students too. If there is a need for it, then that need is catered for by the student unions.

I remember in my days at university that the Liberal Club used to get a degree of support and financial assistance from student unions. As long as student unions are diverse in their organisations, they should be encouraged.

One should also not deny the fact that students have political interests. Fighting governments on higher education fees is one issue which we as a government have found unpalatable. I, and I am sure the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Baldwin), would not stop student unions from being politically active against governments in the interests of their members, no matter how direct or indirect those interests may be.

I turn now to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1990 and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. I will very briefly canvass some of the points made by Senator Teague. One is consistently struck in this place by the degree of irrelevance to the mainstream political process demonstrated by the Opposition. We saw that again this morning in Senator Teague's contribution on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill.

A second reading amendment was moved by the Opposition which chastises the Government on its policy performance in this area. It is a schizophrenic amendment. I ask Senator Bell to have a close read of it. On the one hand we are accused of failing to address adequately the issues of quality in higher education and to provide a framework for accountability and so on. On the other hand, we are criticised for failing to make inroads into unmet demand-for failing to do all sorts of things that cannot be done by any government, unless an interest is taken in the services provided by the tertiary institutions involved.

We are criticised for doing nothing about the unmet demand in paragraph (b) (iv) of the Opposition's second reading amendment. It is very easy to make those political points, but the Opposition's irrelevance is underscored when one looks at the fact that this Government is in the process of creating 70,000 places between 1989 and 1993 in this sector. That is a major attempt at meeting unmet demand in this area.

The amendment talks about bludgeoning higher education institutions, enforced amalgamations and the damaging pressures we have created with regard to institutional uniformity. One only has to look at the situation of the Ballarat university college, I am informed, where that university college chose not to amalgamate with other institutions. Its funding arrangements have been advised. Its position is clear: they are continuing. If Senator Teague wants to come in here with good sound sustainable arguments he should come up with them. If he wants to come up with amendments which look great and read well at his local Liberal Party Friday night scones and tea meeting, that is great. I am sure the speech will get great circulation and great respect there, perhaps ensuring that Senator Teague gets his preselection with the support of the blue rinse set in the eastern suburbs of Adelaide. But in the tertiary institutions Senator Teague will lose and continue to lose credibility for so long as he goes on with schizophrenic motions such as this.

I go on to the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill, which is another Bill I think the Australian Democrats should have a close look at before they consider supporting it. We are told that they deplore the Government's imposition of complex goals and performance indicators. Then we are asked to develop a response to open and flexible training markets. The first point is-it is one I made with respect to the previous Bill-that the Government is taking an interest; the Government does provide moneys. The Federal Government has a responsibility to ensure that the quality of the service is maintained and upgraded and that kids and students all over Australia get an adequate and reasonable level of education, and to that extent we will take an interest and set goals and indicators. At the same time we will recognise the flexibility that this amendment denies that we are doing.

A special meeting of Ministers was held on 2 November this year which agreed to the national approach to make the technical and further education (TAFE) system more effective and efficient. I am sure that Senator Bell is getting a great degree of insight into this debate from Senator Crichton-Browne. If he is going to support this amendment he should take note that on 2 November Ministers across Australia recognised the need for effectiveness, efficiency, the development of key performance indicators for the TAFE system and action to review staffing and conditions to remove inhibitions on TAFE participating in the open and flexible training market, and agreed to a process to rectify that. I do not see the need for this particular amendment. The Government has been working, moving and achieving in this area. It is one of a series of reforms that was mentioned on 2 November. The amendment is there, once again, for grandstanding.

TALK.START.PARA: —We disagree.

—Senator Teague will always disagree. Hopefully, that will do both my reputation and his good. I go on to the next Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1990. We get canned in a very generalised way about that. I do not think I need to go deeply into that Bill. I will leave my comments both on this Bill and the next one, and also on the definition of time problems, to the committee stage, if that is necessary. However, on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, the Government has an amendment to move. That amendment has been circulated. It has the agreement of the Opposition. I have some comments to make on it, but I think it is best for me to make those comments at the time I formally move the amendment.
