The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to Government amendments to be moved to this Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2, paragraph (d), lines 17 to 21, proposed definition of ``additional expenditure'', lines 17 to 21, omit the definition, substitute the following definition:
``additional expenditure'' means:

(a) in relation to complying with an approved award or agreement in a program year-expenditure in that year of a greater amount than the amount that would have been spent if the award or agreement had not been made; or

(b) in relation to complying with terms or conditions referred to in subsection 40F(3) in a program year-expenditure in that year of a greater amount than the amount that would have been spent if the terms and conditions had not been restructured as mentioned in that subsection;

and, in either case, if the expenditure of an approved authority of an approved school system or of a non-systemic school in that year on the salary of a principal or a deputy principal of a school is greater than the amount that would have been spent if the award or agreement had not been made, or the terms and conditions had not been restructured, as the case may be-includes that greater expenditure, even if the principal or deputy principal is not covered by the approved award or agreement, or is not subject to the terms and conditions;''.
(2) Clause 21, page 13, proposed section 40F, add at end of the following subsection:
(a) school teachers employed by the approved authority of an approved school system or of a non-systemic school are not covered by an approved award or agreement; and
(b) the Minister is satisfied:
(i) that the approved authority will incur additional expenditure in relation to a program year as a result of restructuring the terms and conditions of employment of the school teachers; and
(ii) that as a result of the restructuring, elements of those terms and conditions are comparable to elements of the terms and conditions of school teachers under an approved award or agreement;
the Minister may, by determination in writing, authorise payment to the State for the approved authority by way of financial assistance towards that additional expenditure.''.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my comments in respect of those amendments. They are comments which I believe have been discussed with both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1990
GOVERNMENT AMENDMENTS RELATION TO THE AWARD RESTRUCTURING ASSISTANCE PROGRAM
(CLAUSES 3 AND 21)
REVISED SPEAKING NOTE FOR MINISTER

The Senate will be aware that the Award Restructuring Assistance Program (ARAP) is part of Commonwealth initiatives to improve the quality of teaching in Australian schools. ARAP provides for differential grants to schools on the basis of arrangements arising from particular awards and agreements as they occur in each State and sector. In each case, the Commonwealth will enter into an agreement with the system or school on the implementation of measures for improvement of teacher quality and conditions.

The purpose of these amendments is to ensure that the benefits of the Program are available to all school teachers, including principals and deputy principals, in all types of school- non-government as well as government. It has always been the Government's intention that this should be so, but we accept that the Bill as originally drafted appeared to exclude assistance from certain limited categories of staff in non-government schools not covered by an approved award.

Provided that any restructuring of the terms or conditions of such staff is comparable with those under an approved award, schools and systems may, under the proposed amendments, be eligible for assistance towards the cost of approved elements of the restructuring. This applies whether schools are currently paying over or under award rates.
I am sure that these amendments will command general support, and commend them to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to today's announcement by the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Treasurer of a one per cent reduction in interest rates. I ask: does the Minister agree that such a reduction requires also taking offsetting fiscal and wages policy measures, as otherwise the longer term consequences for inflation, investment and jobs could be counterproductive? If he does so agree, what offsetting fiscal and wages policies is the Government adopting? If he does not agree, then what are his grounds for expecting that the current climate provides a basis for a long term reduction in inflation as implied by today's decision and the statement by the Governor of the Reserve Bank?

—It is very easy to take one incident like a reduction in interest rates which was announced today and telescope it into a variety of other hypothetical circumstances in which differing parameters might well apply to the Australian economy. In terms of fiscal and wages policy, the Government has fiscal policies largely dealt with in the budgetary context and except in, I think, five out of seven years here, this Government has introduced a May statement or something of that kind. Fiscal policy, however, is essentially dealt with in the budgetary context, and wages policy has been dealt with for the foreseeable future in terms of having no wage increase through 1991 on the basis of a foreshadowed tax cut for wage earners and others next year. Whether the balance of those things has to be varied in time will be something for the Government to determine at that time, probably early next year.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister: am I to take it from what he has said that he believes that the existing stance of fiscal and wages policy is consistent with the monetary policy decision taken today?

—The monetary policy decision taken today does not in itself make an enormous difference to the major determinants of economic stability. It will depend very much on the effects of that reduction-easing of monetary policy-in the way that it flows through to various sectors of the economy. There is a one per cent difference between the impact of monetary policy today and the situation yesterday. That does not, in my view, necessitate logically a huge change in the other determinants of economic stability and success.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer him to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser on 26 November 1990 about new cash transaction regulations to take effect on 1 February 1991. Will the Minister explain what prompted these new regulations on account verification under the Cash Transaction Reports Act? What improvements will result from such changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had my attention drawn to the article Senator Foreman has brought to the notice of the chamber. It is a fact that the Attorney-General has announced that cash dealers-that is, banks, building societies, credit unions, TAB agencies, et cetera-will have to verify the identity of all new signatories to accounts. This will come into force on 1 February 1991.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the Cash Transaction Reports Act is becoming a very important weapon in the fight Australia is waging against organised criminal activity, particularly against money laundering aspects in relation to drug trafficking. As we know, that particular heinous trade generates many millions of dollars in terms of profits of crime. It is in the interests of the criminals concerned to launder that money into apparently legitimate business enterprises and other activities.

Mr Costigan, in the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, indicated that some bank managers were virtually acting as accomplices and collaborators with organised crime in that they were permitting the opening of accounts in manifestly false names in their suburban branches and turning a blind eye to the fact that quite clearly this was being done in a way to mask the true identity of the origins of the money concerned.

It is very pleasing to note that over the last several years there has been a major change in the ethos and outlook of those involved in the financial institutions, from top management down to the clerks at the counter. This particular change of outlook provides a very sound foundation for the work of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency in its measures to combat money laundering and the movement of profits of crime through various financial institutions.

From 1 February 1991 there will be two methods of verification of identity of those opening accounts with the financial institutions I have mentioned-banks, building societies, credit unions, et cetera. One will require a written statement from an acceptable referee. The other will require the undertaking of certain checks and the production of certain documents. In all those ways the banks will be able to verify the identity of the person opening the account. It is important to emphasise that the records in relation to the verification process will be retained by the cash dealer and will be available to law enforcement agencies only in accordance with existing law and, generally, under search warrants. So there will be no great invasion of privacy involved in that respect.

I believe that Mr Costigan's hopes for the future waging of the battle against organised crime in this area are being achieved in a way which is appropriately sensitive to the interests of the privacy of individual depositors and those who have financial dealings with various institutions. On the other hand, this certainly permits us as a community to deal with the insidious movement of the profits of crime, which not only undermines the legitimate business and trading activity of Australia but also creates havens in which the black market can operate. In that way, I believe that these new regulations Senator Foreman has drawn to the attention of the Senate will be extremely beneficial.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to his statements in the Senate on 14 September, 19 September and 9 October in which he said that the savings from data matching and the extension of the tax file number will result in $400m a year being taken from `cheats and bludgers'. Yesterday in the Sydney Morning Herald the Minister had a letter published in which he claimed the moves would eventually save $300m a year. In light of the very considerable difference between these figures, can the Minister reconcile them?

—I think the Budget Papers show savings of something like $365m-I cannot remember the exact figure, but it is something like that. I said at the time it would save $400m, and I was simply trying to round it off.
—What a rounding off! Ha, ha!

—I would say $365m to $400m amounts to that and if Senator Hill does not think so, then I am sorry. I would have thought, given the gravity of decisions that will be taken here later in the day concerning savings, Senator Hill could do more than laugh. I suspect that by the end of the day he will not be doing that, either.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister saw fit to round off $365m to $400m, for some reason which he has not yet explained, can he please tell us on what basis he decided to round it down to $300m yesterday?
—Because I was speaking directly on a data matching Bill and not on data matching overall, which included the--
—The $100m.
—No, the cross-matching provisions, which Senator Alston would not know about because he has read none of it, which amounted to the rest of it. I stick to both statements; they are both correct.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. How much money has the Aboriginal Legal Service provided for the various legal actions concerning the future of the old Swan brewery in Perth? Did the Aboriginal Legal Service directly or indirectly fund both Robert Bropho and Corrie Bodney who were opposing litigants in a civil action? If the answer to the second question is yes, does the Minister consider this to be an appropriate use of taxpayers' money?

—I am sure that Senator Walsh will not be in the least surprised to hear that I do not have the detailed answer to that question nor, I regret, is that kind of detail available in the brief. Of course I am well aware of the action that has been continuing for some time now in respect of the Swan brewery, and the significance that has to Aboriginal people in the area. But, no, I do not have off the top of my head the dollars and cents amount that has been spent by the Aboriginal Legal Service on that matter. I will obtain that detailed response for Senator Walsh and I will provide it to the Senate later this week.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I ask: firstly, has the Minister yet come to understand that his proposal for resource guarantee legislation completely pre-empts the Government's ecologically sustainable development process and the Resource Assessment Commission inquiry into the timber industry; and, secondly, will the Minister give an undertaking that this matter will be resolved one way or the other at tomorrow's Cabinet meeting so that the resource industries and the public will know where they stand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question begins by asking whether I have come to understand. I find that extremely gratifying and indeed patronising but, yes, I have come to understand and I will give Senator Powell an answer in terms of my understanding, which I think is better than hers. Let me say that her question is based on the most paranoid, suspicious interpretation of the Government's motives in this matter. She has swallowed all the misconceptions behind some of the media and public comment on this issue in recent weeks.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's aims in its consideration of this issue have not changed, and will not change. The Government wants a clear approach that integrates environmental and economic considerations. Areas of high conservation value must be preserved from logging, and logging practices in other areas must be sustainable. Decisions on forest allocation must be made on the basis of objective scientific assessment and community consultation. The various States which have direct control of forest resources require an assurance of the availability of timber so that they can enter into long term contracts with confidence.

The processes must offer conservationists and industry certainty-something which has not been present in recent years, I suspect, and something which is of great concern to a lot of people. It seems fair to say that existing processes have perhaps proved less than adequate for the resolution of these issues because of some highly emotional elements in the public debate. So the answer to the first part of Senator Powell's question is no.

Secondly, Senator Powell raised the issue of the Government's consideration of these matters being consistent with its approach to ecologically sustainable development and the work of the Resource Assessment Commission-both processes invented not by the Australian Democrats but by this Government. When the honourable senator talks about my proposals in relation to these issues, I have to make the point that that interpretation comes from a misreading of a document that was clearly leaked over the telephone, with a bit of Telecom Australia static into the bargain, because it was not a very accurate view of what the proposals are.

The fact is that earlier this year the Prime Minister appointed four Ministers in the Government to look at the question of resource security issues pending the outcome of the ecologically sustainable development process and of course pending the deliberations of the Resource Assessment Commission. It is that committee of Ministers that has prepared a Cabinet submission on these matters. I think the Government's consideration of these issues is quite consistent with those two processes to which I have referred.

Thirdly, Senator Powell asked me whether I would give an undertaking that this matter would be determined in the Cabinet meeting tomorrow. My answer to that part of the question is no, I will not give any such undertaking. The agenda of Cabinet is determined by Cabinet, and the way in which it deals with that agenda is determined by Cabinet, not by a question from the Australian Democrats. In summary, the Government is committed to developing decision making processes which integrate environmental projection and economic objectives and that will be the continuing aim of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister not understand that, by definition, sustainable development in essence ensures resource security and that in fact without sustainable development there can be no resource security-that very certainty to which the Minister referred? Why is the Government still ducking the issue by failing to make a commitment to clarify the question at tomorrow's meeting?

—That question reveals a degree of confusion at a height to which I did not believe even Senator Powell could rise. I understand all of those things, thank you very much. If Senator Powell takes the trouble to read in Hansard the answer to her first question, perhaps she will begin to understand that answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an admittedly obscure journal dealing with industrial and economic issues which is produced in Adelaide entitled Hard Facts? Does a recent edition of this journal claim that Australia's record in industrial disputation compares poorly with the records in major industrial nations? Can the Minister advise how Australia has fared in terms of industrial disputation since the accord between the Government and the trade unions was agreed to?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I agree with the proposition advanced in the question that this journal entitled Hard Facts is an obscure one but, nonetheless, it has been published out of Adelaide. It is nothing more than a propaganda rag and, in the tradition of propaganda rags, it bears only a remote fidelity to the truth. One could say that it is Peter Reith hopeless. The most recent copy of this journal, a copy of which I have here, proposes to make three points: firstly, that the majority of the fall in working days lost through industrial disputes from the high levels of the 1970s and 1980s did not come about during the Hawke years but rather during the last two years of the Fraser Government; secondly, that while industrial disputation has remained at a relatively low level since 1983 the key reason has been the high level of unemployment which has reduced the bargaining power of unions; and thirdly, that our industrial disputation record still compares very badly with the records in Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries in general. The trouble with this journal is that on each of those points it is simply, absolutely and fundamentally wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me go to the first point: disputes declined from an unacceptable rate of 797 working days lost per 1,000 employees in 1981 to the unacceptable rate of 348 working days lost per 1,000 employees in 1982. Now the figure is less than half that of the Fraser Government's best year. The indisputable fact is that the rate of industrial disputation-137 working days lost per 1,000 employees in the year to August 1990-was the lowest figure since this measure was published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on a monthly basis. Under the Hawke Labor Government, the number of working days lost per 1,000 employees through industrial disputation is 62 per cent lower than under the Fraser Government period. Indeed the year to August 1990 returned a very low figure which was still trending downwards. It was the lowest year-ended-August figure for working days lost since 1967. I note that since 1967 the work force has increased by 69 per cent, so that measure of gross lost days has to be compared with a much larger work force.

Turning to the second point, let me say that the allegation that industrial disputation has been kept in check by unemployment is just so fundamentally wrong that it is a joke. In the last year compared in this table, 1982-1983, the growth rate in Australia was negative-minus 0.4. That was the Fraser Government period. Industrial disputation was kept in check by the Fraser Government strangling the economy and introducing bad economic times. That was the reason for that reduction. From the year 1982-83, which admittedly includes some of the Fraser period, to the year ended September 1990, the growth in the economy measured by gross domestic product has been at plus 4.1. So we can compare minus 0.4 in the Fraser period with plus 4.1 growth under this Government. The significance is that during a period of high growth, industrial disputations have gone down under the Hawke Government. When the bargaining power of unions is at its greatest, they exercise restraint under the accord and we get moderate wage outcomes.
On the last matter, the international comparisons--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. The correct opportunity for an industrial relations debate is a little later this afternoon. I suggest that you bring that to the attention of the Minister.
—The Minister's answer is in order, but he is getting close to the end of an unofficial time limit.
—I do not have much longer to go. If I had not been interrupted by the Opposition, I would have concluded by now. I will wait until Opposition members are quiet so I can conclude my answer.

ANSWER.PARA: Regarding the third point, international comparisons, these comparisons show Australia's remarkable improvement since the advent of the Hawke Government. Between 1983 and 1987, the annual average rate of industrial disputation in this country was 250 working days lost per 1,000 employees, the same level as that of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. Contrary to what Hard Facts suggests, Australia was below the United Kingdom annual rate over this period, which was 400 working days lost per 1,000 employees. So this scurrilous rag, Hard Facts, which bears the authorisation of Senator Amanda Vanstone, should be rejected for the lies it contains.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to this morning's Australian newspaper, which states that it has a full record of conversation between Prince Sihanouk and the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Michael Costello, which conversation took place on 2 November 1990. I ask: what was the classification of the record of interview? Can the Minister explain how this might have come into the hands of journalists? Has this matter been referred to the Australian Federal Police (AFP)?

—I believe that the classification was confidential, but I will need to check that answer and I will correct it if it is wrong. I have no idea how it came to get into the hands of a journalist any more than I have any clear idea about how a series of earlier leaks about which I am equally concerned might have happened. Yes, it was one of the documents I was referring to yesterday when I said that the AFP has been asked to add this to the list of things it is presently investigating.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION ON THE RIGHTS OF THE CHILD

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Can the Minister report on the progress of discussions with State governments in relation to Australia's commitment to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child? What benefits would ratification of this convention bring to Australian children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Consultations with the States and the Northern Territory have taken place in regard to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, and I am pleased that that consultation has reached the stage where ratification of the convention took place last night. The convention was ratified by Australia and in that regard it became, I think, the sixty-first country to ratify this very important convention. The convention has been signed but not ratified by over 70 other countries, so one can see that Australia is now in the company of probably most members of the United Nations.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not believe that any other United Nations human rights instrument has achieved such a result of signature and ratification in so short a time. It is obviously a testimony to the importance which governments around the world place on recognising the particular needs of children, who are a most vulnerable group, in many societies. It now provides Australia with a benchmark for the solidarity which we must show worldwide as far as the provision of a certain minimum recognition of the rights and responsibilities towards children is concerned.

As a result of the review of State and Territory laws which was required to be undertaken before ratification could take place, Australia has lodged one reservation in regard to the convention; that is, that we accept all the obligations of the convention except one that requires child and adult criminal offenders to be imprisoned separately. It is not always possible for Australia to meet this obligation in remote areas. Australia has, therefore, made a reservation which means that this obligation will not apply to it. But, of course, in regard to the normal situation within Australian jurisdictions, one would hope that juvenile offenders are not either on remand or kept in prison with adult prisoners after being sentenced to a gaol term.

Apart from that, the Australian Government, of course, has now submitted itself to the Bar of international scrutiny as far as assistance to children is concerned. I believe that with ratification will come a very important phase in the community's understanding of this convention. It will reveal that many of the misgivings and fears which have been groundlessly aroused in the minds of many ordinary and decent Australians will be found to be unfounded because children will not be snatched from the bosom of their families, as has been alleged in a lot of propaganda that has been circulated.

Rather than family and parental responsibilities being undermined because of Australian work in the formulation of the convention under article 5, countries are required to ensure that parents are able to discharge their responsibilities, rights and duties to direct and guide their children in the exercise of the various rights formulated in the convention. I believe that, as I say, now having ratified the convention, those who have had their fears and misgivings aroused will find that they ought to turn their attention to those who are responsible for creating this propaganda which has been so unsettling.

Ratification simply means that Australia is now a state party to the convention. It does not change the law in Australia one jot or tittle. If the law in Australia is to be changed, that must be by way of an action in the parliaments of Australia by the elected representatives of the Australian people. That is also a most important matter to emphasise in relation to this Convention on the Rights of the Child.

So I thank Senator Reynolds for her question. She has shown a very great interest in this particular convention. I believe it marks a very important milestone in securing the international recognition of the rights of that most vulnerable group in our societies.
Senator Harradine-I ask Senator Tate to table the documents from which he quoted.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a matter for Senator Tate to determine.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of the Hon. Steve Hatton, the Minister for Industry and Development in the Northern Territory. On behalf of all senators, I welcome him to the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, Hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Minister's advice to businesses facing problems in paying company tax due on 17 December to contact the Australian Taxation Office. Given the severe limits on the Commissioner of Taxation's discretion to provide relief, which generally cannot be granted unless all sources for obtaining the necessary funds have been exhausted under income tax ruling 2569, how will the Australian Taxation Office put the Minister's directions into effect? Will taxpayers who do qualify for this relief still be required to pay a further tax based on an interest charge that is not deductible for income tax purposes, so placing an even larger burden on struggling businesses?
—I cannot answer that question. Referring me to tax ruling 2569 is like asking me whether I read Pravda on a regular basis. I am not familiar with the details of all those rulings.
—The decision has been made.

—I suppose when Senator Durack was Attorney-General he read all the tax rulings and law reports. The only thing Senator Durack forgot were the tax avoidance files in his bottom drawer. That is all he forgot for five years. But I am sure that he read all the tax rulings. This is an important question. I will obtain an answer from the Treasurer for the honourable senator as soon as I can.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Could the Minister explain to the Senate the difference between Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on 2 August this year and Indonesia's invasion of East Timor in December 1975? Does the Minister recognise the irony of a situation where oil is involved in both disputes but that, in the Gulf, Australia chose to side with the victim while nearer home the Government sided with the aggressor? When will the Australian Government change its position on East Timor, in line with the growing body of international opinion that is now demanding the right of the people of East Timor to self-determination? Will the Government have the courage to admit that its silence in 1975 was a mistake and that this can be rectified by Australia taking a constructive role in settling this dispute, which will not go away?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the most relevant distinction is that the East Timor invasion by Indonesia was never accompanied by any United Nations resolution determining upon economic sanctions, let alone any subsequent UN resolution by the Security Council or any- body else effectively enabling the use of force in support of various objectives if they could not be peacefully achieved. The short point is that the international response against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has been overwhelming and based on a perception as to the absolute intolerability of any naked aggression of the kind that was perpetuated there by one sovereign country against another.

ANSWER.PARA: There are other grounds of distinction which could be drawn: the fact that East Timor was not, of course, a sovereign country in its own right but a colonial dependency; one that had in fact been deserted by its former colonial master and in respect of which there was a significant civil conflict waging between three rival groups, two of which, as I recall, favoured integration with Indonesia. So the circumstances were different.

I do not seek in any way to qualify this Government's very long-standing expression of concern and unhappiness about the circumstances of the Indonesian annexation-we made that clear in 1975; we have made it clear ever since-but there does come a time when the reality of an annexation or an absorption of this kind has to be accepted. That time came for this country some years ago.

We have taken the point that the human rights situation in East Timor can be much better advanced and much more usefully advocated in an environment where Australia does have a working relationship with Indonesia, and one that accepts the reality of the inevitable. It may be that had the international community responded with much more vigour and enthusiasm to the situation in 1975, as indeed to innumerable other international incidents over the Cold War period, the situation would be different. But that is the circumstance as we now confront it and that is the reason why we draw the distinction we do.

The important thing is to look now and in the future at each one of these cases absolutely on their own merits and not regard the appropriateness of international action as being governed by what may have been an inappropriate international response in the past. There were many inappropriate, inadequate or ineffectual international responses in the past. Thankfully, we are moving into a new environment where the possibility of effective international response is very great. The occasion for that, the case for it and the justification for it in the case of Iraq is self-evident, and nothing should deter us from accepting that reality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer, but the last part of my question referred to the growing body of international opinion, for example in the United States Congress and in the European Economic Community, about the recognition of the rights of self-determination for the East Timorese people. Is the Australian Government considering changing its policy on this? If, as Senator Evans has admitted, there have been mistakes in the past, that is no excuse for continuing them, so I look forward to a change in Government policy and ask him whether that is on the cards.
—I do not accept that there is a growing international body of opinion of the kind that Senator Vallentine claims, and the Government is not contemplating any change of policy.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It relates to the Burke-gate cover up. Will the Minister confirm on what date the term of the appointment of Brian Burke as Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See expires? Will the Minister inform the Senate on what date an extension of the Ambassador's term was raised? What is the period of the proposed extension of his term? Has a decision been made on the grant of the extension, and if not when will a decision be made? Finally, if a decision has not been made, will the requirement for the former Premier to appear before the Western Australian royal commission into WA Inc. be considered in the making of that decision?

—I cannot recall the date of Mr Burke's appointment, but his term was for four years. That is a quite usual term for an appointment of this particular kind and one that was certainly repeated on innumerable occasions.
—Usual for a political appointment?

—Other such appointments have been made by Senator Alston's side of politics in the past. There is nothing special that I am aware of about the terms of his appointment, and there is certainly nothing on the record at this stage, as far as I am concerned, to justify that term being cut short.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question did not relate to the term being cut short. It was perhaps a perception on behalf of the Minister that the term was to be cut short. I was actually asking whether an extension of the term had been raised and whether a decision had been made on the extension of the term.
—The question of an extension of term has not been raised with me. It is not a subject of any present contemplation by me.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in yesterday's Australian which suggests that the Australian food industry will lose market share unless both business and governments invest in more innovative products and processes? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government has any plans to support the further development of value adding in the food industry? If so, could he please give an indication of proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report in the paper which Senator Loosley refers to on innovation in the food processing industry was prepared for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce by the Centre for Technology and Social Change at the University of Wollongong. It was a study which aimed to identify the characteristics of demand for new technology by firms in the industry and those factors influencing this demand. Not surprisingly, the report found that only a small number of firms in the food processing industry are strongly active in technology and export development, despite the apparent opportunities to expand the exports of value added food products.

ANSWER.PARA: The report concluded that it is essential that firms develop the capacity and commitment to formulate strategies for competitiveness and technological development internally rather than by external inducement through the provision of Government assistance policies and programs. On this basis, the report recommends that government action be aimed at improving management strategic planning capabilities and the ability to implement plans. Secondly, it supports the establishment of a research and development association for the industry, if it is found to be warranted. The report also recommends that these measures be supplemented by information on export and research and development initiatives.

Some recent actions by the Government go some way to meeting the report's recommendations, and food processing activities have now been given high priority under the existing grants for industrial research and development initiatives. In addition, the international trade enhancements scheme administered by Austrade should be of particular benefit to larger food companies, particularly in countries such as Japan. Also, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is introducing a national initiative for the food processing industries involving various agencies and aimed at increasing awareness of the importance of strategic planning and improving manufacturers' strategy and planning capabilities. I agree that the establishment of a research and development association has some attractions and is an approach that has been considered for some time. But such an organisation would have to be private sector driven, and it is not clear yet that sufficient support is coming from the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. The Minister will be aware that removal costs are a large expense to the Government and thus the taxpayer, in fact running into some millions and millions of dollars. I ask the Minister: is he aware of the probability of a cartel operating in Brisbane and south-east Queensland with the apparent knowledge of his Department? How does he explain that tender prices to his Department are double those quoted to the private sector? Is the Minister aware of what is known as a `wheel' whereby tenderers take turns to obtain removal business from his Department? Can the Minister advise the Senate as to what internal controls, if any, are in place to ensure that this sort of practice is eliminated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last couple of months we have had Senator Parer coming in here, assisted by some of his cohorts from time to time, and making assertions. From time to time they come in here, make assertions, and then on the basis of those assertions they go and put out a press statement. Of course, that achieves the purpose of making a very cheap political point. The press statements often have not been run but from time to time there is a gullible journalist who gives those particular statements a run.
—Skip the preamble, will you?

—It is quite clear that what will happen again today is that Senator Parer will go out and put out a press statement. He did that a few weeks ago when he and Senator Newman got together and produced--

—I raise a point of order. This is a deliberate abuse of Question Time. The Minister has been asked a simple question. Mr President, I invite you to say that he should not be entitled to carry on in the way that he is, which is simply making a discursive analysis of how people might respond.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister is entitled to put a preamble to the answer.
—The most recent display in here was with respect to a claim-
—On a point of order, Mr President, `The most recent display in here' is irrelevant to this question or the answer. Surely you should direct that he answer the question.
—Order! I ask Senator Bolkus to answer the question, but a Minister is entitled to spend some time talking about previous questions within the portfolio.

—On the point of order, Mr President, I refer you to a ruling by a predecessor of yours, Sir Magnus Cormack, who ruled on 22 August 1973 that, if a Minister chooses to answer a question, the Minister should confine himself to points contained in the question with such explanation only as will render the answer intelligible. In all cases an answer must be relevant to the question. Within reasonable limits' supplements should be allowed. I ask you, Mr President, whether you will rule in line with that precedent.
—Order! I ask Senator Bolkus to answer the question he was asked. I also think it is reasonable for him to be allowed to take some time before he gives that answer.
—Mr President, the point I was making--
—That is a new ruling.
—It is not a new ruling.

—The point I was making is that there is very much a lack of credibility in the person asking the question, which of course goes to the heart of the matter. We have before us today a question claiming probable evidence of a cartel, apparently linking my Department. In the previous question we had on my Department, there was a probable case of a disabled toilet on a mezzanine floor which was not built there. But that did not stop a press statement going out. In the question before that, we had a probable case of Comcar going to private hire companies and, once again, facts asserted that were not correct. Today we have probably a similar situation.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Parer will probably get an answer to this question by the end of the week. I will examine whatever evidence he might have. I say to him-this is a consistent line from our side of the Parliament-that if there is evidence the Government will act. But his track record on raising questions in this Parliament is as good as his record as an economic manager in his own company. He should pay his bills and stand up with economic credibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am prepared to assist the Minister. It is a management portfolio and I am only too happy to supply the information that he requires. But can the Minister advise the Senate what internal controls, if any, are in place to ensure that this sort of practice does not occur and, if it does, is eliminated? It is a management question and a management portfolio.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ultimate benchmark in terms of government contracts is the role of the Auditor-General. That person-as should be well known to Senator Parer-has an overseeing role in this area. We have in place mechanisms for both public and private tendering that are transparent and are also open to examination. The overriding role is that of the Auditor-General.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said at the end of my first answer, Senator Parer has absolutely no credibility in raising matters such as this. His track record is such that on every allegation he has raised so far he has been proven to be raising falsehoods. We will take this one at face value, examine it and, if there is anything in it, we will act on it. But it would want to be better than the last three he has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Social Security, follows up an answer he gave in October to a similar question. I ask the Minister whether he is aware that officers of the Department of Social Security are continuing to demand that people applying for the family allowance declare their assets, telling them that unless they do so they will not receive any payment. Secondly, does the Minister agree that officers of his Department have no legal right to demand what is at the moment confidential family information relating to people's assets for purposes of assessing eligibility for family allowance? Finally, will the Minister immediately direct officers of his Department to stop acting illegally in demanding this information, or at the very least instruct them to inform family allowance applicants that the legislation has not yet passed, and in fact will not pass, as he promised he would do in October?

—I did do what I promised in October. I am not aware that we are demanding that information. If officers are demanding it they will be instructed not to. I will have the instruction that was issued in October reissued in December.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer the Minister to the debate on the Airlines Agreement (Termination) Bill in which he accused me of speaking nonsense-which I thought was somewhat unchivalrous-when I questioned whether gate facilities at airports would be available to new airlines entering into the deregulated market. I ask the Minister: in view of the Australian Customs Service charge at the rate of $270,000 per annum faced by Compass Airlines, which is directly attributable to a lack of gate facilities at the domestic terminal in Perth, does he stand by his claim, made twice in the Senate on 19 September, that new airlines are not having extortionate demands placed on them? What steps is the Minister taking to prevent the Customs Service from charging extortionate amounts for the use of the international terminal for one flight per day?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do stand by those statements. If the actual situation was always as it appears in the press there might be some justification to Senator Reid's question, but the facts are somewhat different. I am keenly involved in assisting new entrants into the aviation sector. Aviation is without doubt, both domestically and internationally, one of the most complex, competitive and difficult businesses that one can get into.
—Competitive?

—It is highly competitive. One has only to look at the loadings that Compass currently has on its eastern seaboard operations to see just how competitive it is. Compass negotiated very satisfactorily excellent facilities in the international terminal in Perth, purely as a result of major renovations that are being conducted in the Australian Airlines terminal in Perth, which will be completed next year. Compass indicated its satisfaction with those arrangements.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the charges that the Australian Customs Service is talking about levying, whether they are levied or not they are not extortionate. They simply relate to the difficulty of domestic baggage being confused with international baggage as a result of additional flights that Compass has scheduled into Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —One flight a day.

—Senator Reid should let me finish. In addition to that-and I am not in a position, for obvious reasons, to advise the Senate of the dollars and cents figures-the rate that Compass is paying for the international facility at Perth is extremely competitive with the rate it would have been paying had it been occupying the Australian Airlines terminal, which it will occupy next year when the renovations are concluded. The matter is being pursued by all of the parties concerned: the Federal Airports Corporation, Compass Airlines and Customs, and a meeting between all of those parties will be held on Thursday.

—I refer the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to an answer he gave on 28 November 1990 about the alleged harmful effects of urocanic acid in some cosmetics, in which he stated that the matter was being considered by the Committee on Toxicity of the National Health and Medical Research Council. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Committee has reached a conclusion about urocanic acid, and what action, if any, it will follow? Can he also tell the Senate whether urocanic acid has a more colloquial name?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a report from the Committee on Toxicity of the National Health and Medical Research Council, which came to a conclusion concerning urocanic acid which is present in some cosmetics. I believe that it is important that the public record be set straight because there has been some fear engendered among some users of cosmetics in relation to claims about the carcinogenic effect of urocanic acid in human subjects. The Committee concluded that it should recommend that the use of urocanic acid in cosmetics and sunscreens be phased out as a matter of prudence, but it also made it clear that harmful effects had not been demonstrated in relation to humans. I believe that that is true but, nevertheless, some experiments were carried out on mice which gave rise to the cautious recommendation that I have outlined to the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of that particular recommendation, I have asked the cosmetics industry to recall from sale any cosmetics including the ingredient urocanic acid. I have made that decision, as I say, as a matter of caution and prudence rather than of absolute necessity, but that was the advice received from this expert Committee.

I believe that there is no cause for undue alarm or worry on the part of those who may have used a cosmetic with this ingredient. Four cosmetic suppliers have already withdrawn from the market lines containing the ingredient and I believe that there is no need for overly legalistic reaction on my part. I have asked the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to make further arrangements with the cosmetics industry and cosmetic retailers to withdraw from sale the items concerned and to recall any products now being held in stores, on cosmetic counters and so on.

The Committee on Toxicity found that evidence on the subject was inconclusive and harmful effects on humans had not been proven. But as a matter of prudence, it suggested that a phase-out occur. This is why I have undertaken, with the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs, a process to ensure voluntary recall to eliminate any potential risk. I am confident that, given the level of public concern, we will have the full cooperation of the cosmetics industry.

Senator Crowley asked me about the colloquial name for urocanic acid. The honourable senator would know from her medical background that urocanic acid is the colloquial name. I cannot recall the full scientific name. I think it is 4-imidazole acrylic acid. If I am wrong, I am sure that the honourable senator will correct me in a supplementary question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to the Auditor-General's criticism of the administration of the Department of Social Security's (DSS) telephone rental concession scheme. Is this scheme, which does not ensure that only eligible people receive the concession or that the correct amount of concession is received, indicative of a social security system that is, to use Senator Richardson's words, `in advance of literally any country in the world'? Given that some 20 per cent of the scheme's $46m annual expenditure may be being paid to ineligible persons, does the Minister believe that, to use his words again, `informed people would consider this scheme to be a model for social security policy and administration'? Considering that the Auditor-General found that the administration of the scheme had not improved since 1983, does the Minister include this scheme in his claim that `there is not the slightest doubt that the integrity of the social security system has been enhanced substantially'? How will the scheme's efficiency be improved?
—Order! Senator Patterson, this is a very long question.

—I am finishing, Mr President. It matches the Minister's answers. Will the Minister take up the Auditor-General's recommendation that the operational responsibilities of DSS and Telecom Australia be clearly specified in a formal agreement between them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stopped attempting to take down all those questions. I will give a general answer. There are three criticisms in the Auditor-General's report. The first is that ineligible people may be using vouchers worth up to $8m per annum. The sample used to derive this figure was 100 vouchers out of 3 1/2 million used. I do not think the figure is right. The Auditor-General and I, therefore, are in disagreement as to the extent of it.

ANSWER.PARA: Another criticism was that the responsibilities between the Department of Social Security and Telecom are unclear and neither organisation is willing to fix the problem. Both Telecom and my Department, which share responsibility for the voucher scheme, recognise the problems. That is why the Government has been taking action to improve and review that scheme.

The Department of Social Security responded promptly after seeing the report in draft form on the issues relating to its responsibility. Staff have been reminded of what is required and there is more specific checking of subscriber status. Procedures for the issue of replacement vouchers, which I think is one of the big problems with the scheme, have been substantially tightened up.

In addition, during Budget discussions this year Cabinet asked relevant Ministers to report back to it with proposals for a better scheme. The Department of Social Security is discussing with the Department of Transport and Communications what that better scheme might be and will report back so that a new scheme for beyond 1991 can be introduced.

The third criticism appeared to be that inadequacies in the scheme have been reported as far back as 1976-77 but no action has been taken on them. A number of actions have been taken on them and on the telephone rental concession, including introduction of the voucher system itself in 1988.

In addition to measures already put in place to address the concerns raised, I can assure the Senate that there will continue to be action to improve the administration of the concession. I remind Senator Patterson that out of $23 billion, this is a scheme of some $40m. It does require tightening, and it will get it. However, it does not undermine either of the statements from which she quoted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to reports earlier this year that Hewlett-Packard, the computer company, would wind down its Australian software operations. I refer also to reports of new partnership for development arrangements. Can the Minister say what is the likely future of Hewlett Packard operations in this country?

—Hewlett-Packard essentially closed its research and development centre earlier this year. That made it necessary for a renegotiation of the partnership arrangements between Hewlett-Packard and the Government. I must say that after a period of negotiations here and in the United States that has been successfully accomplished. I believe that Hewlett-Packard has a good and strong future in Australia, contributing to the Australian economy in a variety of ways. As far as the Government is concerned, the matter has now been resolved. I welcome the question because it enables me to provide that answer. Let me say, in addition, that the software operation which I referred to in passing will continue for some time, but at a reduced size. The research and development operation will also continue but in a different field.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans)-by leave-agreed to:
That:
(a) in speaking to a motion of urgency this day the first 3 speakers shall speak for not more than 10 minutes each and each speaker thereafter shall speak for not more than 5 minutes; and
(b) if the debate is not concluded at the expiration of 1 hour and 5 minutes after the moving of the motion, the President shall then put the question on the motion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have received the following letter, dated 18 December, from Senator Durack:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President, Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Parliament to enable employers and employees to make voluntary agreements to determine the conditions of employment in their own work place without the intervention of the Industrial Relations Commission.'
Yours sincerely,
(PETER DURACK)
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Parliament to enable employers and employees to make voluntary agreements to determine the conditions of employment in their own work place without the intervention of the Industrial Relations Commission.

This motion states the essence of the industrial relations policy of the Liberal and National parties in this Parliament. It is one which we have been pursuing now for a number of years. The policy was first published in its present form in May 1986, although we had been developing it for some time prior to that. A little after the publication of this policy, the employer and the employees at a meatworks in the Northern Territory, at a place called Mudginberri, entered into a voluntary agreement rearranging the award conditions that applied to that meatworks. This agreement, covering conditions of employment, was reached voluntarily--

TALK.START.PARA: —To their mutual benefit.

—It was not only to their great satisfaction, but also to their great benefit because the agreement returned to the employees of that workplace a better financial result, and to the employer it delivered greater productivity. There could not have been a better example of the necessity-quite apart from the desirability-of the policy we announced over four years ago, which we have continued to support and inform the people of Australia about as much as we possibly could ever since.

SPEECH.PARA: During that time there have been a number of examples where the rearrangement of working conditions by agreement would have been very beneficial to employees but it has not been possible. Certainly, developments under section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act, which the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) was talking about yesterday, have allowed that to be done with the formal agreement of the Industrial Relations Commission. There has certainly been a great deal of movement in the industrial relations world towards the result which we have promoted in our policy. But now we have the case in Victoria involving SPC Ltd which, like the Mudginberri case, is another classic industrial relations case. It is interesting to note that the now shadow Minister for industrial relations, John Howard, who was the architect of this policy and who has been, I suppose, the driving force in the development and the promotion of this policy, called for 1,000 Mudginberries in 1986. That is now starting to be seen. It will recur. The Shepparton case is another classic and major example of it.

But, unlike the situation in 1986 where perhaps this was seen as a very radical, innovative and controversial policy, the fact of the matter is that last week a Morgan poll was taken on the attitude of Australian voters with regard to the agreement entered into by the employer and the employees of the Shepparton Preserving Company. The result of that poll of a large sample across Australia was that 77 per cent of Australians support the right of the employees to enter into such an agreement with their employer for whatever particular reason they may have. In this case it was to save their jobs. In other cases it might be and probably will be, in many cases, to improve their pay.

The poll showed that 77 per cent of Australians now support that right; in other words, they support the policy that this Opposition has been promoting so strongly for the last 4 1/2 years. But even more interesting is the fact that 67 per cent of Labor voters said that they supported the right of employees to enter into such an agreement, and 66 per cent of Australian Democrat voters supported that same principle. Indeed, only 4 per cent of unionists questioned in this poll thought that the Government should make any decision in relation to these matters at all. Only 4 per cent of union members believe that government should have any role in determining the result of a case of this kind.

As I said, the Opposition's policy is firmly based upon a voluntary agreement between parties. It is not based on settling a dispute. It is about an agreement being made between the employer and, as they see fit, individual employees-not necessarily all of the employees although, in many cases, that will be the case. This completely distinguishes the Opposition policy from that which the Government espouses and which Senator Cook espoused yesterday in relation to agreements under section 115 within the whole framework of the industrial relations system when settling a dispute of that kind. The policy is one whereby the parties themselves enter into an agreement. Certainly, our policy allows the employees to appoint agents, which would include their union, to give them advice and maybe to negotiate on their behalf. Under our policy, there is no exclusion of the role of unions. It will be for the employees themselves to decide whether they want the union involved. They will not have the intervention of the union imposed upon them or the intervention of the Government, through the Industrial Relations Commission, imposed upon them. It will not be able come in as a big brother and say, `Yes, you can do this. No, you can't do that'.

The essence of the Opposition's policy is one of voluntary agreement, and the Minister should note that it is voluntary agreement. Yesterday in answer to a question he expressed concern that this could lead to victimisation in certain circumstances and said that, clearly, the umpire needs to see that each of these deals is fair and that we do not find a situation where there is victimisation. Far from the superior Big Brother notion expressed there by the Minister, clearly Australian people today are quite capable of making these decisions. If they want help, they can get it. They feel that they have the right to make the decisions-not governments, not industrial relations commissions and certainly not unions. Those bodies are there to help and advise-not to make the decisions. They are not there to do the Halfpenny trick, as in the SPC case, when he tried to bulldoze his way in and get his way with the employees.

That is the whole basis of our policy. It will deliver greater productivity to Australia. It means that sensible, flexible arrangements can be entered into. If parties have to go to the Industrial Relations Commission, they are going to have delays, costs and rigidities imposed upon them, when really they want a more flexible and productive result.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know that?

—Senator Cook cannot believe that individuals are capable of making these decisions themselves. The trouble with what we heard from him yesterday is that he does not believe individuals are capable of doing that. The sheer arrogance of the Big Brother notion of government and the notion of big unions, Big Brother Halfpenny and Big Brother Cook: they think they know best! We have faith and we believe that individuals can make these decisions for themselves. It is quite clear from the Morgan poll results I have just quoted from that the Australian people now have sufficient confidence in themselves to make these decisions and, in fact, are demanding that they make them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's policy, apart from being fair and reasonable and one that will return greater productivity to the Australian economy, will ensure a much more democratic system than that of the Government. The people of Australia want to get Big Brother out of this area and are demanding more and more that they be able to do so. They are demanding the policies that the Liberal and National parties have been espousing and promoting for the past 4 1/2 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be grateful if at some stage Senator Durack could table the document from which he quoted showing the poll results. We hear about these results but we never see the document. I would be interested to know whether in that poll a question was asked to the effect, `If management has made a series of bad investments and caused a company to suffer loss, should it be exclusively the right or the obligation of the employees to take wage cuts to bail it out?'. If that question were asked-and I guess it was not because we have not heard of it from the Opposition-we would get an objective view of the circumstances of this case.

SPEECH.PARA: At present in the period of recession, for whatever reason, some companies are facing difficulties. There is existing flexibility within the current system to have trade-offs where those are required. If trade-offs take place, that must be done by consultation with all parties. If we exclude one of the parties, it has a perfect right to object. The forum in which it should object is the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

If there is a trade-off, it must be done through the proper processes of the law. It must go before the umpire, who will say whether it is fair or not. If people advocate particular deals and say that those deals are fair, I ask them, and the Opposition, to tell us what they are afraid of. If they reckon this is a good deal, why not take the matter to the umpire and let the umpire say so? If they have confidence in this deal they will be prepared to come forward and let it be subject to judgment. The nub of the issue is that they do not want to undergo independent judgment.

There is enterprise flexibility in the existing wage system. It is embodied in the accord. The Department of Industrial Relations runs a work change program aimed at trying to generate higher productivity and profitability in the workplace by bringing together the partners-the management and the owners on one side and the workers on the other-to work out how best to set goals for that enterprise, how best to generate higher productivity and greater competitiveness for that enterprise, and how to share the rewards equally, evenly and fairly between themselves for the efforts that they put in.

That is the current system. That system is there; it should be used. I do not leap to judgment about whether the deal done at SPC Ltd is right or wrong. I note that the Opposition does, but I am not as intimately familiar with all of the affairs of that company as to cause me to accredit to myself the right to make a judgment. What I do say is that that right exists with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, and the Industrial Relations Commission process is the process which should be gone through to judge it. That is not simply my view. It is also now the view of Mr John Carboy, the Managing Director of SPC. On the morning program on Channel 9, when asked a direct question on that matter by Elizabeth Hayes, the interviewer, he said that he would have done it differently now that he knows how the industrial relations system operates. In hindsight, he said, he would have gone through those processes. So, before one champions a particular cause, one should come to the facts of the matter, understand what those facts are and relate to those facts in the present system.

What this urgency motion does is a most scurrilous and unprincipled thing. It does not attack the Government; it does not attack the union movement; it does not criticise employers; it does not say that the workers were wrong: it attacks the umpire. It says, `The umpire has no place; the umpire is out of court; it should not apply; the umpire has no standing'.

I look at Senator Winston Crane on the other side of the chamber, who just last week asked me, as a Minister of this Government, to intervene and to tell the umpire to do certain things in a particular dispute. He wanted intervention in that dispute. I was asked yesterday by Senator Durack, who has propounded this item, whether I would intervene in this particular dispute. I am not going to intervene in this dispute, as I was not going to intervene in the other dispute. The Government is not butting in. The Government is not saying, `We are Big Brother; we know best'. We are simply saying, `If the deal is fair, then you have nothing to fear from submitting it through due process to the umpire for it to be determined as fair'.

The process of conciliation and arbitration was founded in this country in 1904 by the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. It has served this country well. It is highly regarded by the community. Although it is criticised by the practitioners, they support it. It is passing strange that the party that aspires to be the government of this country should now want to undermine the central institution which guarantees good industrial relations outcomes in this country and which puts workers on an equal footing with employers in going before an impartial authority experienced in industrial relations and, in a layman's court where one does not have to be a lawyer to state one's case, to argue what is right. It vests in those experienced practitioners who sit on the bench and have knowledge of this field the right to answer the most vexed question in industrial relations, a question which is essentially a matter for value judgment: what is fair in these particular circumstances? It asks the bench to determine that matter.

Employers have one view; workers have another. Someone has to decide it. It can be decided by strike action; it can be decided by lock-out; it can be decided by muscle, if we wish. But in this country we have a civilised system. It is decided by arbitration, and it is decided in a way and in an ethos aimed at lowering the level of industrial disputation and removing conflict from the workplace and from industry. That is the system that the party which aspires to government now wants to throw over.

I make three criticisms of this urgency motion. It is short sighted, it is dangerous, and it is derelict in the duty the Opposition owes to this nation. It is short sighted because, while the bargaining powers in times of unemployment rest with employers, the wheel will turn. Next year at this time, with economic recovery under way, the bargaining power will shift back to the unions. Will those opposite be asking me, when the unions have a stronger bargaining power in the workplace, to allow those deals to go ahead? On the record of those opposite, of course they will not; they will be asking me to restrain the unions' activities.

The Opposition wants freedom now when the bargaining shares are on one side but it does not want freedom in future when they are on the other. There ought to be the restraint of the umpire in all circumstances. Do not be short-sighted; do not follow the course that the Fraser Government went down of double digit unemployment, double digit inflation, massive wage outcomes and low and negative economic growth. That is the experience of the past. The Opposition should learn from its past; it should learn about regulation and stability.

The motion is dangerous, too. As I said in Question Time earlier this week, we have managed in times of high economic growth to get moderate wage outcomes. But we were criticised on polling day. People have said-and Senator Kemp is one of the most recent to say it-that real wages have fallen. Well, real wages have fallen but real living standards have risen under this Government. That is an indisputable fact.

If one looks at the statistics, one sees that there has been an 11 per cent improvement in real household disposable income per capita over the life of this Government. If honourable senators opposite do not want moderate wage outcomes and if in a period of recovery they want the law of the jungle to apply, they should support this motion. They would then free everyone from the shackles of having to conform to a system of regulation, reasonableness and arbitration. If honourable senators opposite want to free people from those shackles, they should face up to their responsibility when there is recovery.

We want to see this economy recover in a steady, regular and sustained way. That requires control over wages policy as much as it requires control over the other levers of economic management. Honourable senators opposite would dispense with that. No wonder the judgment of the electors at the last election was, `If you do not have a wages policy, you do not have an economic policy and you cannot govern'.

The motion is also a dereliction of duty. The Party opposite aspires to government yet undermines the institutions through which a government can regulate industrial relations. I want the next speaker from the Opposition side to give a declaration of support for the rule of law in industrial relations. I want to hear that speaker say, `We support the law and we ask people to conform with it. We advocate that you go through due and proper process and proper arbitration'. If honourable senators opposite are not prepared to uphold the rule of law in this country and declare their support for the institutions able to deliver it in industrial relations, they are bankrupt, they do not deserve to be in government and they are derelict in their duty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is apparent from what we have witnessed in the past 20 minutes that industrial relations will be one of the prime themes of the next two or three years, leading up to the next election and beyond. It was only last weekend that Mr John Howard, the shadow Minister for industrial relations, suggested that within 18 months of the Opposition being elected we would probably be confronted with a double dissolution on the issue of industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: The question inherent in this motion of urgency is whether, as Senator Cook has so assertively stated, the umpire has any relevance and whether he will be called upon to make judgments in matters of prime industrial disputation. In the alternative model proposed by the Opposition, no standing is given to the umpire or to the place of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Therein lies the fundamental difference. The Government's model has been reinforced as a result of legislation enacted in this chamber about 10 days ago. In other words, the model endorsed by the government of the day is the law of the land. That is the model prevailing at the moment. The Opposition is telling us that it has no truck with that model, that it will pursue immediately, with great dedication and commitment-and good luck to it-the alternative model.

Today we are witnessing an example of the alternative model in operation-an alternative model operating in a very positive context and climate. I refer to a cooperative in which workers, who have part ownership, sit down with management and formulate propositions about their future in a very responsible way. That is a technique and an approach to industrial relations which I suggest is totally acceptable to everybody in this chamber.

As the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) said yesterday in answering a question, that approach is inherent in the present legislation. In section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act, there is acknowledgment of the fact that that is the best way of doing things. The Opposition is telling us that that is the only way of doing things and that in the final analysis those outcomes are irrevocable, beyond criticism and must be acceptable, irrespective of whether they begin to dismantle, undermine and erode fundamental standards, awards and conditions that have been hard won over a period of decades. In this context, the outcome may be fine. The consequences of the Opposition's model will be big winners and big losers.

If we want proof of whether or not deregulated labour produces big winners and big losers, we should look at the outcome even within the present model. Look at the change in the salary structures of executives in Australia over the last 18 months to two years. I have cited in this place over and over again the example of the managing director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia getting a 100 per cent increase in salary overnight. We have those particular outcomes for the big winners but, by heavens, I am fearful for the tea ladies at Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. I am fearful for the people who are, under the alternative system, not able to bring themselves together into larger combines than the enterprise will allow.

The Opposition would see unions 10-strong; it would see 10 weak people walking in, confronting a powerful, strong management and attempting to negotiate with it, and the outcomes would not be as positive and beneficial as those glossy outcomes that the Opposition was advocating and waving around in front of us as being the inevitable outcomes of the alternative model.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have sold out again.

—I do not happen to agree with Senator Kemp. Opposition members cannot accept the fact that people can legitimately hold other points of view. They accuse us of selling out and of dealing when we negotiate with a government of the day and arrive at sensible outcomes for legislation. They call that selling out. It is emotive rubbish, and it has to be seen for what it is.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that we are seeing here today propounded in an urgency motion what we predict will be the outcome of the alternative model-that is, the divide and conquer mentality, which requires people not to enlarge their organisations or to unite much beyond the enterprise level, and it is argued that inevitably the best outcomes will result from that. We do not believe that the best outcomes will result in all cases of enterprise bargaining.
