If the workers are part owners, as they are at SPC, if the management is receptive, as it is at SPC, the outcomes are likely to be admirable. The Australian Democrats argue that those outcomes should be taken somewhere where they will be looked upon and judged as to whether they are in the best interests of the community at large; whether they are in the best interests of those who may not have as much power or who are not in as favourable circumstances as those at SPC.

John Howard was quoted as saying, `Give us a thousand Mudginberries'-give us a thousand situations of war, picketing and confrontation as a model. He would argue that that is the method we should use to put into the hands of Australian householders their assured income. We simply argue that there is only one way to ensure that the average Australian and the households of average Australians will be serviced with an adequate minimum income and will be guaranteed to work in safe conditions-conditions which are appropriate for the 1990s-and that is to have in place a centralised model supervised by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission; strong and independent of the Government and the unions; open-doored and open-minded; and fair and just.

That is exactly what we tried to assist this Government in enacting in this place approximately 10 days ago. It was the Democrats who pursued the interests of small organisations and individuals and who moved a whole series of amendments in pursuit of those principles-amendments which were opposed by the Opposition at the time.

Let us be very clear: the Australian Democrats are quite firm in their conviction that deregulated labour with small intensively divided unions will not produce outcomes which are in the best collective interests of Australia as a nation, of our economy, of Australian households, and even of individual Australians. It might seem to be appropriate at SPC today, in hard tough times, to let go hard won conditions and awards, but who is going to get them back? Who is going to be the arbiter? Who is going to be the umpire to ensure that those hard won awards, which are our minimum standards of living, are ever going to be obtained again if the divide and conquer model and mentality are put in place and laid on us over a period of two, three or five years? The hard won achievements of the last five decades or even eight or nine decades will be progressively eroded because individual workers believe that in the short term it is in their precise interests.

It has been said in this brief debate-it has only been a debate in the community for the last week or so-that the SPC workers do in fact have the right to negotiate. Of course they have the right to negotiate about their own work circumstances, but they do not have the right to throw away the awards and conditions of people right across this country because they will not go to the legitimate umpire who is in place by the laws of the land. We simply do not accept the fact that it is inevitable, as the Opposition would argue, that enterprise bargaining will deliver better outcomes to Australian workers. We have grave fears that it will not. The big winners will be the people who are represented on this side of the chamber. The people in this country who are earning $200,000 and $300,000 a year have not made the sacrifices of the last four or five years that have been carried by the average Australian worker. The judgments have been supervised and imposed upon those workers by the Industrial Relations Commission. It should be quite clear to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and to those listening to this debate that we believe in a fair, just--
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Peter Baume) Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say is that Senator McLean does not have a clue what he is talking about. He spent the whole 10 minutes talking about disputation. That is not what this debate is about. The debate is about voluntary agreements between employers and employees. We have got the situation where unemployment is escalating beyond belief. We have been told that 10,500 people became unemployed last week, on top of the rising unemployment that we had last month.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is saying that employers and employees have no right to come to an agreement on how to save both their jobs and their businesses. We have a recession that Mr Keating has acknowledged he deliberately engineered, and he tells us that he has got it under control. With 10,500 people unemployed last week? Some control! We have the highest number of bankruptcies ever in Australia. Yet the Minister's headlines in the Sydney Morning Herald on 13 December read `Hands off worker awards, says Govt'. That is just lovely, is it not?

Mr Kelty says that, when people are trying to reach a voluntary agreement, the employees have said that they are happy to take a cut in conditions so long as the bosses take cuts too. He says, `We have to protect the work force from themselves. We cannot allow that to happen'. The arrogance is absolutely unbelievable. Mr Kelty knows better than any of the workers who are about to lose their jobs and who have trusted the employers on many occasions. The Government is forcing these voluntary agreements to go through a tremendous number of channels before they are finally rectified or agreed to and then only if the umpire agrees.

I will make it perfectly clear because neither Senator Cook nor Senator McLean-Senator McLean has the rudeness to walk out the chamber-will acknowledge that the situation that presently stands is one of the options that can remain under our policy. However, if the employers and the employees want to come to an agreement and do not want to have to go through the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, then they are quite at liberty to do so.

In our policy we say that if the employees want to be represented by a union or any other agent to negotiate with their employer, then they are entitled to do so. We will not allow the situation to occur where an employer would screw the workers down; that is not part of our policy. I also stress that in Australia at the moment because of this Government's wages accord there is a lack of productivity, which has resulted in the present decline in the living standards of Australians.

Let us look at the Power Brewing Co. Ltd because it is a very good example. The employer says, `If there is a productive work environment, people can be employed at a much better rate of wages'. The employee says, `That is fine, that suits us, it is a wonderful idea'. Ray Dempsey of the Trades and Labour Council of Queensland says, `You are a minority group who want secret sly deals and we will not allow it; we will not pander to you'. That is just lovely union work, is it not? The Government has stressed that it will not allow these situations to exist by the legislation it brought in last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Freedom for employees and employers to negotiate what they like, freedom from interference by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, freedom from inflexibility and rigidities, freedom from the shackles of awards through voluntary agreements, everyone will be better off if we have freedom-that is the utopia that the Liberal and National parties opposite would have us believe. It is the sloganing of revolutionaries with sweeping rhetoric and unsubstantiated claims. It is a big lie and a big con. It is fatally flawed for three reasons that I will outline today: under the Opposition's system there would not be equal bargaining power; we do not know who or what is an employee; and there would be no supervision of the process that the Opposition insists would improve our standard of living in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to equal bargaining power, if an employer is allowed to bargain without any restrictions whatsoever with his or her employees, the employer is flanked by legal advisers, security firms and fancy public relations (PR) companies. We do not see any cutting of costs in those areas in the SPC Ltd case. The ultimate strength of the employer is to hire and fire. If that is what is allowed to occur at a workplace, in most workplaces in this country the employer will be dominant. He will be dominant because the bargaining unions will be so small-they will average no more than 10 or 15 employees in a union-that they will not have lawyers, security firms or PR firms. They will not even have the right to strike under the policy of the Liberal and National parties.

Who is an employee some 200 to 300? In the SPC case a number of workers are currently employed, and are determining the rights of 1,000 workers who are not currently employed-the seasonal workers. This is a common occurrence right throughout industry where there is a casual work force in a significant--

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it better for them to have a job to come back to?
—Senator Crane will get his chance in a moment. I did not interject when he made his speech, so he should listen quietly. We have a situation in the hospitality industry--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is typical of the Opposition's policy, which is a shambles and is full of rhetoric. In this country-
—Arrogance.
—Opposition senators are the ones who are arrogant because they want to allow the workers of this country to be ripped off; that is what their policy means.
—Spoken like a good union man.

—Exactly. I am a good union man and proud of it. In these workplaces, where will employees have the right to protect themselves? Last week Senator Walters had the audacity to complain about ballots being conducted at the workplace. She wanted secret postal ballots. How will these ballots be supervised? Who will supervise them? According to Senator Walters, there are standover tactics when these ballots are conducted at the workplace. They are the sorts of problems we have. Workers who are currently employed are decreasing the wages and conditions of workers who will be employed in future. Is it fair that the thousands of workers to be employed by SPC--
—At least they will be employed.
—Order! Senator Chapman, you are speaking next.

—Their wages and conditions are being reduced by the current work force. The workers who will be employed by SPC in future have not been consulted about all this. The Opposition does not want any registration of these so-called agreements. Who is to enforce these agreements then? Who is to determine whether they have been entered into freely and equally without coercion? We do not know. Honourable senators on the other side of the chamber have suddenly discovered freedom, but it is freedom in one area only. I dare say that the business people in this country would like freedom from contract law. They would like the freedom to do what they like. I dare say that if workers in this country were asked whether they would like the freedom not to pay taxes there would be a 100 per cent response. That is what freedom is; it is a buzz word to honourable senators opposite. It is freedom at whose cost? Under the Opposition's system, the strong, including a small number of workers, will get stronger. The rich will get richer, the weak will get weaker and they will be poorer for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Ninety years ago in this country we established an industrial relations system. Until then we had no annual leave, no eight-hour day, no sick leave, no superannuation, no long service leave and no minimum wage. Workers had no dignity, few rights and often died on the job because of it, but they had freedom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no wonder that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and Senator Sherry, whom we have just heard, have reacted so strongly against the voluntary agreement established between SPC Ltd and its employees. It is that agreement which makes this urgency motion moved today by the Opposition so timely. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Parliament to enable employers and employees to make voluntary agreements to determine the conditions of employment in their own work place without the intervention of the Industrial Relations Commission.

The SPC agreement is yet another nail in the coffin of the industrial relations club, of which the Minister is a life member, signalling its inevitable demise. It has demonstrated what I have been saying for a decade and what has been Liberal Party policy for at least five years: the best industrial relations is achieved when negotiations are undertaken at individual workplaces between employers and employees, making the present role of trade unions, employer organisations and that industrial dinosaur, the industrial relations club, largely irrelevant. We see the Minister and the union movement insisting that this agreement, voluntarily and logically agreed between consenting adults, should have to be ratified by the Industrial Relations Commission. His argument that workers, irrespective of the choice they make for themselves, require protection from rapacious employers is nothing more than rhetorical scaremongering.

The Minister, in creating images of nineteenth century sweatshops instead of a twenty-first century flexible and streamlined industrial relations system, which Australia desperately requires if it is going to be able to compete in the world, demonstrates the utter bankruptcy of the Government's approach to industrial relations. There is no evidence of SPC being rapacious. Nor under the Liberal and National parties' industrial relations policy, which strongly endorses voluntary agreements, would there be scope for rapaciousness, as I will explain in a moment.

The real reason behind this Government's insistence that all agreements be ratified by the Commission is simply to protect the vested interests of the industrial relations club, to protect the power and privilege of union officials and to protect the power and privilege of the Industrial Relations Commission. It is neither necessary nor practical for voluntary agreements to be ratified by the Industrial Relations Commission. If the employer and employees at each of Australia's 750,000 or so small and medium-sized businesses reached voluntary agreements, how long do honourable senators think it will take for these to be ratified by the Industrial Relations Commission if that was required? It would take years. That alone demonstrates the nonsense of the Government's position. Or is the Government promoting a commission hearings-led recovery from recession, creating non-productive jobs for all the advocates, research workers and other hangers-on in the system?

A key plank of the coalition's industrial relations policy in relation to voluntary agreements is the requirement that agreements must provide for the relevant minimum award rate of pay calculated as an hourly rate. In other words, there will be no sweated labour under our policy; a fair rate of pay will be mandatory. The extras will be voluntarily negotiable-hours of work, overtime rates, holidays, productivity bonuses, profit sharing agreements and so on, as has been the case with the SPC deal.

Our policy also guarantees that employees may appoint agents, such as a trade union or an expert individual consultant negotiator, to represent them and negotiate on their behalf. One SPC employee claimed last week, `We want the union to do what we want'. This aspect of our policy, to guarantee a choice for employees to appoint agents on their behalf, will ensure that that is the case. Unlike this Government's laws, which through the `conveniently belong' clause and the requirement for a minimum union size of 10,000 prevents employees having a real choice between unions to represent them, the coalition will allow such a genuine choice, requiring unions to offer real service and expertise to employees to attract members.

Australia desperately needs an industrial relations system that promotes industrial harmony and cooperation between employers and employees. Voluntary agreements will encourage direct negotiations between employers and employees and will weld communication between them based on their mutual interests and the uniqueness of their enterprise. It is not acceptable to preserve a centrally determined award at the expense of jobs. We must lay to rest the Henry Bournes Higgins' awards of 80 years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mudginberri was cited today as an example of how well voluntary agreements work. I was recently in Kakadu and went to where Mudginberri used to be. I saw nothing there; Mudginberri was no more. It does not seem to me to follow that, because the results have been proclaimed as a victory, there has in fact been this great victory for voluntary agreements. There may be some other reason, of course, but it would be interesting to know why that famous test was a failure.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been discussions here today. It might be as well to look at what the High Court of Australia has to say about this issue. After all, that is the body which, standing above all, reaches conclusions on the facts as they are presented. In Federated Municipal and Shire Council Employees Union of Australia v. Melbourne Corporation, Mr Justice Isaacs, who later became the first Australian born Governor-General of this country, and Mr Justice Rich said:

This, which is the irresistible conclusion from a broad survey of the stream of industrial effort, is emphasized by the views of Mr Sidney Webb in a recent work. The ``industrial revolution'' for a long time made the workman's labour a mere marketable commodity to be bought at the lowest price that individual competition between workers would permit. The degradation and suffering that ensued, the revolt against the system, the repression of illegal acts, the amelioration of the law, the organization of labour, the gradual recognition of collective bargaining, the introduction of private conciliation and arbitration as well as of industrial laws securing better conditions for workers, are all well-known historical facts.

Their Honours were at pains to point out that if the only thing that a worker has to sell is his labour then he is subject to that competition which has the effect of forcing his and her wages and conditions down to the point where the fearsome results that their Honours talk about result. The problem for the argument advanced opposite is to explain why that would not occur again if there were not some organisation that enabled the workers, as Senator Sherry has so eloquently said, to have some equality in the bargaining position with their employers.
As a ramification to that, their Honours in the later case of McGuire v. Union Steamship Co. of New Zealand, in talking about workers compensation, said:

Next, as to the history of the measure. The pressure of the disability of workmen was constantly increasing. The advancing complication of industry in many occupations vitally altered in practice the relative positions of employer and workman. In connection with another but cognate branch of the law, we have recently made reference to this change.

If we sacrifice the part played by unions in industrial relations there is the threat that we will sacrifice their part in maintaining safety in industry and getting fair compensation for workers who are injured.

I do not think the Opposition understands the full implication of what it says. The implication is there in that case: not only is the workers' industrial strength prejudiced but so too is his and her ability to get fair compensation for the injuries they receive at work. Finally, the Industrial Relations Commission says that unions--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I go to the main theme that I wish to talk about, there are a couple of points I would like to make about the debate so far. Unfortunately, Senator McLean and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) have chosen to leave us. Firstly, I suggest that Senator McLean reads our policy-I am quite happy to give him a copy-because he would find out just how wrong he is. The second point is that the Minister threw down the gauntlet and said that we did not stand for upholding the law. I point out in this chamber that in my experience-as he well knows-not only have I been involved in legal cases against the union movement but also against employers and the Government, of which he is a member. I make it quite clear that when we talk about upholding the law his Government is not above board.

SPEECH.PARA: One cannot let the references to Mud- ginberri go by without comment. Senator Cooney obviously does not understand what happened in Mudginberri. The award under which Mudginberri was operating, established before Commissioner MacKenzie, was the Northern Territory meat award. I want to point out to this chamber that Mudginberri was always terminal. Its termination was hastened very greatly because after the Mudginberri dispute got through the courts there was an increased effort, which was facilitated by this very Government, to have the buffalo which were to be supplied to those works shot out through the tuberculosis and brucellosis program. That is on record and I want to reinforce it right here and now. To talk about Mudginberri being a failure in terms of this debate is absolutely and totally inaccurate.

This debate has been brought on because of a productivity agreement with regard to SPC Ltd. What is it about? It is about preserving jobs, preserving an Australian company and sharing in the profits. I want to ask some questions about this. I want to ask where the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is. Why is he not speaking out on behalf of the workers? Is it not ironic? He fought for his job last week. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission was not involved, but I bet the Australian Council of Trade Unions was. Where is the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook? He has left the chamber. All we hear from him is a warning to SPC not to break the rules. We hear continual reference to the umpire, an umpire which has been totally disregarded in industrial relations in this country for many years. Mudginberri highlights that, as does the current situation with the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, Wally Curran and the meat dispute. We talk about an umpire which one side obeys and the other side ignores.

Why does the Minister not bring an emergency Bill before us-a Bill for commonsense in industrial relations; a Bill which allows management and employees to agree on how they will operate, which allows for productivity increases, which allows for profit sharing and which allows for enterprise agreements to be established on the shop floor; a Bill which allows management and employees to protect the enterprise; and a Bill which protects the jobs of people in the enterprise. I particularly want to note section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988. It says under `Certified agreements':
If the parties to an industrial dispute . . .

There is no industrial dispute with SPC. The parties sat down and worked out the best way to preserve their position and their jobs. We on this side of the chamber will sit here all night if necessary to ensure that commonsense can operate in the industrial relations arena to enable employers and employees to make voluntary agreements without the intrusion of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, the unions or employer organisations. But it would destroy the Minister's union bosses' power base, his preferential clauses for unionists and his beautiful big unions. It would introduce voluntary unionism and create enterprise unions; it would make the Australian Democrats, who sold their souls last week when they assisted the Government in getting its Industrial Relations Bill through, look silly. Where is Bill Kelty? He is only interested in enshrining union power. What of John Halfpenny? He would sooner throw 300 jobs on the scrap heap.

Let us look at why genuine enterprise agreements and genuine enterprise unions cannot be established in Australia. It is because we have enshrined in legislation that the players must be the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and big unions. Let us look at the situation in Western Australia right now. The front page of the West Australian reports 450 companies which will go broke. Would they not love the opportunity to sit down and work out an arrangement whereby they could survive in their jobs?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two areas that I want to consider in the time that I have today. I intend to consider the proposal submitted by Senator Durack on the ground of whether it is desirable for the Australian industrial relations system and I also wish to look at some of the more disturbing aspects of the dispute currently occurring at SPC Ltd. I will start with the SPC dispute. The Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, Mr Howard, said in the Herald-Sun today about the dispute:

SPEECH.PARA: The essential facts are quite straightforward. Due to the recession and the huge problems of the canning industry, the company, SPC, is doing badly.

Mr Howard was half right. The essential facts are straightforward. But he managed to get them wrong. In yesterday's Australian Financial Review, SPC's new chairman, John Corboy explained what the essential facts were. He blamed the company's poor financial state on poor decisions of the previous board, all of which showed a business flair more closely associated with companies like Elders IXL Ltd or Bond Corporation than the local cannery. The results were similar: a debt ridden company servicing the banks. That is a far cry from the portrayal of the company which the Opposition and Mr Howard favour and which the media has, in all but a few cases, accepted without question-that of a local company in a bit of trouble, with workers and management pitching in to save it from the horrible recession of the Hawke Labor Government, a sort of `Mr Smith goes to Shepparton'.

It is truly wonderful what a good public relations firm can do these days. SPC, despite its parlous financial state, seems to have enough money to pay for International Public Relations Ltd (IPR) to do its public relations. IPR is, just by the way, a firm which has been described by the Minister as having New Right connections. I understand that it is accommodating enough to brief journalists on appropriate angles to adopt in reporting the story.

Not only can SPC afford to pay for a public relations firm; it can also afford to commission a Morgan gallup poll to prove to all and sundry that popular support is on the company's side. At this rate, SPC might have to renegotiate its agreement with its workers by Christmas to reduce labour costs further to pay for all this recent expenditure.

The point that appeals to me more than any other is that there is no question that SPC is in a financial mess and that this situation has existed for some time. Last year, for instance, a $2.3m loss was recorded. What austerity measures were implemented then? The directors recommended that their fees be increased by 7.5 per cent. Average weekly earnings rose by only 6.3 per cent in that year. Overall, directors' fees during the year rose from $289,023 to $368,683, an increase of 27.6 per cent. Honourable senators will not be surprised to learn that those austerity measures failed, so the workers are forced to wear it.

Did the company use the processes which have so recently and successfully been used by a number of different enterprises, including Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and ICI Australia, to vary their awards? No. SPC called a meeting of its permanent employees and rushed through a deal. There was no input from the seasonal workers, who will lose about $25 a week because of this. There was no consultation with the unions involved. So now we have a blue and the Opposition sees its chance. It finally has a practical example for its four-year-old industrial relations policy. Hewson is on a plane before someone can say `enterprise bargaining'.

I want to make two brief points about the policy. First, the Opposition apparently thinks that the Industrial Relations Commission is an inappropriate body to approve variations of awards and that only parties involved should participate. They want, in effect, to kill the umpire. The Opposition must come to terms with the fact that the industrial relations system is not made up of level playing fields. In some situations the employers have the upper hand-for instance, right now in Shepparton.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating an urgency motion put down by the Opposition:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Parliament to enable employers and employees to make voluntary agreements to determine the conditions of employment in their own work place without the intervention of the Industrial Relations Commission.

Those are the key words: `without the invention of the Industrial Relations Commission'. My comments will be made on the basis of this urgency motion and the words that are used therein. I will not be referring to the comments that have been made thus far by speakers from the Government, the Opposition or the Australian Democrats.

Frankly, I feel that the Opposition probably does not mean to support the precise wording of the urgency motion. The last time I really heard such a proposition put very strongly was in the 1970s. In the late 1960s and the 1970s, when there was low unemployment and high demand for labour, this call for workers and employers to decide their conditions without reference to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, as it was then, was made by the Communist Party and the hard Left. They were the ones who were calling for the Arbitration Commission to cease interfering in the relationships between employers and employees. They were the ones who wanted the shop committees to be the determinant factor and then to come up with agreements with employers.

As I say, that was at a time when the balance was in favour of the workers because of the low unemployment situation and the high demand for labour. I well recall the arguments that occurred in the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the State executive, of which I was a member at that time. We stood for an orderly system of industrial progress, which meant that there should be an umpire.

That was envisaged by the founding fathers of the Commonwealth in the Constitution. Section 51(xxxv.) of the Constitution clothes the Commonwealth Parliament with the power to make laws with respect to conciliation and arbitration of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State. The system of conciliation and arbitration found favour initially with the trade union movement because of the problems the trade union movement had then, because workers were exploited in the early part of this century.

The fact is that the system of conciliation and arbitration is deeply embedded into national consciousness as being worthy of protection, preservation and improvement. I am concerned with the last part of this urgency motion which indicates that people can do away with the intervention of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission on important award matters. This could give rise to another demand, if not for the abolition of the system, then for the complete undermining of it. I remind the Opposition that the only time the system was put to the test electorally was in 1929 when the Bruce Government went to the people on a platform of destroying arbitration. It was the Bruce Government that was destroyed and the Labor Government, standing for the protection of the system, was elected.
I have grave questions on the policy of the Government at this stage in respect of the amalgamation of unions. I have expressed those in another debate, but I believe--

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I congratulate the Australian Honey Research Council on its annual report and the work it does in trying to increase commercial returns to members of the honey industry by improving the production, processing, storage, transport and marketing of honey and other bee products. Although not much in the public eye, the honey industry is quite impressive, as total recorded production of honey for the 12 months to the end of June this year was 22,619 tonnes, with exports totalling 12,637 tonnes. This is slightly down on the figure from the previous year.

The domestic scene in the honey industry, I have to admit, is becoming quite exciting. The range of honeys on the Australian market is staggering. Created exclusively from a combination of bees, flowers and sunshine, honey is one of the few truly natural foods remaining. Australia's long hours of sunshine and its great selection of native trees and ground flora have given us a marvellous selection of unique floral honey varieties.

However, because the beekeeping industry is relatively small in size and number, it is often ignored by government. It is not a large industry and it does not have a lot of money. We therefore have to be ever vigilant to keep an eye on ensuring that beekeepers stay in business and have them look after the agricultural crops that we need them for so desperately. A healthy beekeeping industry is absolutely essential. For example, as the report notes, the industry is very much tied to circumstances out of its control. The report says:
Council has identified the loss, or potential loss, of traditional nectar and pollen sources as the single major problem confronting the honey industry.

This erosion of the resource base has a number of distinct and unrelated causes including clearing for forested country; clear felling for timber production; uncontrolled burning; biological control of salvation Jane, blackberry and thistles; rural dieback; and conversion of Crown land to reserves or national park status.

As I said earlier, it is in Australia's interest to maintain a viable honey industry and it therefore worries me that, according to the Australian Honey Board, the decline in real incomes of Australian honey producers continues to be of concern. The report says:
The main influences on price remain the level of the world bulk market for honey in US dollars, the Australian and US exchange rate and demand on the domestic market.
It states further:
Domestic operating costs continued to grow as a result of inflation and high interest charges.

It is vital, therefore, under such adverse conditions that we do all that we can to maintain the strength of the industry by watching the effect of economic factors and monitoring the importation not only of honey produce but also of diseases. Of concern to many in the industry is the importation of honey from countries where the chalk brood disease is endemic. This disease is of some concern to beekeepers and is regarded as a serious exotic disease by the Australian beekeeping industry.

The Government, however, in reply to a number of questions in the Senate on this issue by some of my colleagues has dismissed these concerns by saying that internationally chalk brood is not regarded as a major infectious disease of honey bees. Of course it is not. Nearly every country in the world has it and nothing is being done about trying to get rid of it. But I say to the Government that Australia does not have it and our beekeepers do not want it. It is quite a nasty complaint and it affects the effectiveness and profitability of beekeeping. The beekeepers of Australia deserve to be given more support. They deserve to be supported as an industry in their own right and for what they do for agriculture generally.

I conclude by saying that there is no doubting the importance of the Honey Research Council and its work. I commend it for the tremendous job it is doing in addressing the research needs of the industry, and I have very great pleasure in taking note of this report today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to fill the Senate in on a remark which was passed by Senator Bjelke-Petersen a moment ago on honey. She mentioned in passing that the task of apiarists has been made more difficult because of the loss of sources of nectar. Among the sources which she mentioned was salvation jane. Honourable senators will recall that a vigorous campaign was waged by apiarists against the biological control of salvation jane because it is indeed a good source of nectar and quite a good source of honey.

SPEECH.PARA: What is not generally known, and what I should like to put on the record, is that salvation Jane contains a class of very toxic agents called pyrollizide alkaloids. Those alkaloids are known liver toxins and are potent carcinogens. Indeed, when bees collect the nectar from salvation Jane and take it back to the hive to turn it into honey, those pyrollizide alkaloids turn up in the honey in quite significant concentrations.

It was certainly of great distress to me to see that during the several years in which the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation was attempting to introduce biological control of salvation Jane-which is also very toxic to a number of animals, particularly horses, because of its liver toxicity-apiarists were fighting for that particular resource and the public was not being informed that honey from that source contained quite significant amounts of these alkaloids and therefore posed a cancer risk for people eating that honey. So we need to be aware that even with a substance as natural as honey-to pick up Senator Bjelke-Petersen's words-there are a number of natural products which do carry risks, and honey happens to be one of them.

I understand that the biological control of salvation Jane has been introduced. While that might reduce the flow of honey, it will not be detrimental to Australians in general because, presumably, the honey they are getting now from other sources is safer to eat. This is a very useful object lesson to put on the record. Very shortly we will be debating the therapeutic goods regulations. Much of the lobbying which is going on in relation to that legislation is to the effect that natural products are automatically safe and good and should not be regulated in any way. Honey collected from salvation Jane is just one example among many of a `natural' product consumption of which carries with it a very significant risk of developing cancer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

During this year the water storage levels in the Snowy Mountains scheme have increased considerably. Following release from storage, the Murray River system received 1.269 gigalitres and the Murrumbidgee 1.408 gigalitres.

The Snowy Mountains scheme is probably the biggest engineering project that Australia has ever undertaken. It was the first big project after the Second World War. The scheme has been of immense benefit to the Australian economy not only in terms of the production of electricity but also in terms of the amount of water made available for irrigation purposes in agricultural regions. I visited the scheme about two years ago and I could not believe the size of it. I was amazed at the foresight that Australia had in 1948, so soon after the war, even to think of undertaking such a project. The earthmoving machinery that was used then would have been manufactured either prior to or during World War II and would not have had anywhere near the capacity of modern plant.

I doubt whether a feasibility study carried out on such a scheme today would ever get past the drawing board stage because of the restrictions imposed by environmental and radical groups. I am strongly of the opinion that such a scheme would not go ahead today.

Water from the scheme irrigates land extending from Gundagai right out to Griffith. I estimate that it irrigates an area of approximately 150 kilometres by 200 kilometres. As such, it must rank as one of the major irrigation systems of the world. Nowhere in the world have I seen such a large area of good agricultural ground which lacks only sufficient rainfall. The production of electricity and water for irrigation is certainly a memorial to the people who thought of this scheme in the first place.

I would like to pay tribute to the founders of the Snowy Mountains scheme and the people who brought it to fruition. I notice that a reunion was held on 17 October 1989 to celebrate the fortieth anniversary of the scheme. Two and a half thousand present and former workers turned up at Jindabyne for a picnic. This, no doubt, was a fitting way to celebrate such an occasion. As I said, the scheme is truly a credit to engineering in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In moving this motion I am drawn to look at the figures that relate to Commonwealth Government expenditure in Queensland. It was only yesterday that the Vice-Chancellor of the Queensland University of Technology said that higher education in Queensland was underfunded by at least 3,000 places. The Commonwealth's paper in 1988 said that Commonwealth funding of higher education in Queensland fell short by something like 4,000 places. There is a definite need for a greater contribution to higher education funding in Queensland.

It is ironic in one way that I rise to speak on this report today because it was only yesterday that my sister, who finished high school this year, received her tertiary entrance score. She was one of the lucky ones because she received a score sufficient to get her into the course that she wishes to study. The thing that concerns me is that tertiary entrance scores are going up year after year. It is much more difficult now to get into, for example, law, advertising or journalism than it was eight years ago when I left school. I am very concerned that it will become increasingly difficult for next year's high school students or students another seven or eight years down the track. This is a matter that is of great concern to me, as I know it is a matter of great concern to many students and parents.

When we debated this matter in the Senate some two weeks ago, I asked the Parliamentary Research Service to do an analysis of Commonwealth expenditure on higher education as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP). The analysis shows that in the last year of the coalition Government expenditure on higher education was 1.01 per cent of GDP. Yet it has shrunk to 0.81 per cent of GDP under a government that says it is interested in making Australia a clever country. This shows the sad fact that under the Australian Labor Party, under Hawke and Keating, funding of higher education has in fact shrunk if it is measured in terms of the investment of this nation's production into the production of the future. I believe that is a sad indictment.

I want to take this opportunity to raise the matter of a separate university campus in Cairns. At the moment there is no dedicated university campus in Cairns, and it is a matter of much concern to the students who are forced to study there. The Government's own figures show that the participation rate in higher education in north Queensland falls substantially below the national average. While in north Queensland the participation rate is 12 per 1,000, in places like Canberra it is 30 per 1,000. It is very clear that there is a desperate need for a separate campus in Cairns.

I refer to the expenditure of the Commonwealth Government on building projects for higher education. In fact, there are three building projects for James Cook University. One involves $195,794 for general purpose academic buildings; another $500,000 for a library extension; and the third $500,000 for contributions to students' residence. Those are all very important, but I want to know why there is not an item in that report that says `Expenditure on a campus site for a university in Cairns', because it is sadly lacking at the moment.

The student numbers in Cairns justify a separate campus site. I believe that many members of the Government benches would probably recognise the fact that a separate campus in Cairns is desperately needed. We have a catchment area there of something like 175,000 people, yet the university is forced to share a site with the college of advanced education. This is not satisfactory. There is much potential in Cairns for very specialised courses that will add to the employment prospects of young people in the Cairns area, especially in areas such as hospitality, rainforest research and marine biology research. This will never become a reality while the Government refuses to fund the separate campus which is so desperately needed by the people of Cairns. It is a long way to go from Cairns to Townsville, and any suggestion that it is possible for people to just travel down to Townsville for their afternoon elective is ridiculous.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) on its annual report for 1989-90 and commend it on the vital part it plays in the lives of most Australians. However, there are two issues I would like to raise about programming decisions that the ABC has made in the past year, both of which I feel, as a mother and a grandmother and as someone who is from the country, are uncalled for.

SPEECH.PARA: Only last August I raised one of these issues in Question Time, namely, the proposed cuts to certain children's programs. I am pleased to say that I was reassured that the Corporation does not intend to axe the program Play School but it has, unfortunately, axed other quality school education programs. I find it amusing that the Corporation boasts on page 34:
Children's programs are strongly Australian. Play School has become increasingly multicultural . . .

That is all well and good, but what about its other programming cuts? After almost 60 years on the airwaves, ABC radio broadcasting to schools is to cease. After 30 years, a large part of the ABC's excellent television programming for schools is also to be axed. The reason, as ever, is money and the chief losers will be children. I regret this very much indeed.

The ABC has stopped buying educational programs from overseas and stopped making local programs except, thankfully, for the very popular programs Behind the News, Asiawide and For the Juniors. Radio singing programs for children, from which the ABC sells about 200,000 accompanying song books a year, will be scrapped, as will the preschool radio program Ticklepot which has won three international awards. It is ironic that these cuts to aids to learning should be made during the International Year of Literacy. On page 24 of the report the ABC boasts of its contribution to the international literacy year by claiming that:

Radio National supported the ABC's contribution to international literacy year and a radio promotion distributed to over 300 commercial and public stations advertised the ABC's starter kits for adults with literacy problems netting more than 3200 requests for the free package during the three month campaign.

Yes, difficult and painful decisions had to be made on the areas in which money could be saved and, yes, children's programs are expensive because good children's radio and television require more care than do most programs for adults. But, given the concerns about the level of violence in society, it is inexcusable to reduce further the already small range of good television programs for children.

The cuts will cause particular hardship to children and teachers in isolated rural schools and those living in poorer areas. Country people for whom the programs have helped to compensate for a lack of resources in small schools have also found them useful in helping to alleviate their social and geographical isolation. If program cuts are essential the ABC board should look at the cutting of children's programs as the last, not the first, resort. The ending of these programs is a destructive decision which is made more ironic because it has happened in the International Year of Literacy and at a time when we are trying to be the clever country. I believe these comments are very worthwhile indeed and I have pleasure in supporting the report.

HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1990
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have circulated an amendment in my name, which is in three parts. In drafting these amendments and coming up with this set of words I hoped to create a situation whereby students would be able to indicate on their enrolment forms their desire, on any grounds, to choose whether to join any campus-based association and whereby it would be up to the institution or various associations within the institution to furnish information about their services and activities in order to encourage membership. A related amendment would ensure that the students are given full itemisation of the annual student services fee at the time of enrolment so that they knew what they were letting themselves in for. On that enrolment form students could elect whether or not to join any association. Students who chose not to join any association would not contribute to its funding and therefore would not subsidise activities of which they disapproved. Under this amendment, students would still pay the full student fee and this would go into a fund for services and amenities, but it would not be for the benefit of any association.

SPEECH.PARA: A further amendment to the proposed new section 107a would, instead of supporting the imposition and collection of fees for student organisations, actually prevent State interference in the imposition and collection of fees for the provision of student services and amenities as determined by the institution. There has been a considerable amount of input into this particular amendment, which is seeking to do those things which I described. During the process of drafting this amendment we were given information to the effect that it would be quite difficult to achieve our stated aims. Other information was given to the effect that no matter which way we drafted the amendment it would be very difficult to achieve those aims and that in fact the amendment would achieve different aims from the ones we had set out to achieve.

It has now reached the stage where the amendment which has been circulated in my name, because it would operate immediately, would create a situation whereby the institutions would not be able to comply with the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 if it was passed, because they would be unable to comply with the measures that we require in this amendment, that is, giving the enrolling students all of this information, because in fact universities are enrolling students now. I see that as a minor problem-perhaps an administrative one-which could be rectified. But other problems are associated with this matter as proposed in our amendment and, as disappointing as it may be for me, I propose to withdraw the amendment. I am attempting to make the point that this amendment is something which we hold very dear. The Australian Democrats want to be able to devise a scheme whereby students are able to choose whether of not they will join a political association on the campus. But it appears that we are not able to do it at this stage and I therefore withdraw the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bell, which amendment are you withdrawing?
—I am withdrawing parts 1, 2 and 3 of the amendment to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1990, which has been circulated in my name.
—Are you withdrawing all three?
—I think any senator who wishes to withdraw circulated amendments needs the agreement of the Senate to do so. I do not agree to the withdrawal of the amendments.
—I do, Mr Chairman.

—My understanding is that the amendments are not formally before the chamber because leave was not granted to move the three amendments together. If at the end of his contribution Senator Bell had wished to proceed I would have put to the chamber that he needed leave to move all three together, but all three have not been moved together so they are not formally before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Chairman, given your summary of these events and a ruling on the matter, on behalf of the Opposition I move the three amendments as circulated by Senator Bell:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 3, page 2, proposed paragraph 107a (1) (a), lines 5 and 6, omit ``that represents the interests generally of students at the institution'', substitute ``or body that provides services and amenities for students at the institution''.
2. Clause 3, page 2, after proposed subsection 107a (1), insert the following subsection:

(a) the institution permits students at the institution a choice as to whether they become or remain members of any club, society or other organisation associated with the institution; and

The Opposition sees this Australian Democrats' initiative as certainly superior to the unamended Bill. Earlier today, I indicated privately to Senator Bell that the Opposition would support his amendments. They will certainly enable students to make a clearer choice. We have argued all along that this Bill is intolerable to the Opposition because by coercion the Government is seeking to gain the Parliament's approval to deny choice to students. I could speak at some length, even 15 minutes, to give the kinds of reasons that I had supposed Senator Bell was putting forward in support of his amendments. I appeal to Senator Bell, Senator Powell-to the Democrats generally-not to be bluffed by this Government, but to stick to their guns and support an initiative that they have rightly taken.

I agree with Senator Bell's remarks on the practical consequence of enrolment requirements on education institutions in 1991. This is a practical procedure that can be sensibly worked out. The first amendment seeks a change in the definition with regard to students at an institution; that is, any body `that represents the interests generally of students at the institution' will be substituted by `or body that provides services and amenities for students at the institution'. That can be argued. No evidence has been brought before us that would deny that amendment. The Government has been applying some undue pressure upon the Democrats.

Quite frankly, I wish to record that the Opposition's position is to reject this Bill entirely. Our support for the Democrats' amendments is on the ground that they are much closer to our position of maximising choice for students than is the Bill unamended. Accordingly, I have moved the three amendments originally circulated in the name of the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot continue proper negotiations in the time available. Senator Teague may be able to pursue that. DEBATE.TITLE: BUILDERS LABOURERS' FEDERATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Builders Labourers' Federation Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 seeks to extend the deregistration of the Builders Labourers Federation. The Federation was deregistered by legislation five years ago in April 1986. That deregistration will expire in 1991. This Bill extends that deregistration for another five years from April 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not be opposing this proposal by the Government. The reasons for this measure are set out in the second reading speech and are notoriously well known throughout Australia. The Builders Labourers Federation at the Federal level has not met its obligations under the Industrial Relations Act 1988. It has in fact pursued a campaign of intimidation, thuggery and general disruption of the relations between employer and employee in the building and construction industry. Its record is such that it deserved to be deregistered many years ago-not as recently as 1986.

When we were in government, we commenced proceedings to effect deregistration of that union through the ordinary legal processes. We were frustrated in our efforts to achieve that result. It was on foot and still being pursued when the present Government was elected in February 1983. By that time, the Cain Government in Victoria had already been elected and had pulled the plug on that State's participation in the joint Federal and State effort to achieve deregistration through due process. When the Hawke Government was elected, it abandoned those proceedings.

A few years later we have the Government back in this House directly seeking this fast track method of deregistration by the Parliament. So there has been a complete turnaround. In fact, the Government turned around its attitude on this subject further than we would ever have expected it to by using the pretty draconian method of parliamentary deregistration rather than the proposal we were pursuing of deregistration through the due processes of the Act. Nevertheless, the Opposition did support and still supports such a procedure because it firmly believes in the result, namely, the deregistration of this rogue union.

We have some concerns about this piece of legislation. Firstly, its effect at the Federal and State level could well enhance the position of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia (BWIU), which has the major coverage now in the Federal area and is extending its role very strongly in the States. That union's industrial record is not a good one. It perhaps does not equal that of the Builders Labourers Federation, or the BLF, as it is better known. Nevertheless, its activities have resulted in a royal commission in New South Wales because of concerns about its power in that State. The BWIU is also seeking to extend its power in other States, particularly in Western Australia, where it has proceedings on foot to gain coverage. The legislation could stifle the ability of the Western Australian State-registered BLF to resist that intervention in Western Australia.

However, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has made some efforts to meet that situation. The Bill was amended in the other place to enable some delay in its effect. The Opposition welcomes that. I would like the Minister in his reply, if he has the time, to explain more fully exactly what he has in mind and what he hopes the result will be in Western Australia. It seems to us that the Western Australian BLF-the State registered body which has been permitted to continue; it is not affected by the deregistration of the Federal body-should have the right to put up a case to resist the attempt to take over its role in Western Australia.

I believe that the Minister is hoping some result will be achieved in respect of those proceedings. I would be particularly concerned to know what they are. However, the Opposition will not be opposing this Bill because of that, although we believe that those proceedings ought to be allowed to proceed. Although the legislation extends the right of a State-registered association to resist those sorts of proceedings in the future, ironically it does seem to prevent those that have already been commenced from continuing.

The Bill also widely extends the definition of non-registered associations, the members of which may have had a close association with the BLF in the past, may be having a close association with it now or may have a close association with it in the future. These provisions are no doubt necessary to stop a backdoor method of a majority of existing members of the BLF in the Federal area getting around the deregistration of the existing union. I appreciate that such associations are required. But I point out that the net has been cast very much wider than under the previous deregistration Act. It will be very much more difficult for any rival union to the BWIU to get registration at the Federal level.

Because of this legislation and the amalgamation legislation, it looks as though the BWIU is set to become a mega, monster union throughout Australia. That in itself has real problems as far as we in the Opposition are concerned. Those matters perhaps should be ones for another day and another debate, particularly in view of the short time available to me. With those comments, I indicate that the Opposition will support this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Durack has said that this legislation is somewhat draconian but that he will support it. It would be fair to say that he is not alone in being alarmed about the Builders Labourers' Federation Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. As with much of the legislation that goes through Parliament, it is a question of balance. He spoke about the activities of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia. I hope that was not a precursor to a suggestion that the same sort of penalties be imposed upon that union or any other union.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation should be seen as a very isolated piece of legislation. There is no doubt that there is a penalty imposed here. It is clear that it is a penalty to extend the period of deregistration for a union. As a matter of convention, the penalty should not be imposed without proper process. It is not simply a matter of a convention; it goes to the very heart of the way we see ourselves as a society. Penalties should not be imposed without there being due process.

There is a risk in imposing a penalty without some sort of process preceding it. That precedence will be set up and the fabric of the society in which we exist will be affected adversely in some way. The test of a humane, tolerant, decent and just society is not whether it deals with the beautiful and the young and the supposedly good according to the proper process but whether it does so with the ugly, the ageing and the supposedly bad. It is easy to be fair to those with whom we have empathy. It is much harder, and accordingly much more necessary, to be fair to those who stir no feelings of sympathy within us. The true test of any process and the true test of any society is how it deals with those people that the predominant balance of society says should be treated in a harsh manner, in an adverse way.

If we do not set up those proper processes there is a danger that a wrong can be done. Even in this case, where the evidence seems to be so overwhelming against the Builders Labourers Federation, one has only to read the judgment of Mr Justice Beach in the decision that he handed down in Melbourne on 15 November 1990. That was the case of Leighton Contractors Pty Ltd and Others v. John Sector and Others. In his judgment he said:

Pausing at this point, I should say that the dispute has been categorized in certain quarters as a dispute between Leightons and the Builders Labourers Federation (the BLF). Based upon the material before me, I do not accept that this is necessarily so. Members of a number of unions, including the BLF, are involved in the dispute. It seems to me that the dispute may well have been so categorized simply to lend colour to it and make it more notorious than it otherwise would be.

What I want to draw from that is that when we jump to conclusions, when we assume a situation lies a particular way on what seems to be overwhelming evidence, we should be concerned to ensure that there is some sort of process imposed between an initial reaction and a final judgment to ensure that that initial reaction is right.

What I am arguing here, and what I want to put on the record in the light of Senator Durack's statement, is that it is the position of the Government that as a matter of course it desires to see that a proper process is put in place and used before a penalty is imposed. It is a question of civil liberties, and civil liberties have a lot to do with process. Process seems to be a dry instrument at times. Our sessional orders, the orders of the Senate generally and the rules of the various courts, are there for one purpose, that is, to ensure that people get a fair go. The only way that can be done is to set up particular processes.
The Government, of course, will be supporting the Bill, but it does so conscious of the problems that exist in legislation such as this. It is not to be seen as a precedent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't it carry on and support the earlier proceedings?

—The Government's position is that the conclusions drawn from the earlier proceedings are still fresh. Those conclusions were drawn on evidence at that time. The Government sees those conclusions based on that evidence as being sufficiently fresh to justify the proceedings it has now taken. Senator Durack may dispute that. The point that we have to take from this particular Bill is that it must be isolated because it does contain some fearsome precedents.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not much time to devote to this Bill. I know that Senator McLean and others want to speak in the debate so I will finish my remarks at this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill we are debating now-the Builders Labourers' Federation Legislation Amendment Bill 1990-is an extraordinary Bill. This Bill will prohibit any application for registration by the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF) or any other non-registered association for an extra period of five years, until 14 April 1996. In other words, the Bill will exclude the Federation from the normal processes of application which we have devoted so much to formulating-the very processes that Senator Cooney has said are so important. This will take this particular application outside of that context and treat it separately. In that sense it is an extraordinary piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is extraordinary in other respects as well. It will expand the definition of `non-registered' to proscribe retrospectively to 14 April 1986 the entitlement of any State branch of the Federation or any other association constituted by the persons who would have been eligible for membership of the Federation prior to deregistration to apply for registration until 14 April 1996. In other words, it has a retrospective dimension to it as well. Over and over again the Senate stands, faces and addresses the principle of retrospectivity and says that legislation should not be retrospective. This legislation is extraordinary in the sense that it is.

The Australian Democrats will move amendments in the committee stage of this debate in an attempt to remove that retrospective aspect of the Bill. The amendments will be defeated by the combined vote of the Opposition and the Government. They will make this Bill retrospective. They will make this set of circumstances special, despite standing here for days, only a matter of a week and a half ago, and putting in place the very fair, just, adequate processes which Senator Cooney has identified as being so essential in a democracy. Now this Bill takes this case outside that set of fair, adequate, just processes.

The third thing the Bill does is provide the right to State registered branches of the Builders Labourers Federation, the builders labourers union, to intervene in the proceedings before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to seek use of the Commission's powers under section 111 (1) (g) (ii) and (iii) of the Industrial Relations Act and to make objection to the applications part of part IX of the Industrial Relations Act to be heard in relation to that objection. In other words, it cuts across; it uses special powers to create a special lever on applications by one of the State branches of this organisation.

I need to cite the extraordinary double standards that are being brought before the Senate here today in this set of circumstances. Last week we stood here and argued at length about the needs of small organisations to receive just procedure. Here today, during the debate on a matter of urgency which focused on the plight of small organisations, the Opposition argued vigorously that we must acknowledge the requirements of small organisations, although it will not allow them to be taken off to an umpire to make judgments. The Government, on the other hand, has attempted to put in place, with our help, the Industrial Relations Commission, which was strong, fair, able to deliver and able to make decisions on behalf of the community at large. But in this set of circumstances we have decided to take this small organisation and judge it separately and we have decided that the Parliament will make the judgment here and now in a special Bill. We cite that as being an extraordinary double standard and a contradiction of the logic and the principles that we attempted to establish in principal Bills here less than two weeks ago.

The Bill seeks to operate to remove the rights of the registered State branches of the Federation in respect of any procedures before the Industrial Relations Commission that were commenced before this Bill will receive royal assent. The Western Australian branch of the Builders Labourers Federation was described by Mr Howard to me as one of the more reasonable branches. In other words, there was an acknowledgment of the fact that builders labourers right across Australia should not be thrown in the Gallagher bucket and basket, that there are members within the Federation which are capable of behaving responsibly. I think even the Federation itself acknowledges that it has that diversity within itself. One of the branches has procedures before a Federal court in the form of an application to register. Those procedures will be cut across retrospectively and the Federation will be denied due process.

We will be attempting in our amendments to remove the retrospective dimension of the Bill, but I would anticipate that those amendments will be defeated, as I say, by a combined vote of Opposition and Government. It is an extraordinary contradiction when we think back to the debate, and the vitriol of the debate, concerning the principles in industrial relations which we have debated here today and to the intensity and the division between the camps when we were debating the use of a fair, just process to resolve questions of registration and non-registration.

We are not in any way endorsing the behaviour of BLF branches anywhere. The Industrial Relations Commission would have made that judgment not so long from now if we had given it the power, the authority and the confidence to do so-if we had allowed it to exercise the very power, authority and confidence that we extended to it through the legislation a mere few days ago. I know for a fact that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and the Government are embarrassed by this contradiction. I am not too sure that the Opposition is embarrassed by it, but I know there is a great deal of embarrassment about this obvious contradiction. It is important that the Australian people are aware of the fact that these contradictions do and can exist in this place and, above all, that they are aware of the fact that we are the ones who are attempting to resolve and to refute these contradictory processes.

It would appear that this Parliament-in other words, a combination of the Government and the Opposition in this Parliament and certainly not the Democrats-rather than the Industrial Relations Commission will play the prominent role in deciding who enjoys what rights and at what time in relation to registration. That is the effect of this Bill.

Senator Cooney used the expressions `some alarm' and `a question of balance'. There are also questions of principle. There is indeed a need for alarm. Just yesterday the Minister appealed to the Opposition to allow the SPC Ltd case, which we were discussing earlier, to go to the umpire. `Let it go to the umpire', said the Minister. That is what the umpire is there for. Today the Minister spoke about the need for the umpire and pleaded with the Opposition to acknowledge that principle of the umpire making decisions, whether there is thuggery, whether there is irresponsibility or whether we have a group of people seeking to register a union that should not be entrusted with that utterly important responsibility. It is the job of the Industrial Relations Commission to arrive at that decision.

In respect of the agreement that was arrived at earlier about how much time was available to me, it was agreed that I had nine minutes. I have used my nine minutes. I am citing this incredible contradiction. I am appealing to the Opposition to support the Democrats in their amendments, which will at least remove the retrospectivity clauses of this legislation and allow at least one branch, which has an application before the Federal Court, to have that heard. It is the least we can do. We regard this Bill as being a travesty in terms of the principles which it does not adhere to and we dissociate ourselves from any behaviour of the Builders Labourers Federation anywhere. That is not the point. We profoundly dissociate ourselves from the fundamental contradiction which is taking place here now and with the retrospective dimensions of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Opposition does not oppose the Builders Labourers' Federation Legislation Amendment Bill, the main purpose of which is to deregister the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF) for a further five years and thereby in effect prevent the union from seeking re-registration until 1996, there are nevertheless good reasons for concern about aspects of the legislation. One area of concern is that the Bill goes further than that and seeks to preclude the remaining registered State branches of the BLF-and, indeed, any group of builders labourers-from applying for Federal registration.

SPEECH.PARA: That concern is warranted, even though no organisation in Australia's trade union history has, I believe, ever matched the Builders Labourers Federation in ignominy, notoriety or just plain thuggery. This union has been a rogue union. It has had a bunch of scoundrels-quite accurately described as hoodlums-at its helm. It has had a sad history of violence and thuggery and as a union has been dominated by its Federal Secretary, Norm Gallagher, who is in charge of its Federal management committee.

The BLF has been federally deregistered twice-once in 1974 and again in 1986. The union re-registered in 1976 and when the Australian Labor Party won Government in 1983 the new Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, withdrew deregistration proceedings against the BLF which Prime Minister Fraser had begun the previous year. However, the activities of the BLF were too much even for the self-proclaimed world's greatest Prime Minister because subsequently this Labor Government deregistered it again in 1986, and prohibited any application for re-registration for a further five years; that is, until 14 April next year.

While this legislation to further extend the deregistration must pass, its consequences offer no real joy for Australia's industrial relations. The outcome from extending the deregistration of the BLF will be such that the Building Workers Industrial Union (BWIU) and the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors will be the winners. This unholy alliance will benefit no-one except these two organisations and both will continue to combine to extract monopoly rents from developers through the subcontractors and the tradesmen who work under the `no ticket, no start' regime unique to the construction industry.

In the absence of Government action to break that cartel-indeed, it is reinforced by the Government's mania for union amalgamations-there is little hope for a more cost efficient industry to develop. It is certain in the history of trade unionism in this country that no union has been more irresponsible in its behaviour than the union formerly registered under the Federal Act as the Builders Labourers Federation. It has certainly brought much discredit upon itself through its efforts to bring the construction industry in Australia to its knees on numerous occasions through the use of vile and often violent tactics on individuals, property and organisations throughout Australia. It is worth recognising again that a previous Liberal Government originally sought to deregister this organisation, whereas the new Prime Minister in 1983 and the former Premier of Victoria, John Cain, acted to delay deregistration proceedings against them.

Now, years later, it falls to this Labor Government to extend the deregulation which it felt compelled to initiate in 1986. The BLF is but one of a number of union organisations which need to be taken completely apart and thoroughly cleansed. In that regard it is matched by the Building Workers Industrial Union, which has more or less taken over where the BLF left off and has possibly a worse track record than its predecessor, the BLF.

The Royal Commission into Productivity in the Building Industry in New South Wales, appointed by Premier Greiner, is long overdue and should very closely investigate the disgraceful tactics used by the BWIU and others within the construction industry. Although this Bill does extend the deregistration of the BLF, and therefore achieves some benefit to the construction industry, it also unwittingly supports the continued existence of the BWIU, a huge, powerful and unwieldy union that is strongly opposed to the Opposition's industrial relations policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a crime?

—It is not a crime but it is certainly an unwise approach and is detrimental to Australia's economic development. To oppose this Bill would be to support Norm Gallagher and all that he represents and would certainly ensure a resurgence of disruption and militancy throughout the construction industry, which was evident when the BLF was in full cry. We want to avoid that, obviously, in terms of establishing a rational approach to industrial relations; in particular, we want to avoid outbursts of violent behaviour by unionists and try to achieve a reasonable approach to industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians are most definitely sick and tired of hearing about another picket, another round of thuggery and further bouts of violence in the sphere of industrial relations. This Government talks about enterprise bargaining, as does the Australian Council of Trade Unions, but it is only this Opposition which is fair dinkum about the introduction of enterprise bargaining.
