This legislation, in allowing the BWIU to continue in place of the BLF, really does nothing to develop a more rational and enterprise-based approach to industrial relations because it allows the industrial relations structure to head in the opposite direction in the establishment of mega-unions. Undoubtedly the BWIU will become one of the 20 mega-unions.

This union will not confine itself to the construction area but will encompass membership within the mining and engineering industries as well. It is quite absurd when one considers that one union will represent these three major industries. There will be no hope for achieving a cost competitive resource or building development industry in Australia in that situation; there will be no hope for bargaining based on enterprise. The real winners of this legislation will be the Building Workers Industrial Union. The only way to attack the rotten core of the construction industry, before it takes over other areas, is to end the monopoly on the supply of labour held by the unions in the building industry, and that means abandoning compulsory unionism.

The aspect of the Bill which is of particular concern is the measure of retrospectivity. Any proceedings before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission commenced before the Bill receives royal assent will come under the operation of the Bill. This will no doubt affect the Western Australian branch of the BLF, an organisation which has a better reputation than its currently deregistered Federal namesake. That State branch is currently seeking to secure Federal registration under this Bill, and those procedures will be completely destroyed.

Although this legislation will go some way towards addressing the problems which plague the construction industry, it does have the disadvantage of strengthening the hand of the Building Workers Industrial Union in the construction industry and extending its power into mining and development projects. It has the disadvantage that it will, in effect, neuter State branches of the BLF, which are more responsible than their Federal counterpart. It total, it reflects the Government's inadequate approach to industrial relations, the real reform of which must await the election of a coalition government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I congratulate Senator Cooney on his fine exposition on the balance of principle that is required when considering legislation such as this. Personally, I share his very great concerns of principle and the need to have regard for the legitimate rights of individual trade unionists and unions in this country. I sincerely hope that this sort of legislation is never needed to be produced again for any trade union in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I reject a number of comments made by honourable senators opposite. I think it is wrong to totally condemn as hoodlums, using thuggery and violence, members of the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF) the way the Opposition has. I speak from personal experience and knowledge of the BLF in my own State of Tasmania. I was President of the Trades and Labour Council in that State for some time. I am pleased to say that the State Secretary of the BLF in that State, Mr Jim Bacon, was a unionist who commanded very deep respect, not only amongst the trade union movement in my home State but also amongst employers--

TALK.START.PARA: —And in Western Australia.

— In Western Australia, Queensland and South Australia, too, I understand. I am glad to see that this legislation makes it very clear that the State registration of the Builders Labourers Federation is to continue in those four States. Indeed, in my State of Tasmania, that development was recognised last year when the State Secretary of the Builders Labourers Federation, Jim Bacon, was elected as Secretary of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council. That was welcomed not only by trade unions but also by employers and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in that State. The officials of the Builders Labourers Federation in my home State, Bobby Devine and Jack Gill, are well known for their dedication and commitment to the rights of workers. I certainly reject the inferences and sweeping generalisations that are made by honourable members opposite about hoodlums, violence and thuggery, because that is not the approach of those officials to industrial relations in my home State; as, indeed, it is not the approach of the overwhelming majority of officials in this organisation or their rank and file members around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also glad to see a positive provision in the legislation that allows the registered branches of the Builders Labourers Federation in the four States, by leave of the Commission, to appear before the Commission in respect of legitimate industrial matters. The building industry is notorious for its exploitative employment characteristics. The industry is seasonal with a poor safety record and has subcontracting on subcontracting. There is a need for a strong union in the building industry. I reject again the sweeping calls by senators opposite for the smashing of the Australian trade union movement and its breaking down into enterprise trade unions. In conclusion, the Builders Labourers Federation has a slogan, `Dare to struggle. Dare to win', and it is with great regret that I say-although I do not mean it in any offensive way-that it has dared to die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that several of the speakers in this debate on the Builders Labourers' Federation Legislation Amendment Bill have limited their remarks because of the time constraints. I also acknowledge that some of them would have said more in greater detail than they have. I will be brief in reply, answering directly the points that they have raised. I want to answer, though, as comprehensively as I can and start with the contributions of my colleagues, Senators Cooney and Sherry. I am sure that Senator Sherry, who was a union official, will forgive me if I emphasise in my remarks the comments made by Senator Cooney, who as a barrister and solicitor worked and practised for some time at the industrial Bar in Melbourne and nationally and speaks with some legal as well as industrial relations experience on this point. I note his remarks particularly about fairness and the proper process. I acknowledge-and I think it is appropriate that I do so-his remarks as an expression of conscience and of views strongly felt. However, I do not deny the strength of conscience and view of Senator Sherry, who similarly has a long and quite respected history in the Australian union movement. Those views therefore have to be taken into consideration when they have observed the Caucus solidarity necessary in a vote such as this.

SPEECH.PARA: I now concentrate on a few of the points made by Senator Durack. He asked me to reply specifically only to one point, and that was the ability of the Government, given the amendment to our original Bill that Mr Willis put through the House of Representatives, to proclaim at a later time, if we so choose, that section relating to the applications for registration by State registered branches of the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF) to become a Federal union.

The best and clearest way I can explain the position of the Government is to say that, in essence, I behold three separate personalities which are referred to as the Builders Labourers Federation. The first is the Builders Labourers Federation as an organisation which is unregistered but exists nonetheless as a proper organisation. It is registered in one sense under the New South Wales trade union Act in that State, but it exists irrespective of whether it is registered in the Federal industrial relations system. Nothing in this Bill can touch that.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the dinner break I was answering a question put to me by Senator Durack in his contribution to the second reading debate. I had noted the three personalities that the organisation known colloquially as the BLF has. The first is the organisation itself. The second is the Federal Builders Labourers Federation as such, which was a federally registered organisation with State branches. This legislation is aimed at that organisation. The third personality is the builders labourers federations in each State, which are registered under the State jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation, by its enactment, complements legislation in New South Wales and Victoria, meaning that effectively the organisation does not possess registration at either Federal or State level in those two States and does not possess registration at Federal level in any state of Australia, leaving therefore the organisation in existence unregistered and the State registered organisations in Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania.

In this Bill we provide that the State registered BLFs, registered under their State law, cannot apply for Federal registration. We have done that because we believe that there is sufficient cause to worry that, if they were to do that and succeed, it would be a back door method for the Builders Labourers Federation-the organisation led by Norm Gallagher that we are proposing to deal with under this legislation-to re-emerge. However, by virtue of this legislation we are providing that, where their interest is affected in any Federal proceeding, they have the right ordinarily to appear in that Federal proceeding to protect their State interest.

The point of contention that has arisen is that there is an application by the Builders Labourers Federation of Western Australia for Federal registration. That application is being heard in the Federal Commission. It is being heard concurrently with an application by the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia (BWIU) to extend its constitution to cover classifications of `builder's labourer' in the other States. We are proposing in our amendment not to proclaim that section of our legislation which would wipe out that legal action. As I comprehended Senator Durack's question, he asked why we were doing that or he wanted me to provide more background as to why we were doing that. At the moment, talks have been actively--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the order agreed to on 13 December 1990, the time for consideration of this Bill has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: (Extension of time granted)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will bring my remarks to a swift conclusion. I, in my capacity as Federal Minister, have stimulated talks between the BLF in the States-that is, representatives of the Queensland, South Australian, Western Australian and Tasmanian builders labourers federations-and the BWIU and the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia.

SPEECH.PARA: Those talks are being actively followed at the present time, and in the circumstances I think it is appropriate that we not proclaim that section of the legislation. If we believe or apprehend the strong possibility of a threat by the back door to take the application that is being heard by the Western Australian Builders Labourers Federation for Federal registration-if we apprehend an effort to re-establish the Builders Labourers Federation, the organisation we are dealing with in this legislation, by that means-obviously that would be a situation in which I would consider the application of proclamation. I must say that there is no immediate threat of that possibility as we operate now, although it is prudent to clothe ourselves with a power in the event that it might arise to enable it to be exercised should it be necessary.

There is also a second reason. There is a possibility of a negotiated outcome between the organisations I have referred to. Although in recent times that possibility is a little reduced from what it might have been a couple of weeks ago, it is still sufficiently alive for the Government to want conscientiously to explore that possibility. That possibility offers an amic- able and negotiated outcome to the legal conflicts between the BLF and the Building Workers Industrial Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the cover issue, is it?
—This is the issue of the BLF of Western Australia, which has applied for registration as a Federal union.
—What about the other issue?
—The other issue riding with that is the cross application by the BWIU to obtain State coverage. If there is a negotiated outcome it will resolve both issues.
—Have you linked them together?

—I think that in this process they are now inextricably bound up. The other point that I should make is that an application is being heard in the Industrial Relations Commission. Senator Durack has made this point about his concern regarding retrospective application in a case such as that. We too are sensitive about it. We therefore want to have the provision, but in a way in which, if the negotiating and legal dynamics deteriorate and there is a real need for us to have the power, we should be able to proceed. It is for those reasons that the amendment to provide for, if necessary, a later proclamation date on that element of this legislation has been included.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 2, pages 1 and 2, line 8 (page 1) to line 9 (page 2), omit the clause.
2. Clause 3, pages 2 and 3, line 10 (page 2) to line 22 (page 3), omit the clause.
3. Clause 4, page 3, paragraph (1) (a) and (1) (b), lines 25 to 40, omit the paragraphs.
4. Clause 4, page 4, subclause (2), lines 5 to 7, omit the subclause.
5. Clause 6, page 4, lines 11 to 15, omit the clause.
I indicated earlier that the Australian Democrats have sought the cooperation of the Opposition in moving these amendments.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the order agreed to on 13 December 1990, the time for consideration of this Bill has expired. I shall now put the question that the amendments moved by Senator McLean be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: THE ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chairman of Committees reports that the Committee has considered the Builders Labourers' Federation Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and agreed to it. The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to and the Bill be now passed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: DATA-MATCHING PROGRAM (ASSISTANCE AND TAX) BILL 1990SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, 26 November and 6 December, on motions by Senator Richardson and Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a package of Bills-the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2)-which have taken a long time to get to the chamber but which in many ways present a very valuable opportunity for the Senate to canvass some very important issues in the field of social security.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1990 Budget starkly underlines the fundamental differences between the approach to social security that now distinguish the major political parties in Australia. This Government sees welfare as a passive response to economic and social disadvantage, in many instances providing virtually permanent income support for many relatively able-bodied citizens.

This can be seen from the $2.7 billion increase in social security spending for the current financial year, taking the total outlays to $23.7 billion, which is in many respects simply topping-up in various categories. For example, there is a $900m or an 11 per cent rise in age pension payouts; and a $1 billion or a 31.8 per cent rise in unemployment benefit-a figure which is probably fast becoming irrelevant. The extra almost $1 billion in age pensions enables the Government finally to limp across the line in achieving its long-awaited target of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

Even this massive outlay masks the failure of the Government to come to grips with the ageing of the population. Despite forgoing revenue of $4.3 billion last year on superannuation tax concessions, we still have 1.3 million persons-or 77 per cent of those of age pension age-wholly or partly dependent upon the age pension. We still have very serious poverty traps in place. The income test free threshold at which pensions begin to be reduced will finally be indexed in line with the consumer price index from July 1991-a belated and in many respects token response.

Professor Cass's recommendation was that the income test be 15 per cent of average weekly earnings, which would now equate to $74.65 per week. Mr Howe's proposal to index the present low base of $40 per week from July 1991 has been described by a range of interest groups-particularly one that came recently to my mind, the Western Australian Public Service Retired Officers Association-as tokenism at its most insulting. They refer to Mr Howe's statement in the Better Opportunities-Social Security booklet that in 1988 the average amount of non-pension income was $42 per week. This makes a mockery of the Government's rhetoric about enhanced opportunities for self-help, when the current system takes no account of the declining value of money.

The balance of the budget consists of other big ticket items such as assistance to unemployment and sickness beneficiaries, up by $1 billion; assistance to the disabled, up by $35m; and assistance to families with children, up by $311m. The amount currently spent on sole parents-which is more than $2.5 billion-is more than is spent on family allowances, yet the enhancement of the jobs, education and training (JET) scheme will cost $2.2m, to be spent mainly on bureaucrats, in order to save something in the order of $0.5m in revenue. In other words, virtually nothing is being done in order to encourage sole parents to get back into the work force. So far, less than 5 per cent of sole parents have voluntarily participated in the JET program, and of these only about 50 per cent have been within the Government's own categorisation of labour market disadvantaged.

The current Bills, replete as they are with more targeting such as the deeming of gifts, loans and cash, the imposition of a liquid assets test, the introduction of an assets test on family allowance, the amnesty and, above all, the data matching and tax file number regimes, constitute the high-water mark of this Government's boa constrictor approach to welfare. It is a series of penny-pinching initiatives.

Although in many instances the Bills are quite rightly designed to reduce the potential for abuse, correct administrative inconsistencies and maximise pensioner returns, they wholly fail to come to grips with the need to provide substantial incentives to wean people away from welfare, provide meaningful workplace alternatives and provide practical advice to pensioners. In these respects they are sadly lacking.
The tragedy is the lack of serious intent. For example, consider the remarks of the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, on the Sunday program on 14 October last. He said:
I think it would be very difficult for us to try and upgrade training for the unemployed . . . I am not certain there is room in the system for more expansion even if you could find the money.

The Minister for Social Security there shows a total failure to understand the consequences of labour market inflexibility, which makes it so difficult for unemployment beneficiaries, invalid pensioners and sole parent beneficiaries to get back into the work force. Look at all the anguish, heartburn and back-tracking over deeming, to save a miserable $8.7m this year-now $7.6m, due to the latest Richardson back-down-part of which is squandered by way of a Public Service Union trade-off with the appointment of 40 more totally unnecessary, barely trained financial information service for pensioners advisers at a cost of $1m.

The greatest single antidote to poverty is a burgeoning economy and plentiful employment opportunities. Of the Government's much vaunted 1.6 million jobs since 1983, only about half have been full time. The figure has served to distract attention from the fact that unemployment has been stuck at more than 6 per cent throughout the term of the Hawke Government. Now, even that relatively positive indicator has been thrown out of the window by the Government's scorched earth strategy. This is the state to which that consummate political artist, Paul Keating, has brought us: prime bank rates of over 20 per cent; an annual current account deficit of $21 billion for the last financial year; $157 billion in gross foreign debt; and swelling dole queue numbers which in Victoria, for example, have risen by more than 72 per cent over the last year.

These are the efforts of a shonky used car salesman who refuses to see that the wheels have fallen off and persists in trying to flog a very sour and soggy lemon to increasingly irate consumers. The fact is that the recession which we had to have would have been quite unnecessary if Mr Keating had had the vision and political will to champion micro-economic reform, labour market flexibility and real privatisation. It is little wonder that Australia is the object of ridicule and condescension amongst many of our South East Asian neighbours. Ask Harry Lee about our national backbone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you mention expenditure cuts?

—Presumably, the Government will take our advice and deliver them in the new year but it has done nothing to date. Rather than running around making fatuous self-comparisons with Placido Domingo, the great recession engineer might be better off accepting that to the victims of economic collapse and rocketing unemployment he is little more than a poor man's Sid Vicious presiding over a punk economy. Instead of being tempted to read T.S. Eliot's Whispers of Immortality he would be better off surveying the wasteland; and I trust that that reference is not lost on the Acting Deputy President, at least.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has simply been too gutless to make real reforms and has been content to hide behind the blunt instrument of monetary policy. This has had the presumably unintended consequence of promoting a massive redistribution of wealth from the battlers to the rich. So much for social justice! The major effect of the hand of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) being stuck on the monetary lever has been to slow private capital investment to a trickle because of the impossibility of profit making based on rates of interest double, and sometimes treble, those of our major trading partners. The Government's favourite weapon for tackling poverty seems to be bagging archbishops. It is noticeable that the putative leader did not speak up at that time and showed not the slightest interest in welfare or welfare reform, as even Senator Richardson conceded in Question Time the other day. In fact, we have heard absolutely nothing from him on welfare. The man who despises shopping malls where most ordinary mortals have to buy the necessities of life blithely spends $5,000 on a VIP flight to watch a game of football played by a team about which he knows nothing and cares less. He is simply an opportunistic carpetbagger bitterly resented by hordes of long-suffering Collingwood supporters, including myself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this a recycled speech?
—It is not. This is brand new and highly relevant.
—Order! Senator Alston, please address your remarks through the Chair.

—Indeed, where was the putative leader on the issue of telecommunications reform? The answer is he was standing in the shadows whilst his minions backgrounded the press and leaked the Beazley Cabinet submission to the Australian Financial Review.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, let us look at the token, leisurely and irrelevant gestures made by this Government in two critical social security areas-unemployment and dis- ability. The invalid pension will be replaced from 1 October 1991-how slow can you go?-by the disability support pension requiring a minimum 20 per cent level of medical impairment which, as Senator Richardson so graphically conceded in Question Time not so long ago, even he does not understand, and an assessed inability to work full time. This is presumably the outcome of grovelling to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It will mean that an ability to work part time will simply be ignored and the disability payments will become a proxy for unemployment benefits. This heroic measure will save $14.7m in 1991-92 and will not even operate in this financial year. Why? According to Senator Richardson it is because these things take time. The Government has only had seven years to come up with this strategy. Perhaps another reason why savings will be so low is that in the first year of operation of the disability support pension only 2 per cent of existing invalid pensioners will be reviewed. So much for the active employment strategy.

The sickness benefit will become the sickness allowance, initially limited to 12 months but capable of extension for a further 12-month period. About the only change seems to be that there will be an early referral to rehabilitation. Otherwise, there would seem to be precious little review of current recipients to attempt to understand why numbers have risen by over 35 per cent since Labor came to office-well in excess of the population growth rate of something in excess of 10 per cent. Since 1970 the number of people on sickness benefit has actually risen by over 811 per cent. Unemployment benefits will be replaced from 1 July 1991-again I ask why the hurry-by the Jobsearch and Newstart allowance. How this renaming can save $79.4m in the current financial year is therefore beyond me. In other words, the whole scheme is irrelevant. It has been blown out of the water by the current massive deterioration in the labour force. The Budget estimate looks very sick indeed. The figure of 475,000 by June 1991 has already been overtaken by the latest figures showing that some 498,000 people are in the dole queue and almost 700,000 people are out of work. Given that the Budget estimates rise by approximately $80m for every 10,000 additional unemployed, any savings at all that might derive from the shuffling of the welfare pack will be completely drowned by the increase in new numbers.

The initiatives that have been announced constituted by the three Bills that we are currently debating also deal with another notorious example of thinking after the event. The family allowance proposal, hastily conceived without any adequate data available at the time, without any proper consultation-it was drawn up, as Senator Richardson has said, before the extent of the rural crisis became apparent-was finally amended by the Government in line with the general views of the National Farmers Federation. Around 80,000 families would have been affected by the proposal, when 86 per cent of farmers already have assets in excess of $300,000. That initiative was not mentioned prior to the election, as is the case with many of the Government's proposals. It would seem that it was simply trotted out in the Budget without any proper consultation or analysis. We had the ludicrous spectacle of Senator Richardson telling the Australian last weekend that the Government went to the National Farmers Federation. He said that the Government would help the Federation any way it could, offered to get some statistics and basically advised it on how to reshape its request. If ever there was a ludicrous--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read Inside Canberra yet?
—No, I have not.
—It is very good.

—I must have a look at it. At the moment, I confess that I am stuck with the national dailies. The Australian gave me the most amusement because it made it patently clear that in the time that this Minister has been in charge of social security, or ought to have been in charge, there have been a whole range of backdowns and backflips. For example, there was a lot of big talk on restricting the payments of overseas pensions. We ultimately saw savings forgone of something like $52.5m over a three-year period. Then there was the backdown on the $2.50 charge for pensioner prescriptions where an additional $50 was given to pensioners up-front to help them with extra payments. According to the Minister, none of this was apparently foreseen or predicted, but according to Messrs Howe and Staples, the issue was explicitly canvassed in the Expenditure Review Committee and rejected. They made their concerns known to the public by way of the leaking of a letter of advice.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a watering down of the original assets test of the family allowance proposal, with savings forgone of $24m; a backdown on tighter assets testing of family allowance supplements and Austudy, which cost another $58m over two years; a watering down of the original 10 per cent deeming proposal, with savings forgone of $7.6m. On the original liquid assets test proposal, there were savings forgone of $5m to $10m. That was another decision bitterly opposed by Minister Howe. In total, the current Minister's backdowns have cost the Government approximately $150m.

There is not much doubt that we have seen a new approach to government which basically involves, whenever there is a whiff of grapeshot, diving for the trenches, caving in to any interest group that might potentially have a vote up its sleeve. There is no regard at all to protecting the integrity of the Budget.

I conclude on an issue which my colleague Senator Patterson will no doubt be developing at some length. It relates to the reasons why we have felt it so necessary to ensure, in relation to the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill, that we protect two fundamental rights: the right of the public to privacy protection, an issue that has been totally ignored by the Government and which has been most unwillingly foisted upon it; we are also very anxious to ensure that the Parliament retains control of the process, and that is why we will be intro- ducing a sunset clause.

The most obvious reason why there has been so much concern about the privacy implications is, I suppose, the sort of appallingly cynical admission of guilt made by Senator Richardson and the deafening silence of the Treasurer, which confirmed the original suspicions that promises about confining the tax file number to the tax system were simply jettisoned through political expediency-designed no doubt at the time to lull the community into a false sense of security. But it is now clear that the Government always intended what it is now proposing.

I will not go into any detail about the notorious admissions made by the Minister for Social Security in the Sydney Morning Herald. Suffice it to say that the quote `few things are immutable' speaks for itself. The Minister says the reality is that every time a change of policy is announced in a Budget one goes back on something said before and that every Budget from every government contains changes. If that is not the Watergate defence recycled, I do not know what is. Inoperative statements apparently can be simply discarded whenever it suits him. That is precisely the reason why we are so concerned about privacy implications and why I think it has been necessary to have taken the trouble and effort that we have. I congratulate Senator Patterson in particular for the assiduous nature with which she has pursued a number of these very important aspects. I will have more to say on the details of these Bills during the committee stage. Suffice it to say that these Bills represent merely a pale imitation of what a real welfare policy ought to be about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin tonight by looking at some of the positive features in the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), including employment entry payments which have been extended to recipients of sole parents' pension; the introduction of the fixed set disaster relief payments; the extension of the remote area allowance to people living in special zone B, as defined under the Income Tax Assessment Act-and I add that this is something for which the Australian Democrats have been calling for some time-extension of the carers' pension to include carers who live adjacent to those that they are looking after, which again is a long overdue measure; the quarantining of the recently introduced pharmaceutical supplement from the social security payments themselves. In fact, this was an amendment that the Australian Democrats moved, but which was negated, at the committee stage of previous legislation. We are very pleased to see that the Government has taken that on board at this point.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to address first the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, which is a very tough piece of legislation. It contains some extremely tough measures that expose the Government's rhetoric about its commitment to the more disadvantaged constituents. It is yet another example of the Government's willingness to make the unemployed, the sick, the aged and the rural poor bear the brunt of what is now a very costly flirtation with so-called economic rationalism. The headlines we have all seen in the papers in the last few days read: `Unemployment expected to increase again'; `Unemployment rising'; `Unemployment hits three-year high'; `Dole figures rocketing'; and `Jobless may rise to 10 per cent'. That headline referred to something said by Senator Walsh.

Last week we saw some 6,933 more persons added to the dole queues, some 4,500 the week before and nearly 6,500 the week before that. The Government's estimate has been well and truly exceeded. Half the companies in Australia have retrenched or reduced some staff this year. The Westpac Banking Corporation alone has decreased its staff by some 1,500. At the same time, we see in this climate that the importation of chocolates has risen some 139 per cent and that the importation of caviar is up 25 per cent. So some people in this country are certainly doing very nicely. This legislation does not attack these people but is causing much of the hardship.

I just pause briefly to look at the changes that have already been made both to this legislation and other pieces of social security legislation that we have seen this year. Time and time again, there are softening measures and small adjustments, and it is very pleasing that the Government is listening to reasoned argument put forward in particular by the lobby groups. However, we have to keep asking ourselves why it is that the Government legislation needs these changes. Is it because the Government is not consulting with or listening to those people in the community who are hurting the most? I think we must conclude that the social security policy is being designed by economic rationalists who do not know or care what their policies are doing to people.

The Government will not get its policies right first go until it begins listening to the community. It needs to ensure that the people who are dealing with the portfolio have some empathy with those in the community that the Department of Social Security is supposed to be assisting. But let us be clear: there is no need for some of these draconian, very cruel, measures in the first place. The community is not fooled: it knows that it is bearing the brunt of bad economic decisions and the failure of this Government to curb corporate excesses of the very worst kind. The community is suffering because it knows that this Government and the Opposition prefer to give benefits and concessions to the wealthy rather than make necessary concessions and changes which will benefit the community as a whole.

The other option-and I guess a rather cynical one-is that perhaps these mistakes are deliberate and we are really to end up with what the Government wanted all along: `Make the policies tougher and tougher and then give back a little bit to create the impression that we are really not bad guys after all and are listening to the pressure groups'. One hopes that that is not the scenario, but one does begin to wonder.

I would now like to deal as quickly as I can with the various clauses of the Bill to which I will move amendments as we proceed through the committee stage. Firstly, in respect of deeming on cash in accounts: this issue has caused enormous concern among pensioners and has already been dealt with extensively in committee. We have had numerous letters from anxious pensioners who are fearful of the consequences of these moves and those who are angry that the Government has taken action in this fashion against them while failing to close tax loopholes.

Let us be clear about this measure. It is essentially discriminatory as it will apply only to certain assets held by certain groups in the community. It is well established that the loss to the community in taxation revenue from taxpayers not using their assets to best advantage is significantly larger than the additional social security pay-outs to pensioners and beneficiaries who are mistakenly investing their assets at low or minimal rates of return. I believe pensioners are entitled to ask why the Government does not deem a minimum rate on return of all assets owned by pensioners, beneficiaries and taxpayers. Why indeed? Could it be that the Government thinks pensioners are easier targets than wage and salary earners, executives, company directors or whatever, who will perhaps kick up more of a fuss and are able to be more organised than pensioner lobby groups?

The Democrats have some sympathy with the Government's aims. There is a long history of pensioners' savings being used to the financial advantage of banks. It is also true that if many pensioners are able to get the right advice and have access to the right information, they will be better off, but there are a number of problems in relation to those who are poorly advised, less well off, frail, disabled or simply not able to cope with the great difficulty of arranging or rearranging their affairs at a stage in their lives when they thought they had everything already organised.

The Government, despite its rhetoric, is not prepared to take on the banks to ensure that they do not misuse their position in relation to their pensioner customers. Pensioners are a rather blunt instrument with which to try to encourage the banks to get some re-regulation. Some products are already coming onto the market which still treat the first $2,000 as in effect a free loan to the banks and provide the 10 per cent on anything above that figure. We believe that is grossly unfair and goes against the Government's intentions.

We also note a considerable lack of independent financial funding advice. There are simply not enough services extended to people for independent advice about how to make best use of their available funds. In effect-and this has been put to us by a number of pensioner groups-this measure targets the poorer and the more frail pensioners because they are the very people who cannot access advice and are already using strategies both to reduce tax and to minimise their pension entitlements.

I will not move these amendments tonight, but the Democrats attempted to amend the legislation to reduce the interest rate from 10 per cent to 8 per cent or, preferably, 7 per cent. Interest rates have fallen again today and we believe that by the time this legislation is enacted next March the Government will have to come to the understanding that it simply will not be possible for the majority of-certainly not for all-pensioners and beneficiaries to get the 10 per cent at call. As I said, we moved the amendments at the committee stage, but they were negated by a combined vote of the Government and the Opposition.

We are also concerned with the level at which the threshold is set. If the interest rate is to remain at 10 per cent, it will be extremely difficult for pensioners and beneficiaries to get that rate of interest unless they begin tying up their money. The Democrats believe having only $2,000 at call is unsatisfactory. Pensioners have pointed out to us that they need to keep reasonable funds available to cover emergency situations and to make them feel economically viable.

I note with pleasure that a mistake was apparently made at the time the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill were redrafted to take on board some amendments that were made in the House of Representatives. These mistakes mean that married couples will now be treated as individuals in their own right. I believe that this is particularly important for women. Normally, one would not be pleased when government drafts- people make errors, but on this occasion I wish to congratulate them most sincerely on behalf of all married pensioners and beneficiaries.

The Australian Democrats had indeed sought through amendment to have separate thresholds for individuals and married beneficiaries of $5,000 and $10,000. While acknowledging the need for some form of legislation, the Democrats would have preferred to see the carrot rather than the stick approach. If pensioners had been able to earn more than their $40 a week, many would have chosen freely to invest their money in higher earning accounts. If they had been assured of some sort of provision by way of a seniors card for all those over retirement age, many would not be so worried about losing their fringe benefits.

Again, at the time this legislation was before the Committee we tried to change it with some amendments. Through the amendments we were attempting to raise the level to $65 a week for single pensioners and $90 a week for married couples, with an extra $30 a week for each child. If these had been initiated and accepted by the Government a considerable time ago, we believe that tonight there would not be any need to start forcing pensioners, in what we believe is a rather draconian measure, particularly for aged pensioners, to actually go out and seek that 10 per cent.

The amendment I wish to concentrate on tonight relates to voluntary organisations-charitable groups. They have for many years relied on low interest or no interest loans for the carrying out of their charitable services. In particular, we are concerned about those organisations that provide aged care. Again, we moved amendments in committee and these were negated. We have taken on board some of the Government's concerns. The main concern of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) was that the amendment was too broad. We have therefore redrafted the amendment, and hopefully it will be reconsidered tonight. We believe that what the Minister has come up with is far too narrow in that it limits funds for exempt organisations only to capital works and does not include welfare services.

As we see more and more people feeling the bite of the recession, welfare agencies are having to assist greater and greater numbers of people, and they simply do not have the resources to do this. The Government has said that it is not able to help at this point in time, but these agencies are desperate. All they want to be able to do is at least to continue to have access to money lent or invested with them by concerned citizens who, unlike the Government, have a social conscience. As for the Opposition calling for privatisation for welfare, here is an opportunity to support this amendment and to encourage private citizens to support charitable and voluntary organisations. Hopefully, it will consider this later tonight.

To move on to the liquid assets test, we note again that the Government has made some changes. For example, the threshold is now $10,000 if there are dependants. But again we look at the figures and at the headlines, and we know that we certainly are in a recession. We have increasing unemployment, and what does the Government do? It makes it even more difficult for those people who have been retrenched through no fault of their own to obtain income support.

We have listened to some reasons as to why this measure was introduced, but we do not believe that it will be catching those people it is aimed at. It will be catching many average Australian families. There are already adequate means of testing whether a person is genuinely unemployed, such as work tests. There are sickness benefits for people who are genuinely sick, but they must have a doctors certificate from an authorised medical practitioner. There are adequate income tests. There are assets tests for both these benefits. Persons with annual leave or termination payments are already required to wait up to four weeks before becoming eligible for any benefits.

We believe that this is a very callous and unnecessary measure that will cause most harm to low income families, and it is a disgrace that the Government can contemplate this with such apparent equanimity when it acknowledges that it is its economic policies that are causing the increased unemployment. The Government should be encouraging people to save, not discouraging them. This measure will also be particularly harsh on seasonal rural workers.

We draw the Minister's attention to the Victorian Council of Social Service (VCOSS) report of April this year titled Off the Street Begging and the Australian Social Security System which looked at recipients of emergency relief in Victoria. The VCOSS report estimated that 30 per cent of Victoria's pensioners and beneficiaries were forced to request emergency relief during 1987-88. The report found that unemployment beneficiaries and sole parent pensioners were overrepresented amongst emergency relief recipients. It also found that current waiting periods for pension and benefits were causing significant hardship with around 50 Victorian individuals and families per week seeking emergency relief while waiting for unemployment benefit. The report says that the Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, and other Government Ministers:
have failed to acknowledge to date . . . that current Social Security arrangements under Labor are forcing large numbers of Australians to rely on emergency relief.

Those numbers, as I mentioned in a question last week, have escalated considerably. In its conclusion, the report says that there are obvious areas where inequities remain in the social security system that the Government continually refuses to address. It points out that severe hardship continues to be caused by the complexity of the payment system and an increasingly tightly targeted eligibility criteria. I stress that this proposal before us tonight does nothing to reduce the existing inequities and only serves to increase the hardship for those people who least deserve it.

The Australian Democrats will propose an amendment that will simply delete this clause altogether. We did move this amendment in committee but it was not accepted, due to the combined vote of the Opposition and the Government. However, individual Democrat senators feel so strongly on this issue that we wish to vote on it again. I will be moving the amendment in Committee of the Whole tonight.

I want to refer to the assets test on the family allowance and the family allowance supplement (FAS). These proposals have caused an interesting series of comments, including some changes in the positions of both the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party, which we welcome. The Budget announcement originally put a $300,000 limit on the family allowance assets test. The family allowance supplement was reduced to $200,000 and we are very pleased to note that that has already been changed.

However, I stress that the rural crisis is unparalleled in postwar Australia. Since World War II our rural communities have never seen the range of circumstances coming together to cause such severe problems that they are now facing. The common cyclical problems have all merged together. With high interest rates and other Government policies such as free trade-ideological suicide, I guess one could call it-many farm incomes have dropped to zero and below. Most farming families are excluded from the benefits available to other Australians.

This legislation comes at a very bad time for rural Australia. Figures of income from unincorporated farm enterprises-which represent most farm family businesses-show a near bankrupt scenario, falling more than 80 per cent from $1,106m in the three months to June to $230m for the September quarter. Worse results are expected for the next two quarters.

There had been suggestions that farmers should borrow against their farm, especially those who need income support at this time. We argue that this is exceedingly difficult, especially for young farmers, many of whom already have highly encumbered properties. With equity levels falling below 75 per cent, the actual viability of the farm is endangered. To have a notional salary of 25,000, farmers need assets of over $833,000-that is, if they are going to get the 3 per cent return this year that we are now told they are most unlikely to make.

The farm is not an investment that can be called upon when needed. It is not cash in hand and the capital is in fact often not even realised. It is passed from father to son and on to his sons. So, the actual cash in hand is never realised. For many rural women, the family allowance has been the only cash in hand that they can rely upon regularly.

Few farming families now qualify for the family allowance supplement under the assets test, although most of them would certainly qualify if they had to face only the income test. If we look at the recent report that has come out on the family allowance supplement, we see that for many people FAS is just a short term payment until such time as the family's total income can increase. Results from the survey show that the FAS payment is being used to pay for basic necessities such as clothing, food and school expenses for children. These are the benefits that the Democrats would like to see extended to all farming families who need them.

The final point I wish to make on the assets test on the family allowance and the family allowance supplement concerns the considerable difficulties that farming families now face when they need their properties assessed for Austudy. The Democrats do not want to see these difficulties extended to the family allowance. It is an issue that we will be taking up next year. We are proposing that the assets test on the family allowance be abolished altogether and that the assets test for the family farm of registered primary producers be removed for the family allowance supplement.

We hope that the Opposition will agree with this amendment, as it did when it voted on it in the Committee. We hope that the Opposition will reconsider tonight the amendment to the family allowance supplement, which we also put at the committee stage but which at that time it was not able to support. We believe that even in the couple of weeks since the Committee met we have had considerable ongoing reports of the incredible difficulties that rural families are facing.

There are a number of other miscellaneous measures in this Bill. The reduction in rent assistance is unnecessary. It is a mean measure which will have the effect of reducing rent assistance for people paying less than $85 a week rent. It is very harsh on single pensioners and beneficiaries, who will still be paying a very significant proportion of their income in rent. I will not be speaking on the other legislation tonight. Senator Powell will be dealing with the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 forms an important part of several pieces of legislation associated with data matching. The implications of these pieces of legislation are pretty profound. I feel that it reflects very poorly on the Government and the Australian Democrats that such limited time is available to debate such important and far-reaching legislation as a result of their unholy alliance to gag debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lees obviously had a lot of serious concerns about the legislation that she wanted to raise. It is ironic that she took 20 minutes to raise some of those matters. They obviously could have done with even greater attention, yet she and her Party have assisted the Government to gag debate in greater detail on this package of such important legislation.

The amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, which are outlined in the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990, can be split into two sets. All the provisions of the first set of proposals are essentially aimed at limiting avoidance of the veterans' affairs assets income test. For example, the Bill provides that income will be deemed to have been received from deprived assets at a minimum rate of 10 per cent a year.

Similarly, this Bill also provides for the assessment of income on loans made by veteran pensioners with a minimum return of 10 per cent assumed. Changing economic conditions mean that a deeming rate of 10 per cent may well be too high. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) has pledged:

I do not think I could survive in my job, nor could the whole integrity of the deeming provisions survive, if they were to disadvantage people because we maintained an artificially high rate. I can give you an absolute undertaking that we will not.

The Minister's pledge is absolutely vital if service pensioners are not to be unduly burdened with an unrealistically high deeming interest rate. My colleague Senator Walters will tonight be speaking on these deeming provisions in greater detail.

Clause 24 of this Bill deals with the second set of amendments. It allows the Secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs to ask for the tax file number of any person eligible for payment under the Act. The pensioner will not be eligible for payment if he or she does not provide the number. Significantly, any eligible persons will also be required to provide the tax file numbers of their spouses.

The Opposition expresses serious misgivings about difficulties which may arise as a result of eligible persons being required to supply the tax file numbers of their spouses. Consequently, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, which was passed earlier today, adds to the provisions contained in clause 24 of this Bill. The Secretary to the Department will have the discretionary power to waive the requirement for a statement of the qualified person's spouse's tax file number if he is satisfied that the person does not know that number and that it would be unreasonably difficult for that person to obtain it. At the very least this is a minimum provision to improve the provisions in this legislation before us tonight.

The tax file numbers are to be used for the purposes of detecting incorrect payments or false or misleading declarations of income. As it pertains to the veterans community, the Department of Social Security will be the central matching agency and will assist in the detection of any service pensioner also in receipt of any Department of Social Security payment, any disability pensioner in receipt of a Department of Social Security payment who has not declared the disability payment as income, and any service pensioner whose income is known by the Australian Taxation Office but who has not declared it to the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

I would like to place on the public record the concern of the Opposition at the need for disability pensioners to provide a tax file number at all. Their pension is not taxable. It is not counted as income in assessing the rate of service pension. It is counted as income for the purposes of assessing the social security pension and it is here that the Department justifies the collection of the tax file number.

The concerns raised by the Opposition in the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs when considering the data-matching Bill have resulted in the intended use of the tax file number in payment matching being dramatically reduced. With respect to disability pension and matching with the Department of Social Security, the Government will ensure that the tax file number will now be used only as a means of last resort for identification purposes. This is an important concession although, given that it is now claimed that the circumstances in which the tax file number will be used as a tie-breaker in payment matching will be exceptionally rare, it is to be doubted whether the administrative costs associated with the collection of tax file numbers from disability pensioners is justified by the savings associated with its use.

In relation to service pensioners, initial savings projections have already been significantly modified since the data-matching Bill was first introduced. Initial savings estimates for the Department were in the order of $120m over the next four years. Subsequent figures have indicated that savings will be significantly less than this-somewhere in the order of $95m over the next four years. The fact that projected savings have diminished so much in such a short time leads one to question what the real savings will be over the next four years. We await that with enormous interest.

There is no doubt that the vast majority of veterans would not oppose measures seeking to ensure that revenue fraud is curtailed. The Opposition supports the philosophy that only those who are truly entitled to benefits should receive them. I would caution, however, that the tax file number scheme should not be uncritically accepted as the panacea for all ills associated with fraud. Only this week in the Senate we had an Auditor-General's report which gave alarming indications of minor fraud on the Department of Veterans' Affairs which seems, to date, to have been unacceptably attended to by the Department. There remain too many questions associated with the use of tax file numbers which have not been satisfactorily answered.

Also, in any provisions of this nature the right to privacy of individuals must be of central concern. The Government has not properly addressed our concerns. Evidence from a wide cross-section of the academic and social welfare community has borne this out. Tonight my colleague Senator Patterson will give much greater attention to the details of our concerns on privacy. The measures which the Opposition will be introducing with respect to the data-matching Bill may go some way towards restoring the confidence which veterans and members of the wider social security community can have of a proper balance being struck between the protection of their fundamental liberties and the detection of those who seek to defraud all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to direct attention to one particular aspect-the extension of the use of the tax file number-of this package of Bills: the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill 1990, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. That aspect is critically important for the privacy of ordinary Australian citizens and adequate protection of that privacy.

SPEECH.PARA: Before turning to the specifics of the legislation before us and the history leading up to it, I want to make some brief remarks about privacy. Sometimes, regrettably, the privacy issue is lost in the general point scoring and dubious claims associated with this kind of debate, but we must not lose sight of the central point or of its overwhelming importance. The issue of privacy is necessarily one of competing principles. It is concerned with the role of governments in the private lives of its citizens. It is directly relevant to the balance between citizens' autonomy and control over them. It always emerges in the ongoing competition between efficiency and the price society is prepared to pay for that efficiency.

In this important area of human rights, Australia has always lagged well behind the United States, for example-that great bastion of free enterprise-in developing protections under the law for privacy. We had to wait until 1988 for privacy legislation to be passed in this Parliament. Even then, the resulting Act is, in the view of the Australian Democrats, an inadequate example of its type. Limited in scope and weak in its application, the Privacy Act should have been a far more robust creature than it is. Of course, if the Government and the Opposition had supported the Australian Democrats' amendments at the time, it would have been. A mere year passed before the Parliament had to consider and finally pass further legislation to deal with private sector credit reporting agencies because the original Act failed to cover the private sector. Beyond the particular credit reporting area, of course, it still does not.

The imperative need for privacy protection, apart from its inherent importance as a human right, has been compounded in recent years by rapid developments in sophisticated information technology and the enormous potential for the compilation of centrally held and accessible personal and other information on ordinary people. `Potential' is probably the wrong word really because the actuality of massive databanks is already with us in both the public and private sectors. The capacity for intrusion by the State and its agencies into the lives of ordinary citizens is enormous. It is a growing trend and is driven by the technology which is making it possible. In this context the nature of the erosion of our precious privacy is insidious, scarcely visible at times, and to be guarded against with great vigilance.

This Government's record on privacy is, frankly, appalling. First, it tried to foist on us the Australia Card proposal. Hardly surprisingly, the Australian people were not convinced by Government assurances that the benefits of the Australia Card outweighed the dangers. Thwarted in that attempt, the Government then introduced an extended tax file number system. However, it had learned one lesson from the Australia Card fiasco: the Australian people did not want an identification numbering system at all. Sensitive to that attitude in the electorate, the Government gave assurances that the tax file number system would not be extended to other Government departments. For example, on 3 June 1988, in response to a question in the House of Representatives, Mr Keating, the Treasurer, said:
We have no intention now or in the future of extending the basis of the tax file number to do anything like some of the Australia Card tasks.
On 1 September that same year, when presenting the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax Files Numbers) Bill 1988, the Treasurer said:

No other government or non-government agency will have access to the Tax Office file number registration system, nor will it be able to use an individual's tax file number for any registration system of its own.

The history of Government actions since that time has shown that its assurances are worthless. Even before the current proposals emerged, problems were evident. As has been ably demonstrated in an extensive analysis by Dr Roger Clarke, an acknowledged information systems expert at the Australian National University, the initial scope of the tax file number scheme was wider than had been commonly understood and additional uses have accumulated through what is known as function creep. I will not detail the analysis here for those who are interested, because it is well documented in the Hansard record of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs of 19 October 1990. Suffice to say that the analysis is a telling indictment of this Government and its credibility on this issue.

We have before us tonight in legislative form the Government's latest proposal in relation to the extended use of the tax file number, allied with its far-reaching data matching proposals in the third Bill in this package. These Bills embody the Government's announcements made earlier this year. In February it was announced that sole parent pension recipients, family allowance supplement recipients and new family allowance applicants would be required to supply tax file numbers and those of their spouses to the Department of Social Security.

It was then announced in the Budget that the requirement to supply tax file numbers would be extended from the original three classes of benefits to all remaining social security payments, as well as Veterans' Affairs and Students Assistance Act payments and those falling under the first home owners scheme. As if that is not bad enough, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) has also introduced legislation to permit the matching of client information by the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Department of Community Services and Health, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the Department of Social Security.

The Government's repudiation of its explicit and frequently repeated promises to restrict the use of the tax file number to tax related matters is now complete and its credibility on this issue is destroyed. On November 9 the Minister for Social Security admitted to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs:
One must concede that the Government has gone further in this Bill than it announced it would some years ago.

This remark may deserve some sort of dubious prize for honesty, but it also ensures that the Australian people will not now accept the Government's assurances in relation to its future intentions. Even more chillingly, the evidence of the Minister to the Committee made clear the extent to which the Government's approach is technology driven. He said:
The main reason why we have gone further is that we can get the technology to do something that we could not obtain several years ago.

This attitude conjures up some quite terrifying prospects and adds profoundly to the concerns of the Australian Democrats about the Government's assurances for the future. There is no doubt that information technology will increase in sophistication and potential invasiveness at a hitherto unprecedented rate. It appears that this Government, on the basis of the Minister's own words that I have just quoted, would give the highest priority to using that technology, regardless of the cost to individual privacy.

Let me say at this point that I do not dispute the claim that the Government's proposed system increases efficiency. But that brings me back to my earlier question: what price is society prepared to pay for increased efficiency? Furthermore, the Australian Democrats question even the need for more efficiency. It is well documented, and often proudly vaunted in this chamber, that Australia has an extremely well-targeted social security system. To a great extent, these measures are aimed squarely at the recipients of social security benefits and pensions.

One often hears anecdotal evidence of massive rorts, and the Government has extrapolated from other guesstimates to claim large potential savings from this proposal. But it cannot have it both ways. To the Government's credit, the system is already well targeted. In fact, the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee report on debt recovery is but one example of this, showing that less than one per cent of overpayments are the result of fraud. Further, to intrude into the lives of this country's most vulnerable class of people is quite outrageous. To do so in a way that flies in the face of the principle of privacy protection is absolutely unacceptable to the Australian Democrats.

The Minister will argue that protective safeguards are being implemented at the same time, and to a certain extent that is true although they need to be far stronger, as we will be discussing in the committee stage. He will also argue, quite irrelevantly, that the Government is not establishing a huge central databank. I remind the Senate that a central databank is quite unnecessary to compile data on an individual as long as one has the means to link information about that person in different databanks. This is precisely the facility the tax file number will provide.

Even the safeguards being provided is not the issue-quite apart from their inadequacy. The real issue is the installation of a system which, once in place, would be as hard to unscramble as the eggs in an omelette. The already massive and interconnected surveillance system-including the provision of tax file numbers in the private sector, for example, bank accounts and employment-is being just as massively extended again by a government which has shown scant regard for either the principle of privacy or truthfulness about its intentions in relation to it.

Tragically, it appears that the Opposition intends to support the Government in this exercise. As the Australian Privacy Foundation said, the Opposition will be the Government's accomplice in ignoring the privacy rights of Australian citizens and its moves to strengthen the Privacy Commissioner's powers are, in that context, hypocritical. Despite the Opposition's sound and fury over the issue in recent weeks, it has shown its contempt for the constituency which will be most affected, Australia's most disadvantaged, and revealed its desire to have such far-reaching powers at its disposal when it occupies the treasury bench-and Senator Watson nods his head vehemently at that point.

Although the Opposition will move amendments in the committee stage, and the Australian Democrats will be happy to support some of them and move some of our own, the fundamental issue is clear. The Opposition will support this scheme and the Australian people will not be fooled into believing that the Opposition is any greater a supporter of privacy protection than is the Government. I will also be most interested to hear Senator Alston's reasons for supporting a full inquiry some weeks ago and now backing away from that when I am to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading.

By contrast, the Australian Democrats reject this unacceptable proposal. We will oppose the relevant clauses of the social security Bills and the entire data-matching Bill. At the very least, the relevant clauses in the social security legislation and the entire data-matching Bill must be referred to a Senate select committee for proper inquiry into all the Government's data surveillance plans, and, accordingly, I will be moving that by way of an amendment to the second reading motion. Such an inquiry must include a full cost-benefit analysis. To bring in this extended scheme without a proper inquiry is quite unconscionable, and the Australian people-particularly social security recipients-are entitled to such an inquiry.

The recent Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs hearings were useful but their limited scope was inadequate to deal with the implications for such a far-reaching scheme. I remind the Senate that the existing tax file number system was established only after an exhaustive Senate committee inquiry which heard 48 witnesses, received 95 written submissions and recommended that the tax file number system be strictly limited to taxation purposes. To move away from that without an equally extensive inquiry is unconscionable.

Like the Australian Privacy Foundation, the Australian Democrats reject the extended use of the tax file number on both pragmatic and principled grounds, but primarily the latter. The questions of competing principles that I raised at the beginning of this speech have not been addressed by the Government, and we know that any assurances it might offer are worthless-the evidence is there. The same dangers apply to these proposals as four years ago with the Australia Card. The Australian Democrats will not accept these threats to privacy by the conversion and perversion of the tax file number system into a multipurpose identification system, and nor will the Australian community. Therefore, I move:

At end of motion, add ``, and that the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill 1990, clauses 27, 29, 30, 35, 41, 42, 51, 52, 57 to 60, 82, 88, 89 and 95 to 99 of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and clauses 9, 10, 11, 24 and 37 to 42 of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 be referred after the second reading to a select committee, the powers, composition and reporting date of which will be contained in a separate resolution, for inquiry and report''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the Australian Democrats joined with the Australian Labor Party in forcing a guillotine in the last sitting week of the Senate, we are limited in our speeches and have each agreed to speak for 10 minutes. Indeed, the Government has given us only 3 1/2 hours to speak on the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill 1990, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990, and the second reading speeches are meant to take only part of that time. Of course, we have the committee stage to reach but the Australian Democrats have overspent that 10 minutes and that has restricted the rest of us to very short speeches. It is for that reason that I intend to keep my remarks solely to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. I will speak to the Government's original Bill, although I believe that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) has had second thoughts and intends to put through a few amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: First, we have the deeming provisions. Pensioners-both single and married-who have just over $2,000 in the bank are deemed to be earning 10 per cent whether they invest their money or not. As Senator Lees said tonight, interest rates are coming down. Indeed, they came down again today and there is no possibility that the pensioners will be able to get at call their interest of 10 per cent for the $2,000 or whatever figure the Government has amended it to. It is just not possible for them to do that.

We now come to family allowances. As we all know, the Government some time ago commissioned a paper to be written by Bettina Cass. Some time ago in this place I spoke about the commissioning of this report. Bettina Cass was commissioned to put forward to the Government the income support that families with children should have. She went through it very clearly. I will read a few of the comments she made. She said:
Assistance for families is based on the fundamental conviction that children are a highly valued social resource, on which the future living standards of the society depend.

. . . it is appropriate for the social security and taxation systems to redistribute income to families in recognition of the increased costs which they bear in carrying out the essential and socially valuable tasks of child-rearing.
She went on:

. . . at any level of family income people with children incur greater costs and have greater needs than do people without children at the same level of income. The objective is to provide universal support which will increase the disposable income of all families so as to offset, at least in part, the additional costs of raising children.
She also said:

. . . wages do not take account of employees' varying family responsibilities. Universal family allowance payments increase the real incomes of people with children, an objective which the wages system does not address.
One of the headings reads `Family allowances in Australia: recognising the costs of children in all families'. This was written in 1986-before the Government got its hands on it.

The Government commissioned this report and then, even though Bettina Cass's main recommendation was that family allowances not be income or asset tested, promptly introduced an income test. It is now attempting to introduce an assets test on families, as Senator Lees has pointed out, at a time when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has deliberately engineered a recession that has particularly affected people in the bush. He engineered that recession through wages accords and high interest rates. People in the bush with high assets but no income, particularly those in the wheat, wool and horticultural areas, will have a very rough time in the coming year, and Government is introducing an assets test. However, we will come to the amendments later. In addition, the Government has reduced the assets test for those on family allowance supplement.

Perhaps even worse is what it is doing to people on unemployment benefits. As I said in a speech earlier today, last week alone the number of people unemployed rose by 10,591. These are not just figures, but people. Ten and a half thousand people were added to the unemployment lists in just the last week-1,500 people a day.

This is what the Government intends to do with those who, unfortunately, through this engineered recession-the one Mr Keating keeps telling us he has under control-have to rely on the unemployment benefit. Those in receipt of the unemployment benefit already have an income test of $60 a week. On top of that, they are already subject to an assets test. On top of this, the Government is going to impose a liquid assets test. The Government intends to make sure that people with $5,000 in the bank or in any other liquid assets do not get the unemployment benefit for a month. That is completely unacceptable.

The Government says that this measure is needed to stop people who have lucrative seasonal jobs from receiving the unemployment benefit. But that will not catch them. People who organise their lives will put their money under the bed. They will not put it in the banks. We all remember a very eminent person who warned the people of Australia that, when Labor got in, they would have to put their money under the bed or the Government would rip it off them. How true that statement was. This is just what the Government is doing. Those people will put the money under the bed. If they have a paltry $5,000, the Government intends to make sure that they use most of that up before they get the unemployment benefit. As I have said, the Government is changing its mind and it will increase that amount. It is a paltry amount.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be to you.
