—Could honourable senators imagine the effect of this on a 45-to 50-year-old man with a dependent spouse and a couple of young children? Senator Zakharov can say all she likes. She should just visualise this, because she does not understand.
—I have been there, done that.

—I have been there and done that. Senator Zakharov has not. If she had she would not support this legislation. What does that 45- or 50-year-old man do? He will not be able to get another job very quickly. Last week 10,500 people were put on the dole by the Government's organised recession. What does that man do? If his wife has saved a few bob, he has to say to her, `I am sorry, love, but that's it; we can't get unemployment benefit because you have saved a few bob'. At the most expensive time of his life, with teenage children, the Government will make sure that he is not entitled to unemployment benefit until he has used up most of his savings.

SPEECH.PARA: He will already be devastated by the fact that he has been sacked. If the Government persists, honourable senators can imagine what will happen to these people. The Government will sink this group of people into abject poverty that they will never be able to get out of. The Government's original intention to set a liquid assets test of $5,000 was anticipated to save $33m in a full year. Unfortunately, my 10 minutes has expired. Any further comments I have will be made in the committee stage of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address my remarks to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. I remind the Senate that Labor used to claim to be the Party of the battler. Yet its policies have often failed to do much to assist those most in need of help. The assumption that the worst off will always do better under Labor is now seen to be untrue. Lower and middle income earners have suffered most from Labor's economic mismanagement, with their real disposable income and their share of the national income reduced. Labor's spending initiatives and redistributive taxation have not brought with them equality or prosperity, only inflation, debt, high interest rates, unemployment and bureaucratic interference.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening we are debating yet another example of Labor's redistributive taxation and bureaucratic interference in a number of aspects of the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). These Bills make numerous changes and will affect the entitlements of various social security beneficiaries, and will also require many beneficiaries to supply their tax file number and that of their spouse as a precondition for receiving payment.

I want specifically to address the issue of the assets test on the family allowance. The legislation sets the assets test threshold for the payment of family allowance at $500,000. At Budget time the threshold was to be $300,000. The family allowance supplement will be indexed, and the threshold will be increased from $322,750 to $347,500. Again, a threshold of $200,000 was announced in the Budget.

In Australia we already see much evidence of the detrimental effects of an assets test on other benefits such as Austudy and assistance for isolated children. They have already created hardship for some Australian families. Like many other senators, I have had many representations from people who have already been hurt. We accept the fact that many rural people have assets, but they do not have liquidity. They cannot say that they will pay their bills with their stockyard. Perhaps they could pay them with the sale of stock-that is, if they had some stock, or crops, that were of some value. The problem is that no money is coming in and parents need actual cash to cope with the expenses of raising a family. Denying rural families these allowances will preclude many young people in rural areas from receiving the same opportunity as those who live in the cities. There is no doubt that some Australian families are already suffering, and their hardships would be increased by the denial of financial assistance with a test on the family allowance.

The Government has stated that these changes will principally benefit farmers in rural communities. If it really wants to help farmers, small business people and communities in rural areas, because of the severity of the rural downturn and the deterioration in incomes, it should abolish the assets test altogether-which the Opposition will move for in an amendment to the legislation.

I wonder whether the Government really appreciates the difficulties being experienced by the rural and farming community. Originally, child endowment was not assets tested or means tested; neither was the rebate for dependent children. Now it seems that family allowance is seen merely as a welfare measure put in the same category as unemployment and sickness benefits. Instead, it should be seen as an investment in the next generation of Australians. There are few better investments than in the young children of the families of Australia.

In our immigration program we pay to bring in children from other nations. It would surely be far better for us to support Australian families and to encourage them to bring up Australian children in the great traditions of our national way of life. These days it appears that Government policy is emphasising much more the provision of child-care centres and extra places. Indeed, we ought to encourage children to be raised within the traditional family units of our nation where child-care is seen as a worthy career and an honoured role. There can be no doubt that a dollar spent on family allowances is a far better investment than a dollar spent on child-care centres. The Government has abused the family allowance firstly by means testing or income testing it, and secondly, through this legislation which seeks to make the payment of it subject to an assets test.

There was no appreciation of what the family allowance is and what it means to families throughout Australia. Indeed, the Government did not seek to amend its original proposals until there was a considerable outcry about the injustice and the insensitivity of these arrangements, particularly during a massive rural crisis.

Even some Government members eventually acknowledged that there was a very real problem. The Australian Labor Party member for Grey, Mr O'Neil, said many farmers might be assets rich but income poor, particularly with this year's rural downturn. In many cases people in rural areas will not be earning any income. I think this is a complete indictment of this Government. I suggest that, if the Government really wants to help farmers who have been hit hard by the rural downturn and by the deterioration in farm incomes as a result of the Government's own economic policy, it would not even think of introducing a test on the family allowance.

The family allowance is a very important source of income for many farmers. It is not appropriate to have a test which has a very different impact depending upon where people live. By the very nature of farming and small business, liquidity is a major problem. For country people, particularly, the assets test is a most inaccurate and unfair system of determining a family's financial status and ability to make ends meet. It seems to me that the Government believes in helping people in the cities, not in rural Australia where, unfortunately, so few live now.

In Paul Keating's Australia, farmers are on their knees at the bank manager's table after years of negative income. This action is in keeping with Labor's general attitude of contempt for rural Australia. Messrs Keating and Hawke talk loudly about social justice but rural people, apparently, are not part of the social justice program. What have country people done to be treated in this way? It is bad enough that this Government chooses to beat farmers and small business men. Its economic policies have already been ruinous to anyone trying to contribute to the productivity of the nation. Already, farm children are significantly disadvantaged. Without question, they have reduced opportunities for education, health services, cultural experience and, of course, future employment. That is bad enough, but this proposal would deny them some of the basic necessities of life at a time when many are living in poverty.

The same lot has befallen many of the small businesses around Australia. As we have been told many times in this Senate by my colleague, Senator Boswell, many small business people are facing the threat of bankruptcy. I remind the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) that, as is the case with farming, assets in a small business are not equivalent to income. Because of the discriminatory nature of the test on such families in such bad economic times, they will soon be among the most disadvantaged in today's ever depressing outlook for Australian families.

It is for these reasons that the Opposition will be opposing any sort of assets test on the family allowance. It can only further disadvantage those children of families who are already in difficult financial circumstances. I remind the Government that it is one thing to be efficient in the outlay of taxpayers' money by the Department of Social Security and quite another to achieve a reduction in outlays at the expense of families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill 1990. This Bill raises very complex and difficult issues involving, among other things, clashes of important principles including the need to protect the revenue while, at the same time, ensuring that an individual's privacy is not compromised.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs held five hearings and heard evidence from a variety of outside organisations including the Australian Privacy Foundation and the Australian Council of Social Service. The Privacy Commissioner made some useful and valuable contributions to the Committee's considerations. I would like to record in this chamber that I believe the Committee worked very effectively which is in no small measure due to the abilities of its Chairman, Senator Cooney, and the intelligent approach of my colleagues including Senator Vanstone, Senator Alston, Senator Patterson and Senator O'Chee whose questions helped draw out the difficult issues which were raised by this Bill.

The data-matching Bill will, amongst other things, allow the relevant agencies to transfer sets of client data to a matching agency set up within the Department of Social Security. It proposes to regulate the conduct of data matching programs by requiring that agencies substantially follow a six step framework as set out in the Bill. It has to be stated that by bringing this Bill into the Parliament the Government has broken the promises it made regarding the use of the tax file number scheme. The Australian Privacy Foundation, through Roger Clark, very effectively outlined the series of assurances that the Government had given on the limited use of the tax file number. In June 1988 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said:
We have no intention now or in the future of extending the basis of the tax file number to do anything like some of the Australia Card tasks.
In September 1988 he said:
No other government or non-government agency will have access to the Tax Office file number registration system, nor will it be able to use an individual's TFN for a registration system of its own.
The response of the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, to these accusations was little short of astonishing. In the committee stage of the Bill, Senator Vanstone asked:
What has changed since these commitments were given?
Senator Richardson made a new contribution to political theory by replying:

. . . everytime in a budget process the Government announces a change you could define it as going back on an undertaking. All Governments of all persuasions do it all of the time. They have to; that is what the budget process is all about.

I think that is an astonishing view of the Budget process. I am sure that it is a view that Senator Collins, who is at the table, will certainly not endorse when he stands up to speak. Given the performance of the Labor Government and its disgraceful record of broken promises across a whole range of issues, it comes as little surprise to people on this side of the chamber that Senator Richardson should hold this view of the Budget process. It is worth making the point to Senator Richardson that Budgets should be largely about honouring promises, not breaking them.

Senator Richardson gave two reasons for the Government breaking its promise with regard to the tax file number. As he says, the main reason we have `gone further' is so that we can now get the technology to do something we could not obtain several years ago. The second reason for the broken promise was to cut $1 billion off government expenditure in the last Budget. Senator Richardson said:
So if you make that decision you have to examine ways of doing it.
If the reason for breaking a promise is to save money it again helps to explain the easy manner in which this Government breaks its promises.

Of course, there are numerous ways in which money can be saved without breaching solemn undertakings which have been given to the public. For example, Senator Richardson could have examined the Economic Action Plan of the coalition which effectively identifies $2.8 billion in savings which the Government could have put into effect without breaking its solemn promise. Senator Richardson also gave another reason for the broken promise-to make these savings without impacting on honest people. We applaud the desire to avoid impacting on honest people. It was the Opposition's intention to ensure that this legislation does not intrude on important principles of privacy.

I do not argue that the Government is not aware of the privacy problems. It has attempted in this Bill to institute measures which would protect privacy considerations. We believe these measures are simply not adequate. The amendments which will be moved by Senator Alston will ensure that the privacy principles are buttressed in a number of very important and significant ways.

The estimate of savings made by the Government through this broken promise is $65m in the first year rising to over $300m in subsequent years. One of the major concerns of the Committee was to analyse whether the Government was in effect introducing an Australia Card. There was a very vigorous debate between the Privacy Foundation and the Privacy Commissioner. Mr O'Connor, the Privacy Commissioner, tabled two important documents before the Committee in which he analysed the arguments put forward by the Privacy Foundation that the Government was, in effect, introducing an Australia Card. These documents were carefully read by members of the Committee. Mr O'Connor summed up the differences between the Australia Card and the extension of the tax file number as proposed in this Bill. The views of the Privacy Commissioner are set out in the Hansard of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs hearing on Monday, 3 December. Mr O'Connor said that the differences are at two levels, and I quote:

. . . it was important that the Australia Card took the form of a card. Sure, it bore a number, and a number was a key element of the scheme . . . its administration was to have a universal impact and to be fairly intrusive at the point of registration.
He went on to say that he thought other differences were also significant, and again I quote:

The significant distinctions appear to lie in the health care area, that is, Health Insurance Commission, Department of Health, and then in the census, death, epidemiological area, where it was proposed that those authorities would have access to the national births deaths and marriages register. I think we all know separately that a small but significant group in the community is constantly challenging aspects of the practice of the Bureau of Statistics. I spent, I think, the first six months of last year looking at those complaints quite consistently. Then we had uses proposed, on the final version of the scheme-
that is, the Australia Card scheme-
in the immigration area and in the passports area, and again under the final version to the births, deaths and marriages register. So it was being used as an identity authentication device.

Despite the assurances of the Privacy Commissioner, the coalition is concerned by the extension of the use of the tax file number and believes that these extensions must be counterbalanced by upgrading the role of the Privacy Commissioner. I strongly support the amendments that will be moved by Senator Alston.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the restraints of the guillotine, I will restrict my comments to the extension of the tax file number system and the setting up within the Department of Social Security of an eligibility checking facility for Commonwealth income support agencies. The Government's attempts to put these two proposals into a workable legislative form have been nothing but disgraceful-sloppy and indecisive. The Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill all reveal additional pieces of the Government's tax file number jigsaw. They extend the mandatory provision of tax file numbers to clients of the Department of Social Security, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the first home owners scheme, and outline how these tax file numbers will be used to crosscheck data provided to the Department of Social Security, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Community Services and Health. There were 50 Government amendments to the original data-matching Bill one week after it came to the Senate. The Bill came into the Senate on the Thursday night, and the following Friday 50 amendments were faxed to my office.
—Disgraceful.

— As Senator Kemp says, that is disgraceful. In fact, there were so many changes that it was decided to break the Senate's Bills curfew and draw up a new data-matching Bill incorporating the amendments. This Bill is about the privacy of Australians and the extension of a tax file number. What do we have? We have legislation brought into this place that has 50 Government amendments before it even sees a day in this chamber. Despite all these changes, the Government still cannot strike a proper balance between identifying fraud and protecting the privacy of honest citizens. My staff member and I have spent hours and hours, as no doubt have the members and staff of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, examining this Bill in haste. The Bill was brought in at 8 o'clock on Thursday night. The next Friday morning we were supposed to be looking at this Bill in detail.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1988, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) assured us that tax file numbers would be administered exclusively by the Australian Taxation Office for tax purposes. They were designed solely to help reduce tax evasion, he said. They would not apply to benefits where tax instalments were not deducted, nor would they apply to exempt pensions, such as invalid pensions. Finally, he said, the Government had agreed that the tax file number system would be completely voluntary.

Within two years, all of these assurances have been torn to shreds. They are not worth the paper they have been written on, if they were ever written on paper-and, anyway, we have learnt what Mr Keating's assurances mean. As clause 93 of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill states, the tax file number is to be used to facilitate the administration of any Commonwealth legislation under which pensions, allowances, benefits or other payments are provided. These Bills make providing a tax file number a prerequisite to the payment of all government benefits, including social security and veterans' affairs pensions, which have no connection with the tax system.

We are haunted by the suggestion made to the 1985 Tax Summit that the way to introduce the Australia Card was by staged implementation. That is how the Government would introduce a national identity scheme. This would be desirable, a good way to do it, because it would minimise adverse public reaction: we'll bring it in by stealth and what we will do is bring it in at the end of a session and hold a gun at their heads and tell them various things about what is going to happen and how much money will be lost if we do not bring it in.

What is Senator Richardson's reaction to the change and the turnaround in the promises that the tax file number would not be extended? We have heard him tonight, `Nothing is immutable'-Senator Richardson has learnt a new word- `we have kept lots of promises and we have broken some. That is what the Budget process is all about'. That is not a normal part of the Budget process, and Senator Kemp has gone into that in much more detail. The Government gave firm assurances about a matter of principle that had evoked adverse public reaction-that reaction to the Australia Card was unsurpassed in the 1980s-and yet this is another one of the Government's long line of broken promises.

We still cannot believe what the Government says about tax file numbers and data matching. On 9 September, in an answer to a question I asked, Senator Richardson told the Senate that the Tax Office would provide the Department of Social Security with data-matching details relating only to Social Security clients. He really was not on top of it and he had to slide, during the next few days, into a bit more detail. But then that was not what was going to happen. It is untrue that it was going to provide the Department of Social Security with only DSS data-matching details. Steps 2 and 3 of clause 7 of the Bill confirm that the Tax Office will give Social Security details relating to all of the agencies involved in the data matching-and that was what was denied in that first question.

Then on 10 October-as I said, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) was slipping along because he was beginning to get a small grasp of what it was all about-the Minister claimed that all the data from the data-matching process would be destroyed within 90 days. But he was wrong again. He had not paid attention to the detail. He has not got on top of his portfolio, as we know. On the contrary, the Bill allows source agencies to retain the data indefinitely. In his first second reading speech, the Minister claimed that the guidelines in the schedule would be replaced by the Privacy Commissioner's general data-matching guidelines when they were finally released. The Bill simply does not allow for this takeover. The Minister has concocted a misguided idea that the stricter guidelines will apply.

Then we have the latest and maybe the most deceitful backflip of all. In the hearings, Social Security was adamant that the data matching would be precise and that any discrepancies derived would be conclusive. I have here-and I have not got the time to go through them-Hansard quotation after Hansard quotation after Hansard quotation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Take my time, Senator Patterson.

—Thank you very much, Senator Crichton-Browne. I have example after example of senior people in the Department saying, `This will be precise. When we get a hit, it will be a hit. When we get a match, it will be a match. It will be definite'. However, the Bill no longer backs up this assertion. Originally, the Bill allowed Social Security to return to the source agency any data that `showed' that something might be untoward. Then in what the Minister referred to as `a minor drafting change', the word `show' suddenly disappeared and `suggest' appeared.

SPEECH.PARA: It might seem to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, a minor change, but let me tell you that that minor change has caused great stirrings in the Department, great stirrings even to the point that we have the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) writing to the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, about it-about one little word. But what the Minister said was that it was `a minor drafting change'.

Because `suggest' did not reflect the claimed certainty of the data-matching results, the Opposition sought to replace it with the word `indicate'. Well, all hell broke loose. The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, treading delicately through this legislation, as it had to because of the policy implications-and, having been a member of that Committee, I know how difficult it must have been-actually talked about this in its second report. It said it was concerned that `show' had been changed to `suggest'. However, we had the gall to suggest that we would move an amendment to change it to `indicate'! Next thing the Prime Minister wrote to the Leader of the Opposition claiming that $150m a year would be lost. He plucked out of the sky a rough estimate of where the agencies might get mismatches in their dragnet fishing operations. When Dr Hewson replied, an answer came back not from the Prime Minister but from the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, who said:
I do not accept that the debate about `indicate' and `suggest' is merely one of semantics. The Government regards this as a fundamental issue going to the heart of the data matching program.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you know in your heart of hearts, even if you cannot admit it outwardly, that the Minister on the one hand said that changing the word `show' to `suggest' was a minor drafting change but, on the other hand, when the Opposition wanted to change it from `suggest' to `indicate', said he did not regard the debate as merely an issue of semantics. He said that the Government regarded the matter `as a fundamental issue going to the heart of the data-matching program'. I wonder about the Minister and whether he is capable of discerning fact from fiction.

If one reads the clause as a whole, one finds that, with our amendment, it would say, `indicate that the person might have been in receipt of an overpayment' and `might' have done something else; it does not say `indicate that the person is in receipt of an overpayment'. Anyway, all hell broke loose. The Government had an army of bureaucrats to add up the figures-although as far as I am concerned they did not add up. But we have conceded that it might have lost $150m a year. I am concerned about the privacy of those social security benefit recipients-the veterans and students on Austudy, who today do not have the freedom not to belong to a union. I have suggested, and the Opposition has agreed to it, that we put at the end of our amendments a requirement that the matching agency and the source agency come back to the two Houses of Parliament and justify what they have been doing. They should show us how accurate they are and tell us how many false positives and how many positive positives they get, because from evidence presented to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs one would have thought that almost everyone was going to be a positive hit.

The Minister has openly admitted that this data matching is driven by money and technology. Senator Powell addressed this issue, and I think it is something about which we must be very careful. We have seen it in the Health Insurance Commission. That is an issue I shall address because it will not go away. As technology develops, we will have bureaucrats saying, `Oh, we can save money. Don't worry about privacy'.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would say that we could probably save money.

— `We can probably save money; let's go ahead with it'. We must be vigilant about this matter. Mr Acting Deputy President, you and I both were afraid, on the committee inquiring into higher education, about the technocrats not understanding the ethics of their professions. That is what we have to be concerned about. That is the issue we are discussing today-the core of a Senate report which the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) dismissed out of hand. We are looking at the heart of the issues. People see something as convenient and easy and they forget the social issues that go along with it. On 10 October the Minister claimed that the scheme would take $400m from the pockets of cheats and bludgers. The explanatory memorandum for the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill says that the whole data-matching package will generate savings of $290m in 1991-92. However, the Department of Social Security (DSS) believes that it will achieve $290m by itself.

SPEECH.PARA: On 29 November, the Minister claimed annual savings of $350m. We know that these are all gross figures and not really savings at all. I have identified costs of over $14.3m for the first financial year which put a sizeable dent in the estimated savings of $65m. The Minister is known as the chief numbers cruncher but I think this is taking his job beyond its limits.

All the Social Security estimates are based on the assumption that a 2 per cent residual of clients are illegitimately receiving benefits but are not being identified by present monitoring techniques. The 2 per cent is based solely on a survey of 10,000 family allowance clients undertaken between June and October 1989. The sample is totally unrepresentative of DSS's client population in terms of how much they are paid, why they are paid, how often they are monitored and the methods that they use to cheat the system.

DSS has also referred to risk based reviews and accelerated claimant matching results as evidence that the residual is at least 2 per cent. This is also a rubbery guesstimate. When I asked bureaucrats, the senior public servants, how they got these figures, they said, `Well, a lot of it is based on experience'. There is no breakdown of savings from each of the three types of matching, namely, identity matching, income matching and double payments. There is no estimate of the percentage of the 2 per cent residual that would be picked up by data matching. No account is given for welfare clients who have not lodged tax returns for the last financial year and who are not legally required to do so. Also, we have no figures at all for the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

The Minister has openly admitted that the use of tax file numbers as an identifying link in this data-matching exercise is technology driven. Social Security has found computer technology that can high speed parallel match large amounts of data obtained from a number of sources. However, this technology requires a highly structured matching key, such as a tax file number. As representatives of the Department said at the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs hearing on 9 November, Social Security believes that the matching cannot be effectively carried out without using such a key.

I believe that the Government has put the cart before the horse. The tender for the matching will go out after the legislation is passed, yet the Bill has been specifically framed to accommodate the technology earmarked for the data matching. Already a number of computer companies and some computer experts have told me that they can do the data matching without using a tax file number.

Had we had the time and had due process been given to this legislation, a Senate inquiry would have had the chance to ask questions of those experts. I am not a computer expert and I do not pretend to be, but I have learnt a lot in the last two months. We would have had the opportunity, on behalf of the Australian public, to examine this properly and in much more detail, not as it has been done here-brought in on a Thursday night and debated in the Committee on a Friday. It is disgraceful.

Except for a representative of Australian Associated Press, there is not one person in the press gallery. I do not suppose that other members of the press are watching the proceedings on television or listening. They are not interested in this issue, which is about the privacy of Australians. I believe that the Health Insurance Commission will be next. Someone will say, `Oh, we need the tax file number for the Health Insurance Commission'. Then it will be, `Oh, it is stupid to have a tax file number and a Medicare number. Why not have a single number'.

I am not convinced that the tax file number is an essential element of the data-matching proposal; it is certainly not essential enough to warrant the Government reneging on its 1988 assurances. The Department assures us that a fair and open tender will be conducted. I will be watching that very closely. That may be true, but the very specific nature of the legislation may well disqualify tenderers whose technology does not require the use of the tax file number as an identifying link.

How conned we will be if it is found that the tax file number is not needed for the data matching and is only being used because the Act was drafted to accommodate technology that the Department had earmarked to do not only this task but management information system tasks as well-all because Canberra bureaucrats are locked into a particular system.

The Opposition is as keen as the Government to stamp out welfare fraud. However, the Government stands condemned for the deceitful and unethical way in which it has handled this data-matching proposal. It has unashamedly turned its back on its 1988 tax file number assurances without even proving the necessity for the tax file number in the data-matching process. It has put the Privacy Commissioner on a false pedestal, whilst realising that the Privacy Act `statutorily muzzles' him from speaking his mind on an issue about which we know he is very concerned.

Whilst claiming how privacy conscious it is, the Government has presided over a massive watering down of the draft data-matching guidelines. I will address these privacy matters in the committee stage of the Bill. Over the last two months we have witnessed intolerably sloppy drafting, pie in the sky estimates, and a Minister whose lack of understanding of this issue has been evidenced time and time again.

Data matching can be a very effective weapon against welfare fraud, but it is not the only weapon and nor is it the only solution. If the Government is serious about stopping fraud, it must also make a concerted effort to improve the efficiency of its other monitoring and recovery procedures. Yesterday's tabling of the Auditor-General's report on the telephone rental concession scheme is testimony to this fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be but five minutes because much of what I might have been tempted to observe has been presented in a very articulate way by both Senator Alston and Senator Patterson. The reason I bothered to rise is that I believe that, of all personal human rights, privacy perhaps goes to the central core of human nature's desire for some certain limits against intrusion. Once that basic right is abrogated in any way, when that right is eroded, then we begin to erode all other rights.

SPEECH.PARA: We all agree that whatever the circumstance there is nothing more personally offensive to our soul than to have our privacy threatened-whether it be by way of our conversations being unlawfully listened to or whether it be as a result of what we judge to be private information being exposed to improper public scrutiny. Of course, in principle, it is sensible to have the means to trace payments and claims histories and to have the facilities to cross-match information. However, let me remind the Senate of what the Treasurer, Mr Keating, said on 1 September 1988 in his second reading speech:

No other government or non-government agency will have access to the Tax Office file number registration system, nor will it be able to use an individual's tax file number for any registration system of its own.
Perhaps my words were prophetic. As I now cast my eye back, I see what I said in this Senate during the introduction of the tax file number in its original form. On 10 November 1988 I stated:
Once introduced into Australia government will find it hard to resist the temptation to expand its scope and to encompass transactions it was not originally meant to regulate.

I am also concerned about comments to the effect that the system is now, in all respects, voluntary. I have some difficulty with this notion, given the pecuniary penalties involved in not quoting one's tax file number. I suggest that the system operate with the assistance of a certain amount of compulsion.
I went on to observe:

Overseas experience in particular demonstrates that legislation of this kind, even if originally limited in scope and intent, will quickly escalate to cover the fields of human transactions and dealings. The Australian Privacy Council calls this `function creep'; that is, a substantial confinement of the uses of the identification system to taxation purposes is a constraint which will be eroded by the incremental addition of functions for which the tax file number will become an essential adjunct.

How absolutely true. I quoted examples of the United States of America and Canada, where the tax file number was set up for one basic reason. They found, as I think Senator Patterson mentioned, that it was a great convenience and a great temptation for other government departments to want to embrace it and the information contained therein.

It has taken absolutely no time for this Government to recognise the merit and benefit in terms of financial savings of expanding the use of the tax file number. In 1988 the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs recommended in relation to the tax file number legislation:
. . . be strictly limited in its terms so it applies only in relation to taxation purposes and those purposes be so framed as to prevent a progressive extension of the ambit of the Bill.

Senator Richardson would tell us that the Government has kept the word of its commitment. The present guidelines provide, inter alia, that the tax file number is not to be used for cross-matching information for `non-tax purposes'. The Government notionally stays within its guidelines simply by progressively widening the scope of the objects of the tax file number in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. In other words, it simply broadens the definition of taxation purposes. The Privacy Commissioner then obligingly broadens the tax file number guidelines accordingly. Perhaps such manoeuvres by the Government would be more difficult if the Privacy Commissioner had greater independence and an ability to report directly to the Parliament other than through his annual report.

In respect of the question of what taxation is, a substantial degree of legal fiction is now involved. The guidelines currently state that the Department of Social Security is administratively responsible for taxation law. The Budget provisions make all government benefits taxation matters, even where the benefit is entirely non-taxable. So the Government, by using this word `taxation', comforts and soothes itself by arguing that it is still strictly within the parameters of taxation.

I will say just two things about my specific privacy concerns. Firstly, data matching is a random technique which involves an arbitrary investigation of a whole class of persons without reasonable cause. Information collected for one purpose is matched for another purpose without the consent or knowledge of the person involved. In this regard it should be observed that data matching is to be applied retrospectively in the sense that the information which was disclosed prior to the announcement of this program is to be included in the matching program. There can be no argument as to consent or knowledge.

In conclusion, I find it passing strange when I look back on the landscape of this Government and those amongst it who used to consider themselves the great civil libertarians that Senator Zakharov might have once been a good example, but now is just a remnant, of somebody who cared about these matters. There was a time when she would have been most indignant about the pervasive influence that government has on one's life, the amount of information that is available to governments--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not if they are cheating.

—That is right. Senator Zakharov sums it up. She says, `Not if they are cheating', which goes to the very heart of the onus of proof. Everybody is cheating until the Government can satisfy itself that they are not. Therefore, we need these intrusive provisions to ensure that governments are able to satisfy themselves that people are not cheating. That is a great departure from the arguments we used to hear from the Left when we were in government.
—You speak for the Left now, do you?

—I find that I have to take up the fundamental causes and endeavours of human rights, privacy and concern for the individual-all those matters about which the Left used to posture many years ago when it was in opposition and had the luxury of pretending to care.
—And get done by the Right.

—It is not only a question of getting done by the Right-that is a daily event; it is a question of the price to stay in government. Members of the Government have all subjugated, abrogated and jettisoned the beliefs in privacy that they once had.

SPEECH.PARA: Time prevents me from going over the amendments we have introduced. I trust that they will all be successful. I know that the Democrats-they demonstrated it with their concern for the Australia Card-will accommodate the concerns and anxieties that are manifested therein.

Finally, there is one matter that I hope we will get some satisfaction on; that is, the Bill does not provide any remedies for citizens who believe that they have been treated unjustly by the data-matching process. There should be some minimum remedies both for negligent matching, resulting in any kind of detriment to beneficiaries, and for owner authorised use or disclosure of information exchanged pursuant to the data-matching exercise.

If time permitted-by vigorous nodding, Senator Patterson tells me that it does not-I would tell honourable senators all the things that are wrong with the Privacy Act which, while not only being parallel to this Act, would also make this a better Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not attempt to answer every point raised in the second reading debate, given that many points will be raised in the committee stage. However, I would like to go over a few. Senator Alston's contribution at the beginning of the second reading debate consisted largely of an attack on Government economic policy, which is not worth refuting now. His reference to my alleged backdowns beggars the imagination. I find it extraordinary that he referred to the family allowance assets test. He said that the decision was hastily conceived and amended when the Government knew the full story. The reality was that the Government took the decision in June. It was announced in August, but during the four to five months from when the decision was originally taken the rural crisis got much worse.

SPEECH.PARA: When fully appraised of how bad the rural crisis has become the Government either takes false pride in a decision taken on one set of parameters and refuses to admit a change, or when the parameters change the Government addresses that change and alters the decision. That is what happened. The Government, in changing the original Budget proposal for a family allowance assets test, was able to forgo $25m in savings and I am accused of a backdown. Yet on the very same provision the Opposition proposed to abandon it altogether, forgoing a further $57m on top of the $25m forgone by the Government. The fact is that when it comes to backdowns on this issue, Dr Hewson could not even front his own Party room and allowed his shadow Minister to get rolled instead.

When it comes to the pharmaceutical changes, we were also accused of some enormous backdown because of the $50 up-front payment to pensioners. That was money to which they were already entitled under the Government's announcement in the Budget. It was merely brought forward. There was no new money and no suggestion of an extra payment. Money was merely brought forward to ameliorate any effects. In terms of a backdown on the chronically ill, again one ought to be able to admit that if people are chronically ill and are going to suffer hardship from a decision, then a very minor amendment can be the right thing to do.

Senator Lees, while welcoming many changes, was particularly concerned with the deeming provisions. Senator Newman correctly quoted from something I had said earlier about the Government varying the decision on the 10 per cent interest rate. I intend to speak with members of the Senate committee during the course of this week on the direction of that debate and consult with them again prior to Parliament resuming in February, when an announcement can be made on what rate will apply from March. If the 10 per cent is not available at call to people right around the country, with a minimum of fuss and bother, then that amount would be changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have said this months ago.

—I did say it months ago. I have repeated it time and time again, and I am repeating it now because it is an assurance worth repeating. I believe that this will not be a problem when the crunch comes. Much of the rest of the debate has centred on the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill. Because I am conscious of time, I do not seek to go into the detail of that; we will leave that to the committee stage. There have been claims that the number of amendments and corrections that have been made in answer to this are in some way an example of incompetence. But when one looks at the Opposition amendments to be presented tonight, a massive error has not yet been picked up which would suggest that Senator Alston is a complete incompetent. I would not dare suggest that-not complete, anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: When there are negotiations with agencies-not to mention the Privacy Commissioner-in Senate committees, then numbers of amendments are obviously possible. It is not the case in the Senate that the Government has the numbers to crunch through anything it likes, and therefore amendments to Bills the size of this one-and this kind of dimension is rare-occur every single year. There is nothing terribly unusual about these.

Far from our figures being proved to be rubbery, as Senator Patterson has said, they have stood up to the test every single time they have been examined. Even the amnesty figures, which I thought were underdone, finished up coming out almost exactly right; I only hope we can have a debate on tax file numbers in 12 months time because the Government's Estimates for this will prove to be underdone. We will get more out of tax file numbers than we have put in the Budget; they are very conservative figures indeed. None of them are rubbery.

This Bill contains changes that will affect social security recipients for years to come, but the most important thing is that all fraud in the system that can be eliminated will be eliminated by this measure, by the use of computer technology which has only come onto the market during the last six to nine months. Governments cannot act any more quickly than that. By doing this, we will be taking money out of the pockets of cheats and bludgers and putting it back into the pockets of ordinary decent citizens. That is what government is elected for.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Powell's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: DATA-MATCHING PROGRAM (ASSISTANCE AND TAX) BILL 1990

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments and the new part to be added to the Data-Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Before clause 1, page 1, insert the following heading:
``PART 1-PRELIMINARY''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the effect of the amendment moved by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) is to insert the heading, `PART 1-PRELIMINARY'.
—Yes.
—I agree with that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Alston) agreed to:
2. After clause 3, page 5, insert ``PART 2-DATA-MATCHING''.
Clause 4 agreed to.
Clause 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 5, page 5, subclause (2), lines 32 to 39, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:

``(2) Guidelines in force under section 17 of the Privacy Act 1988, in relation to TFN data or tax-file number information are not breached where an agency has complied with the provisions of this Act.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment on the basis that it is one of the Opposition amendments which tightens provisions of the legislation.

—The difficulty here is not so much the disagreement in principle. I think it does the same job as the clause in the Bill, but the clause in the Bill is easier to understand. It is not the kind of thing over which we will divide. I think that the Bill presents a better form of words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without labouring the point, clause 5(2) is worded in such a way that it is possible to comply with A but not B and vice versa. In each of those situations there can be an undesirable outcome.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Richardson) agreed to:
(2) Before clause 6, page 6, insert the following heading:
``PART 2-DATA-MATCHING''.
Clause 6 agreed to.
Clause 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. Clause 7, page 7, Step 5, paragraph 13, lines 24 and 25, omit ``Where it is necessary to identify a person for the purposes of paragraph 12'', substitute ``Where the matching of family identity data given by assistance agencies in Step 1 cannot identify a person for the purposes of paragraph 12''.
6. Clause 7, page 8, Step 6, after paragraph 15, add the following paragraph:
``16. Information exchanged in paragraph 15 must not include the return of TFN data from the matching agency to an assistance agency.''.
Amendment No. 4 is designed to tighten the requirement so that it is more specific in terms of when a person cannot be identified. We are not pursuing amendment No. 5.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 8 and 9-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 10.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 7. Clause 10, page 9, after subclause (2), add the following subclause:
``(3) (a) Any action commenced in accordance with subsection (1) hereof, must be commenced within 12 months from the date that the information was received from the matching agency.

``(b) an agency may from time to time apply to the Secretary of its Department or the Commissioner of Taxation (as the case may be) who shall be empowered to grant an extension of time for up to 12 months on such terms of conditions as the Secretary or the Commissioner of Taxation thinks fit.
``(c) notwithstanding any other law or provision to the contrary, the power referred in (b) hereof shall not be capable of delegation.''.

This amendment provides for an action to be commenced within 12 months of the date on which information is received but then provides a mechanism by which agencies can get extensions of time, essentially self-executing, because they will simply apply to the relevant secretary to the department. We believe that that is an effective way of ensuring that there is some control over discipline exercised, that it is not too difficult to obtain extensions while in the ultimate the agencies themselves, through the secretaries, will be accountable.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 8. Clause 10, page 9, after subclause (2), add the following subclause:

``(4) After the completion of action taken in accordance with subsection (1) hereof, a source agency must not retain any information obtained in the course of such action in a separate permanent register of individuals.''.

We see this amendment as enabling material in the aggregate to be retained but we are concerned to ensure that there is not a register that will enable the identification of individuals after the completion of action which has been taken. That is why we move the amendment in that form. It does not preclude the collection and assembling of material.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would prefer that this amendment were not passed, but it is not a great problem so the Government will not oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the basis of increasing discipline in the system-a system which I reiterate that the Australian Democrats do not support-we are supporting this Opposition amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: DATA-MATCHING PROGRAM (ASSISTANCE AND TAX) BILL 1990SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Clause 11.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 9. Clause 11, page 9, after paragraph 11(1) (a), insert the following paragraph:
``(ab) to reject a claim for personal assistance;''.
10. Clause 11, page 9, subclause (5), line 42, after ``prejudice'', insert ``the effectiveness of''.

These two amendments just tighten up the situation. In many respects they are probably just oversights, but in one instance the amendments give additional discretion to provide for an assistance agency to take action, and in the other they ensure that the effectiveness of an investigation is not prejudiced rather than simply the investigation itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts Opposition amendments 9 and 10.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 12.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 11. Clause 12, page 10, lines 11 to 13, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Guidelines relating to privacy

``12. (1) The matching agency and the source agencies are to comply with the interim guidelines set out in the Schedule until guidelines under subsection (2) come into force and, when those guidelines come into force, those agencies are to comply with those guidelines.

``(2) The Privacy Commissioner must, by notice in writing, issue guidelines relating to the matching of data under this Act on or before 30 September 1991 and thereafter may, from time to time, issue further guidelines to replace any existing guidelines.
``(3) The Privacy Commissioner must report to the Parliament any failure to issue guidelines in accordance with subsection (2) within 15 sitting days of 30 September 1991.
``(4) Guidelines under subsection (2) are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.
``(5) Section 46a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 applies to guidelines issued under subsection (2) as if there were inserted after paragraph (1) (a) of that section the following paragraph:
`(aa) section 48 applies as if paragraph 48 (1) (b) were omitted and the following paragraph substituted:
``(b) shall, subject to this section, take effect from:
(i) the first day on which the guidelines are no longer liable to be disallowed; or
(ii) if the guidelines make provision for their commencement after that day-in accordance with that provision.'.''.

The Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), in his second reading speech or, might I say, in various drafts of it, waxed and waned about whether there would be any further guidelines following those currently attached to the schedule. Therefore, we wish to make it clear that we regard what is there at present as interim guidelines. We wish to put a discipline on the Privacy Commissioner in terms of time so that he can address his mind to the current draft set that applies to Commonwealth administration and then specifically decide whether those guidelines or any narrower form ought to apply to this Act. In that way, we will have the matter specifically addressed by the expert rather than simply leave it to the Government as a matter of discretion to judge whether or not it thinks there is a need for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this amendment on the basis that we believe it provides a much better approach to compliance with the guidelines and, therefore, deserves support in strengthening this legislation.

—The Government opposes this amendment. I stated clearly that the guidelines which are before us now will remain in force unless new guidelines are issued which are more protective of clients. If new guidelines were issued that were less protective, we would not be very happy. Neither the Government nor the Parliament ought to abrogate its responsibilities in making a final determination. That is what I would much prefer to see happen. That is all that the Government was suggesting. I do not think it is worth dividing over, but it is an important point which is worth considering.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our concern is that this leaves it entirely in the discretion of the Government and the Executive, not the Parliament. We cannot bring it back and decide that we do not like the interim guidelines or that we prefer another version. We are concerned with avoiding a situation where the Government makes a judgment about whether these are tighter or laxer. In our judgment, that is not adequate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 13 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 12. Page 11, add the following clause:

``13a (1) A breach of Part 2 of this Act or a breach of the guidelines referred to in section 12 constitutes an act or practice involving interference with the privacy of an individual for the purposes of section 13 of the Privacy Act 1988.
`(2) An individual may complain to the Privacy Commissioner about an act or practice in relation to the operation of this Act which may be an interference with the privacy of the individual.
`(3) In the event of a complaint being made by an individual, it shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of part V of the Privacy Act, which shall apply mutatis mutandis to this Act.

This amendment inserts an additional clause 13a after clause 13. The object of the exercise is simply to ensure that the provisions in the Privacy Act that enable breaches to be dealt with will encompass a breach of this Bill. In those circumstances, it would allow for the various rights and remedies that are provided in the Privacy Act to apply to this Bill. At the moment there seems to be a gap that would not allow for injunctions to be obtained, damages awarded or, indeed, any proper investigation carried out of a breach of an individual's privacy under this Bill. For that reason we want to bring the two together.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is also opposed to this amendment. The difficulty I have with the last amendment is that we heard from the Opposition that the Privacy Commissioner's every wish must be observed. With this amendment, even though clause 13 has the agreement of the Privacy Commissioner-it is the approach suggested by him-it is now inadequate. The Government has tried very hard to meet the wishes of the Privacy Commissioner all the way through. There have been extensive consultations with him. We are sticking with clause 13 because it is the approach that he suggested.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, I do not want it to be thought that the Government can be regarded as Robinson Crusoe. We and, I am sure, the Australian Democrats have constantly consulted with the Privacy Commissioner. We have provided him with drafts of all the amendments that we propose to put forward, and we have taken all of his considerations into account. There is nothing that the Minister might have behind his back that would in any way persuade us that the Privacy Commissioner takes a dim view of what we are proposing here.
—It is not a dim view. I am not saying it is a dim view.

SPEECH.PARA: 13. After clause 14, page 12, add the following clause:
Cessation of operation of Act
``15. Parts 1 and 2 of this Act, unless sooner repealed, shall cease to be in force at the expiration of 2 years after the date of commencement of this Act.''.

Amendment No. 13 inserts a sunset clause. Suffice it to say that we regard this as an absolutely crucial part of the new approach that we have outlined. We see this as enabling the Parliament to keep control of the process and make judgments about some of the assertions that have been made. Without wanting to traverse Question Time today, perhaps we will be able to see which of the many predictions about revenue saving will come to pass. But, more importantly, in many respects I think we will be able to determine just what infringements of privacy there might have been, what defects might occur as a result of some of the improvements that we think will be made to the legislation and, ultimately, to make a global judgment on whether the system ought to continue. We are very much concerned about the Government's cynical disregard of its previous promises. On that basis, given the Government's prior convictions for dishonesty, we treat this sunset clause as putting the Government on probation.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Australian Democrats had had their way this legislation would have ridden off into the sunset at the end of the second reading. However, as a compromise we are prepared to support this sunset clause, although we will have to wait two years. We regret that the privacy of many Australian citizens is likely to be impinged upon in that two years. Nevertheless, the Opposition has been able to bring itself to this position, in spite of its earlier opposition to the Australia Card and so on, and so we welcome the amendment and support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

I am confident that the figures that I have given will be borne out. I plead not guilty to the allegations of dishonesty. I have clean hands and I speak with a clean conscience.

TALK.START.PARA: —While amendment No. 14 actually covers a fairly wide range of matters, essentially it aims to provide the Privacy Commissioner with a degree of independence that we do not believe is there at the present time. There are some misconceptions about what might be involved. We do not propose that the Privacy Commissioner be part of the Executive or part of the Parliament as an officer of the Parliament, but rather that he be a statutory officer appointed by the Parliament. The current Privacy Act allows for an interim appointment to be made or for an acting commissioner to be appointed in the event of that position becoming vacant.

SPEECH.PARA: Our proposal would simply enable the Parliament to make a judgment. That is not something that should be shied away from. In many respects, it ought to be welcomed. One would think that the Government would follow the same path that it currently follows in relation to the appointment of High Court judges, that is, to consult with the States. In this instance, the Government would consult with Opposition parties in order to ensure that it put forward a candidate of high calibre. I would have thought that a government acting responsibly would have nothing to fear from that. Any Opposition that chose to reject that nominee capriciously would rightly incur the wrath of the community. Therefore, I would have thought anyone would be very reluctant to oppose such a nominee.

The Opposition sees this amendment as simply a mechanism for ensuring that in future the Privacy Commissioner remains, as best he can, more responsible to Parliament and able to report directly to Parliament and to have a direct line of appropriation so that he does not have to rely on the continuing goodwill of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, as he does at the moment. I hasten to say that no difficulties have been experienced by him in that regard to date, but there is always the possibility that the Government might squeeze the Commission, which would then feel compelled to put the squeeze on the Privacy Commissioner. Our amendment would simply enable him to have a line allocation of his own.

TALK.START.PARA: —He could also squeeze the Parliament; there have been some arguments about that, too.

— Indeed. That is why, in many respects, we are not going to subject him to that process. There could be all sorts of claims by people in this building on who should rank above whom. We are not proposing to subject him to that. We simply suggest that he ought to be entitled to know precisely how much the Government thinks he ought to get, not how much the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission ought to get as a global sum and for him then to hope that he gets what he needs.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not confident that we will have the support of the Australian Democrats on this. It is a matter of regret that they do not appear to be willing to go down this track. In many respects it is a new approach, but I think, given the concerns that the Democrats share for the ways in which this Government has been forced to face up to the privacy considerations virtually as a last resort in order to get this legislation through, this might have been the opportunity to regard the Privacy Commissioner--

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought they were joining us.

—No, they are not supporting us. We were hopeful that they would and I think that, in many respects, they had led a lot of people to think that they were. Unfortunately, they are not, and no doubt Senator Powell will be able to explain that last minute about-face.

(i) in the situation where, at the expiration of twelve months from the commencement of action in accordance with section 10 (1), the case is under the control of the Australian Federal Police and is proceeding to the satisfaction of the source agency-when all investigation action, legal proceedings and repayment of debts due to the Commonwealth is finalised;

(ii) in the situation where, at the expiration of twelve months from the commencement of action in accordance with Section 10 (1), the case is under the control of the Director of Public Prosecutions and is proceeding to the satisfaction of the source agency-when all legal proceedings and repayment of debts due to the Commonwealth are finalised;

(iii) in the situation where, at the expiration of twelve months from commencement of action in accordance with Section 10 (1), a debt due to the Commonwealth remains outstanding and action is being taken to recover it-when the debt is fully recovered, waived or written of; and
(iv) in all other situations, within twelve months from the date of commencement of action in accordance with Section 10 (1).

I have quite a number of comments to make about these amendments, but since the Australian Democrats will be supporting them, I guess many of our concerns, although they might be put on the public record, have been expressed in the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: The guidelines as they appear in the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill 1990 are a watered down version of the draft guidelines that the Privacy Commissioner released in public debate in October this year. There are a number of fairly sloppy situations where, for example, the protocol is outlined, as is the technical standards report. The program protocol has to be presented to the Privacy Commissioner. Nowhere does it say that the program protocol or the technical standards report have to be enforceable.

We have addressed other issues in these amendments. For example, we have ensured that the public is fully informed and that the clients of the source agencies know the purpose for which the information they are giving that agency will be used; that is, in data matching. We have tried, in consultation with the Department, to put in an amendment which will not place undue demands upon the Department, yet give attention to the privacy concerns of the individuals who are providing information.

Another issue we addressed was legislation to strengthen the power of the Privacy Commissioner. In this Bill he is only able to request agencies to provide information. We will give him the power to require such information, which strengthens his powers.

In the last amendment there is a requirement that the matching and source agencies will have to report to the Parliament six months after the first data matching cycle has commenced. I put the Government on notice that if, in the opinion of the Liberal-National parties, these reports from the source agencies and the data matching agency are not adequate, then we will move a motion-I am sure that we will have the support of the Democrats-that the legislation be referred to a select committee for examination so that it fully examines the data matching program prior to the sunset clause coming into effect. We will not be doing this at the eleventh hour; we will do it with due consideration and hopefully we will have the information before us as will be required in that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many of these amendments are acceptable to the Government, but some are not. Amendment 15 on the program protocol requires the disclosure of material prepared for Cabinet. That is a worry. Amendment 17 does not seem to us to make any great sense. It is not descriptive of an individual's rights. The Bill confines agencies to conform to all matters referred to in the protocol. I cannot see any need for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 18 contains the vague term `reasonable steps'. I worry about the use of it, but it is not a great problem. Amendments Nos 19 and 20 are not a great problem. Amendment No. 21 permits the Privacy Commissioner to change the terms of the technical standards report. It will also make non-compliance with the change a breach of the data matching guidelines and subject to remedies under clause 13. This means that an agency could be taken to have breached the data matching guidelines because the Privacy Commissioner has changed the standards without the agency even knowing. It is also highly doubtful whether the Privacy Commissioner will always have access to the expertise sufficient to ensure that those imposed changes are practical. We are dealing with highly technical and complex standards. I do not believe that that is necessarily the Privacy Commissioner's area of expertise. Amendment No. 22 also concerns the technical standards report. That report details how matching will be done technologically and how security will be ensured. Again, it is not prescriptive of the rights of any individual. Of course, the Bill obliges agencies to follow the standards laid down.

The other amendment that concerns me is amendment No. 26. This amendment provides for an additional guideline requiring a source agency to delete information about action taken against a person as a result of a data match when that action is complete. There is already in existence a disposal schedule in accordance with the Archives Act under which destruction would occur within a set period after a person ceases to be a client. We believe that to be an adequate protection. The other amendments are acceptable. I think some of them are unnecessary, but none of them interfere with the integrity of the Bill. The Government opposes the amendments that I have just referred to.
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to page 5 of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill, clause 5 (q), which is a re-definition of `prescribed student child'. The Government has taken that measure to overcome a position that I raised in this chamber as far back as May of this year. I raised a case of a person who was living in Port Arthur in Tasmania; that person had appealed against the removal of family allowance when her child reached 16 because she was receiving a boarding allowance for a student child under the assistance for isolated children (AIC) scheme. I asked the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) whether he had noted that the Social Security Appeals Tribunal said that, because of the technical interpretation of section 81 of the Social Security Act, the appellant's appeal could not be upheld but that her case was `a reasonable case' and that it seemed `unreasonable that receipt of AIC . . . should disqualify receipt of family allowance'.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a fair amount of toing and froing about that matter; in the end, when the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 came before the chamber on 29 May, I moved an amendment to give effect to the views of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and to have the matter rectified. The Minister responded by indicating that this was a very important question, that there was a question of justice involved and that, as Minister for Social Security, he was concerned that any injustice should be rectified. He indicated that, so far as the Government was concerned, he believed that this was a matter that should be rectified.

I appreciate that the Minister has rectified the problem, but he has done so in a manner that has not taken account of the fact that the person who was affected and whose case actually highlighted the injustice has still not received a payment. I refer the Minister to the comments that he made in respect of this matter when I moved the same amendment to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill last session. On 29 May 1990 the Minister said:
There is a problem with the drafting of Senator Harradine's amendment which, I think, renders the Committee incapable of agreeing to it. Senator Harradine's amendment proposes an amendment . . .
the Minister described the problem, and said:

Of course, it is feasible that an amendment with the same effect as Senator Harradine's could be drafted, but this would not be an easy task. It would be quite a complicated one, and I do not believe that we would be able to achieve that tonight.
Later, the Minister said:
If one goes back to-
and he mentioned the case-

. . . from which this arose, it should be noted that when Senator Harradine raised this matter in the Senate I said that it was the only case of its kind. I appeal to the Minister to honour the undertaking that he gave on the previous occasion and to take action in this case.

(b) money invested by way of an accruing return investment, or a market-linked investment, to which Division 2 of Part 1 applies; and
(c) money given to an exempt organisation on the condition that the money be repaid, whether or not interest is payable on the money;''.
3. Clause 6, page 3, subclause (1), proposed subsections 4c (2) and (3), lines 11 to 15, omit the subsections.
4. Clause 6, page 3, subclause (1), after proposed subsection (6), insert the following subsection:

`` `(6a) Where circumstances occur because of which the whole or part of a loan will never be repaid, that loan, or that part of the loan, as the case may be, ceases to be a loan for the purposes of this section.''.
5. Clause 6, page 3, proposed subsection 4c (a), lines 36 and 37, omit the subsection.
6. Clause 21, page 15, subclause (1), proposed subsection 50b (1), before the definition of ``interest'', insert the following definition:

`` `exempt organisation' means an institution, society, association, club or other organisation whose income is exempt from income tax under section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and which provides aged care and/or welfare services as its principal activity;''.
7. Clause 21, page 15, subclause (1), proposed subsection 50b (1), after the definition of ``interest'', insert the following definition:
`` `loan', in relation to a person, means money given by the person to another person on condition that it be repaid but does not include:

(c) money given to an exempt organisation on the condition that the money be repaid, whether or not interest is payable on the money;''.
8. Clause 21, page 15, subclause (1), proposed subsections 50b (2) and (3), lines 9 to 13, omit the proposed subsections.
9. Clause 21, page 15, subclause (1), after proposed subsection 50b (6), insert the following subsection:

`` `(6A) Where circumstances occur because of which the whole or part of a loan will never be repaid, that loan, or that part of the loan, as the case may be, ceases to be a loan for the purposes of this section.''.
10. Clause 21, page 15, lines 28 and 29, 50b (7), omit the proposed subsection.
