QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Jindalee project considered by the Defence Force Development Committee; if so, on what dates; if not, why not.
(2) When was the prime contract let.
(3) What was the planned: (a) cost when the prime contract was let; and (b) completion date for the contract.
(4) Have any sub-contracts been let; if so, how many.
(5) For major sub-contracts, please provide the: (a) date when let; (b) cost; and (c) nature of good contracted.
(6) Is the project: (a) still on time; and (b) on budget; if not, in each case, why not.
(7) What are the principal points and dates at which the Commonwealth must approve the payment of monies under this contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Jindalee Operational Radar Network project was considered by the Defence Force Development Committee (DFDC) on 24 July 1986. Although the project has subsequently been considered by other senior defence committees, it has not been referred back to the DFDC.

(2) to (7) Evaluation of tenders and selection of a prime contractor are currently underway; a prime contract has not yet been let. Matters of contract cost and completion date, sub-contracts, delivery schedule and payment of monies are still to be resolved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the New Utility (Blackhawk) Helicopter project considered by the Defence Force Development Committee; if so, what dates; if not, why not.
(2) When was the prime contract let.
(3) What was the planned: (a) cost when the prime contract was let; and (b) completion date for the contract.
(4) Have any sub-contracts been let; if so, how many.
(5) For major sub-contracts, please provide the: (a) date when let; (b) cost; and (c) nature of goods contracted.
(6) Is the project: (a) still on time; and (b) on budget; if not, in each case, why not.
(7) What are the principal points and dates at which the Commonwealth must approve the payment of monies under this contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Defence Force Development Committee considerations leading to procurement decisions occurred in August 1984, November 1985 and April 1987.
(2) The prime contract was let on 29 May 1986.
(3) The planned cost of the prime contract (initially for 14 aircraft) was $A179.275m (September 1985 prices).
An option to purchase an additional 25 aircraft was exercised in May 1987, at a further cost of $A288.421m (September 1985 prices).
The planned completion date for the contract as of May 1987 was September 1990.

(4) and (5) No sub-contracts have been let by the Commonwealth; however, many have been let by the prime contractor, United Technologies Corporation. Information about these sub-contracts is Commercial-In-Confidence between the prime contractor and the sub-contractors.

(6) An eight month delay has been caused by slower than expected assembly, inspection and test (AIT) of the aircraft by the main Australian sub-contractor, resulting, in part, from early under-estimation of the size and complexity of the task.

A project cost decrease from $A749.750m (April 1987 prices) to $A708.581m (April 1990 prices) has resulted from rationalisation by Air Force of logistic support requirements in the project, and the effect of exchange rate changes, particularly in FY 1987/88 and FY 1989/90.
(7) Payment of monies against the contract is tied to physical milestones (over 80 in all). The final milestone payment is due to be paid in February 1991.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Austeyr F88 project considered by the Defence Force Development Committee; if so, on what dates; if not, why not.
(2) When was the prime contract let.
(3) What was the planned: (a) cost when the prime contract was let; and (b) completion date for the contract.
(4) Have any sub-contracts been let; if so, how many.
(5) For major sub-contracts, please provide the: (a) date when let; (b) cost; and (c) nature of goods contracted.
(6) Is the project: (a) still on time; and (b) on budget; if not, in each case, why not.
(7) What are the principal points and dates at which the Commonwealth must approve the payment of monies under this contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. It was considered on 14 November 1985.
(2) Purchase Orders were raised on the Commonwealth Small Arms Factory Lithgow on 3 February 1987 for the manufacture and supply of weapons and ancillaries.
(3) The planned cost was $105.750m (April 1985 prices) and the planned completion date was March 1994.
(4) Yes. Australian Defence Industries (ADI) Lithgow Facility (formerly Small Arms Factory Lithgow) have let 12 sub-contracts.
(5) Major sub-contracts let by ADI Lithgow Facility for the AUSTEYR project are as follows:
4 Mar 87-Magazine Plastic Parts.
3 Aug 87-Optical Sight Units.
5 Mar 87-Die Cast Housing Units.
18 Aug 87-Butt Plates.
10 Mar 87-Guide Tubes &Rods.
10 Mar 87-Plastic Mouldings (except
10 Mar 87-magazine).
1 May 87-Various Machined Items.
The other information sought about these sub-contracts is Commercial-In-Confidence information that is not held by the Department of Defence.

(6) (a) Completion of delivery of the first main production weapons is currently 17 months behind schedule. This is due to difficulties encountered in the transfer of technology from the Austrian designer and manufacturer of the rifle and a problem related to Australian ammunition propellant. It is anticipated that completion of all deliveries will only be six months behind schedule.
(b) The project is still on budget.
(7) Payment of monies under the contract are on a performance milestone basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the PARAKEET Tactical Communications project considered by the Defence Force Development Committee? If so, on what dates? If not why not?
(2) When was the prime contract let.
(3) What was the planned: (a) cost when the prime contract was let; and (b) completion date for the contract.
(4) Have any sub-contracts been let; if so, how many.
(5) For major sub-contracts, please provide the: (a) date when let; (b) cost; and (c) nature of goods contracted.
(6) Is the project: (a) still on time; and (b) on budget; if not, in each case, why not.
(7) What are the principal points and dates at which the Commonwealth must approve the payment of monies under this contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The project has not involved issues that needed to be referred to the Defence Force Development Committee.
(2) The prime contract has not been let. Contracts were let for previous completed phases as follows:
Phase 1. Concept Studies, completed in 1982 at a project cost of $0.79m (July 1984 prices).
Phase 2. System Definition, completed in 1984 at a project cost of $3.857m (September 1984 prices).
Phase 3. Equipment Definition, completed in 1988 at a project cost of $14.113m (April 1989 prices).
(3) to (5) See answer to (2) above.
(6) (a) No. Issue of the Requests for Tender for supply of equipment for PARAKEET have been delayed awaiting completion of an internal review of the Defence Communications requirement.
(b) Yes.
(7) These are to be negotiated on a performance milestone basis as part of awarding contracts for the supply of equipment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Seahawk Helicopters project considered by the Defence Force Development Committee; if so, on what dates; if not, why not.
(2) When was the prime contract let.
(3) What was the planned: (a) cost when the prime contract was let; and (b) completion date for the contract.
(4) Have any sub-contracts been let; if so, how many.
(5) For major sub-contracts, please provide the: (a) date when let; (b) cost; and (c) nature of goods contracted.
(6) Is the project: (a) still on time; and (b) on budget; if not, in each case, why not.
(7) What are the principal points and dates at which the Commonwealth must approve the payment of monies under this contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Defence Force Development Committee considerations leading to procurement decisions occurred in November 1983, August 1984 and April 1986.
(2) The prime contract was let on 30 June 1985.

(3) The planned cost when the prime contract was let (initially for 8 aircraft) was $A241.281m (January 1984 prices). An option to purchase an additional 8 aircraft was exercised in May 1986. The planned cost of the total of 16 aircraft was $A370.388m (January 1984 prices) and at that time acceptance of the final aircraft was scheduled for September 1989.

(4) &(5) No sub-contracts have been let by the Commonwealth; however, many have been let by the prime contractor, United Technologies Corporation. These sub-contracts are Commercial-In-Confidence between the Prime and the Sub-contractors.
(6) The final aircraft is now due for acceptance in June 1991. The delay has been caused by difficulties experienced in developing the unique RAN Weapons System.
(7) Payment of monies occurs on completion and acceptance of physical milestones (over 100 in all).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Australian Frigates (FFGs 05 and 06) project considered by the Defence Force Development committee; if so, on what dates; if not, why not.
(2) When was the prime contract let.
(3) What was the planned: (a) cost when the prime contract was let; and (b) completion date for the contract.
(4) Have any sub-contracts been let; if so, how many.
(5) For major sub-contracts, please provide the: (a) date when let; (b) cost; and (c) nature of goods contracted.
(6) Is the project: (a) still on time; and (b) on budget; if not, in each case, why not.
(7) What are the principal points and dates at which the Commonwealth must approve the payment of monies under this contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Frigate Project was considered by the Defence Force Development Committee in July 1980, November 1980 and August 1981.

(2) The initial prime ``contract'' was an agreement between the Australian Frigate Project and the then Williamstown Naval Dockyard. Following the sale of the dockyard to Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON) in early 1988, the Australian Frigate Project contracted AMECON to complete the construction of FFG 05 and 06 in February 1988.

(3) The contract price when the contract with AMECON was let was $403,549,410 (June 1987 prices). The contract completion date is November 1993. Additionally, $147m was spent under the previous production agreement with Williamstown Naval Dockyard prior to its privatisation, and the Commonwealth has entered into Foreign Military Sales agreements with the USA for the acquisition of a broad range of ships systems costing more than $250m which are to be provided as Government Furnished Equipment to AMECON. The balance of the project costs comprises provision for spares, stores and other miscellaneous equipments required for completion of the project.
(4) Approximately 100 sub-contracts have been let.

(5) The only major sub-contract let by AMECON to date has been for the construction of hull and superstructure units by Eglo in Newcastle and Adelaide. They were let in February 1989. Cost information for these sub-contracts is Commercial-In-Confidence and the Commonwealth does not have access to this information.
(6) The Project remains on time and within budget.
(7) The Commonwealth makes monthly progress payments to AMECON.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Minehunter Inshore project considered by the Defence Force Development committee; if so, on what dates; if not, why not.
(2) When was the prime contract let.
(3) What was the planned: (a) cost when the prime contract was let; and (b) completion date for the contract.
(4) Have any sub-contracts been let; if so, how many.
(5) For major sub-contracts, please provide the: (a) date when let; (b) cost; and (c) nature of goods contracted.
(6) Is the project: (a) still on time; and (b) on budget; if not, in each case, why not.
(7) What are the principal points and dates at which the Commonwealth must approve the payment of monies under this contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minehunter Inshore (MHI) Project was considered by the Defence Force Development Committee in April 1976.
(2) The MHI Project consists of the following:
Phase 1. Project Definition Studies, approved at a cost of $1.594m (April 1988 prices) was completed in September 1988;
Phase 2. Prototype Construction and Evaluation, approved at a cost of $112.109m (April 1990 prices) is in progress and due for completion in mid 1992;
Phase 2C Trials of Alternative Minehunting Weapons Systems approved at a cost of $19.1m (April 1990 prices) is in progress and due for completion in mid 1992; and
Phase 3. Production of MHI has not yet been approved.

The major contract in Phase 2 of the MHI Project, was the Shipbuilding Contract. This contract, for provision of a Shipbuilding Facility and two prototype Minehunters, was let to Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd on 28 January 1983.
(3) At the time of letting the shipbuilding contract the cost was $22.927m (January 1983 prices) and the completion date was 28 April 1986.
(4) Some 690 subsidiary contracts were let in support of the MHI Project.
(5) Details of the four major subsidiary contracts are as follows:
On 11 January 1982 a contract was awarded to SCHOTTEL-Holland for 3 Ship sets of Minimum Magnetic Propulsion Steering Units at a cost of $4.230m;
On 2 February 1982 a contract was awarded to POYAUD-France for 3 Ships Sets of Minimum Magnetic Propulsion/Generator Diesel Engines at a cost of $1.049m;
On 22 July 1981 a contract was awarded to KAE-Germany for 3 Containerised Minehunting Weapons Systems and associated supplies and services at a cost of $15.085m; and
On 29 April 1983 a contract was awarded to ECA-France for 3 Ships sets of PAP 104 MK3 Mine Disposal System at a cost of $3.255m.

(6) All equipments with the exception of the Minehunting Weapons System have been delivered and accepted. The failure of the KAE Minehunting Weapons System has resulted in deferral of the production decision by up to four years. To overcome the Minehunting Weapons System deficiency, a new sub phase (Phase 2C) of the MHI project was approved in the context of the 1990 Budget at a cost of $19.1m to allow the conduct of comparative trials of two Minehunting Weapons Systems by mid 1992.
(7) The payment of monies under the contracts is tied to physical milestones.
